reviewText: A very bad screenplay adaptation of the novel.A very bad movie in general.pro:- Effects are generally good, except for the main Mars alien face designs which look cartoony in an otherwise realistic world.con:- Poor overblown acting once the story gets to mars... which is 95% of the film.- EXTREMELY bad script with non-stop unlikely plot driven coincidences.  Nothing that happens in the film naturally 'leads' to anything else-- plot events just happen one after another strung together by impossible coincidences.- Bad TV style editing and camera angles.- Relentless BG soundtrack, which is so overblown that it becomes distracting.- Also surprisingly BORING since the viewer doesn't care about the characters or what is going on despite all the ridiculous cartoony action, which is a killer for a movie of this length.-story summary: Bad guy is bad, good guy is good, there is no character development.  Everyone in the movie takes a turn at beating up the good guy like a roadrunner cartoon-- this is supposed to generate sympathy for his plight/struggle-- but since the good guy is obviously invincible it doesn't matter.  And on Mars a giant mars-frog-dog runs in super-sonically and licks the good guy's face after each time he gets beat up-- which is supposed to be funny.  Eventually people stop beating up the good guy, good guy falls in love with the cute Mars Princess after about three days and marries her, and the bad guy dies.  Good guy accidentally teleports back to Earth, spends the next 10 years becoming a billionaire and trying to teleport back to Mars, which takes about 5 minutes of screen time-- he succeeds.  THE END.point of movie: noneaction/excitement: brainless adult or 5 year olds and underbuy/rent/skip: skipadditional notes: do not listen to your friends with kids who tell you what a 'great' movie this is. . .I love sci-fi action movies. . . but this one is pure refined big-budget garbage.  I'd call it a polished turd, but that would be an insult to turds.
summary: This is a very bad movie!

reviewText: Flash Gordon.That's right, I said it.  For all the modern fascination with special effects, BLUE aliens, metal suits, flying fortresses and capes, my memories drift back to a childhood high cheese favorite named Flash Gordon.  See, in Flash Gordon, this human guy got mixed up in some bad alien juju at the hands of a bald bad guy.  Flying, fighting and high hokum of the Saturday night matinee ensue.  This is precisely what John Carter is.  In fact, John Carter has easily out Flash Gordon'd every single Star Wars prequel because George Lucas's pointless toy commercial epics never had the entertainment or fun factor Andrew Stanton's epic has here.What is wrong with people?How John Carter has been hated on is beyond me.  Wait, I get it, Avatar's aliens are blue not green!  Wait, the Avengers has a bigger flying fortress! Captain America, oh that's right, has a BLUE suit! We was robbed, because John Carter is a total sendup of the old style Disney nonsense adventures like Mary Poppins, Way Down Cellar and the original Escape to Witch Mountain.So let's get this straight, people will pay to see Loki stand around in those ridiculous plastic gold horns for two hours but not this?  What about the dog?  John Carter has that hilarious butt kicking dog!At least see it for the dog.  Did I mention the dog?

reviewText: OK, you can read a couple of hundred reviews here about how the movie was unjustly overlooked, how it lost Disney millions of dollars at the box office, etc.  All true.  But I just want to comment on how fantastic the film looks on Blu-ray hi-def.  John Carter is that rare film which combines an intelligent and entertaining story with state-of-the-art visual effects.  Truly, it is a feast for the eyes.  If you're among those movie lovers who is still holding out on upgrading to Blu-ray, this is the movie that should convince you.The bonus features are also plentiful--which I found a pleasant surprise, given the lukewarm box-office performance--and really do a lot to enhance one's enjoyment of the film.  There's a feature on adapting E.R. Burroughs' original stories to the screen, and John Carter's "journal," which can be viewed simultaneously with the film.  There are even some amusing "Barsoom Bloopers" and a featurette on the amazing special effects."John Carter" should have been the Star Wars of a new generation.  And by the way, when I say "Star Wars" I'm talking about the original 1977 film.  Watching JC in the theater, I really felt the way I did watching George Lucas's original flight of space fantasy way back when.  I'm happy to report the movie loses almost none of its splendor on the home screen.  But again, Blu-ray is an absolute must to savor every pixel of the fantastic world of Barsoom.  Buy it!
summary: This is what Blu-ray what made for!

reviewText: Okay, so I had no intention of ever watching this movie so I never added it to my Netflix list.  Mostly based on two facts: the critics hated it and it was a box office bomb.  That said, my teenage son borrowed it from his friend and after I told him what a bomb it was, he said that his grandma (my mom) said it was really good.  Not wanting to waste over two hours of my time, I came here to look up the reviews which were very good.  After the first 15-20 minutes I was hooked!  I thought the Tharks and Therns (?) were quite interesting races.  I loved the amazement they all had of John Carter and his jumping abilities.  And of course what kind of girl would I be if I didn't enjoy a bit of love interest.  My son thought the "dog" (or whatever it was) was very cool.  I keep wondering why this movie did so poorly at the box office and all I can think of, aside from poor critics reviews, is that they should have given it a different title.  The title "John Carter" is too main stream for a sci-fi movie.  I'm thinking "Return to Bardoom" would have been a better title...but that's just me.  There will never be a movie which will be enjoyed by 100% of it's audience but overall, I'm happy that I did see this one and would recommend!

reviewText: Not nearly as bad as the critics say, but not great, either. It was a script problem; I can't find fault with the acting, directing, effects, cinematography, etc -- but I felt no affinity towards any of the characters. The overall concept also isn't one that merited a $175 million budget, much less advance planning for two blockbuster sequels, because this golden-age story just isn't compelling enough for today's science fiction. It would be like declaring 20,000 Leagues Under the Sea to be the "next big thing" and committing the franchise to three $200 million blockbusters.

reviewText: I have no idea why the critics lambasted this movie, I can only assume they were huffing glue or something. John Carter is an awesome old-school romp that fans of Edgar Rice Burroughs both new and old can enjoy.John Carter has an excellent cast and a screenplay that was co-authored by Michael Chabon, so for once the story isn't one tired Hollywood cliche after another, but a ripping yarn that reminded me favorably of Raiders of the Lost Ark or Star Wars. John Carter is as resourceful as Indiana Jones, and Thars Tharkas is so finely drawn that he nearly steals the show.Do yourself a favor, ignore the critics and give this a try, I'm glad I did!

reviewText: My $30 gamble paid off on this film. It has vastly more visual, dramatic, and narrative value than implied by its disasterous marketing. I took a chance that the trailers had  misrepresented the film. (In fact, I bought it mostly so that I could test out the 3D playback on my Sony/PS3 system with a movie I hadn't caught before). Amazingly, the trailers that promoted JC's original release contained the *dullest frames* of the entire picture - making it appear to be a CGI snoozefest like Transformers. In fact, there is very little of that in this film; while CGI is a massive component, it it used to realize a distinct vision. I'm hoping to see a different world/reality than anything I've seen before when I watch a Fantasy film; ideally, one which is beautiful to look at. And this is what I got out of this film. It drew me in. It feels as though there's more to this world than the backdrop of an expensive beat 'em up. Anyway, this film is great to look at & is a surprisingly entertaining way to spend two and a half hours, but remains an unsung sleeper and not a blockbuster. It's not a five star success because: (a) it is played straight, throughout... this is Flash Gordon without the camp, and (b) the heroes are substantially less interesting that the antagonists (Mark Strong & Dominic West). On the other hand, these uncomplicated/unrelatable heroes are set against non-CGI villains - one reason that this is a lot more fun than something like Cowboys & Aliens.

reviewText: The way this film was short changed, by both the Disney marketing dept (who apparently couldn't sell ice cream cones at high noon in Tucson in August) and the critics (who seem to always equate controversial, sarcastic and/or mean spirited fare with "good" and are confused when a film doesn't fall into one or more of these categories) borders on being a crime.This film has about the best adaptation of the classic Edgar Rice Burroughs Mars stories that one could hope for. Sure there are a few harmless tweaks here and there to keep up with the times (the native Americans that pursue Carter at the beginning of the tale are now seriously provoked before doing so, Dejah Thoris besides being a loyal defender of her people and displaying significant sex appeal now has a doctorate in Barsoomian physics as well, etc). But the heart of Burroughs fantasy remains. Carter and Dejah are suitably heroic, the Therns are appropriately villainous, the Tharks are portrayed wonderfully, and Woola is both steadfast and whimsical without becoming the Martian Jar Jar Binks.This is a **GOOD** movie, it just probably doesn't have enough profanity, graphic violence and all around nihilism to keep jaded professional critics engaged. For most of the rest of us, it's a solid couple hours worth of escapist entertainment, and it's just sad that we'll never get to see where sequels could have taken things (the Therns in particular, being an obviously much greater threat than in the original tales, could have been explored further in the followup films we'll never see.)
summary: Any critic that's made a better adventure movie, please raise your hand...

reviewText: I read the entire series when I was young. It was a simple, action/romance driven story, and I always thought that when special effects had advanced enough, the first book A Princess of Mars would lend itself well to a simple screenplay and a great movie. This is not that movie. This is part of the first book, part of the second book, and numerous awful plot changes which are confusing to those who haven't read the books, and aggravating to those who have. Why are the Therns immortal intergalactic bad guys like the one in Star Gate who can shape shift? They changed everything about them other than the name Thern and the fact there are bald. What is it with the ninth ray wrist gun thing? What are all those flaps sticking out of the flyers, which are repeatedly describred in the book as "sleek"? Where did the medallions come from? There are literally hundreds of story line changes which can't be explained as making for a better screenplay. At least the appalling version done by the Asylum stuck to the basic story. I give this bloated epic two stars instead of one, for Bryan Cranston's backhanded humor in the blonde wig, and some of the special effects and action scenes.
summary: No, reading the book doesn't help

reviewText: Ignore the critics, talk of the cost of the film; director Andrew Stanton shot the story line perfect.  With splendid special effects, you are emerged in the world of John Carter.  Like James Cameron's Avatar, you will follow a broken warrior's journey to self redemption.  John Carter is a drifter after being a cavalry officer in the Civil War.  He no longer finds love in his heart, wandering lost without a purpose.  By accident, he teleports to Mars and discovers new meaning and new purpose.  The world of Mars explodes on screen, creatures, a war that is being fought in front of him, and he is given new powers due to the gravity of Mars.  John Carter could make a difference in this war if he so chooses.Edgar Rice Burroughs wrote this before Superman, Star Wars, Avatar, Starship Troopers, and Dune.  I read three of the book series by him and have waited 35 years to see a screen adaptation.  I was not dissapointed at all.  Disney, the cast, especially the leads and Willem Dafoe, did a splendid job.  I saw the picture twice on opening weekend, 2D and IMAX 3-D.  Everyone that I know who has seen this picture has liked it.  This film is far better than The Prince of Persia.  I only hope that Disney does a second film from the book series.
summary: JOHN CARTER The Original Sci-Fi Series

reviewText: 1977 was a transformative year in my life.  It started with the discovery of my first "Conan the Barbarian" comic book at the Eckerd drug store near my house.  Little did I know at the time that I had just crossed the threshold into a whole new world of endless wonders.  This discovery soon led me to the "John Carter: Warlord of Mars" comic that Marvel was publishing at the time, and in a short couple of months I was immersed in the amazing artwork of Frank Frazetta, as well as the original pulp stories and novels by authors like Robert E. Howard, and of course, Edgar Rice Burroughs.  1977 also marked the premiere of a little known film at the time called "Star Wars".  I have often said over the last 35 years that the first time I saw "Star Wars" was the single best time I've ever had at the movies, and while there have certainly been a lot of great films in the last three decades, I was convinced that movies simply didn't have the power to make me feel like that again.  I was wrong.  "John Carter" managed to do what I thought was impossible: make me feel like that wide-eyed 11 year old kid again.  It goes without saying that I've been waiting for this film for 35 years, but it was worth the wait.  "John Carter" exceeded - no, shattered - my expectations.The original "Princess of Mars" is one of my favorite novels of all time.  I've read it so many times over the last three decades that I've lost count, and while some Edgar Rice Burroughs fans were disappointed or even outraged at the deviations from the original source material, in my humble opinion the changes were in most of not all cases justified.  Bob Clampett, the first person who tried to get a John Carter film off the ground in the 1930s, said this about his meetings with Burroughs: "Edgar was smart enough to understand that one couldn't just literally translate his Mars books page by page into animation; it just would not be cinematic. So, he gave me a great deal of freedom to dream up and be inspired by his writing and develop a cartoon story on my own."  While ERB was a tremendously gifted author, his works aren't without flaws, and they're a bit dated; there's very little moral ambiguity, he often recycles his own plot twists, and his plots often rely on coincidence.  Additionally, ERB's heroes tend to be sort of Mary Sue characters with no visible physical or moral flaws. I can't see how John Carter or Ulysses Paxton or Cathoris or Gahan would behave differently in the similar circumstances.  So I can see why Stanton chose to give John Carter some personal angst and some character development in order to sell him to modern audiences.  Some have argued that Stanton's changes have rendered a character unrecognizable to fans of the original novels, but I would ask them "what characteristics define John Carter as a character?"  There's the physical characteristics: black hair (though it's closely cropped in the original novels...no biggie), heightened strength and agility, fairly tall, good looking, in excellent physical health, and agelessness. Although the last characteristic was not overtly stated in the film, it was highly suggested, if people pay attention to the subtle clues in the film. How could Carter, a man who appears to be about the age of thirty (as in the novel) possibly have been able to hold ERB on his knee when ERB was a child and tell him about his wild adventures all over the world? Was Carter doing this as a teenager? And then there's the fact that Carter doesn't age at all during the ten bitter years exiled back on Earth, when the effects wizards could easily have accomplished this with some rudimentary makeup effects.Then there's Carter's personality: Fearless, willing to throw himself in harm's way against impossible odds; selfless, willing to lay down his life for others; Carter behaves consistent with these characteristics throughout the film, even while he's giving lip service to "only caring about his cave of gold". He rescues Powell from the Apaches when he could have just left him to die; when he sees the air battle between Zodanga and Helium, he expresses his innate sense of justice and fairness with the remark "That don't look like a fair fight!" and then he throws himself into the thick of the battle when he spots Dejah (whom he doesn't even know) in imminent danger.Some argue that the dead wife and child back-story and Carter's initial reluctance to get involved transform Carter into a character unrecognizable to ERB fans, but I disagree.  I saw a character onscreen that was TRYING not to be noble and selfless because of a personal loss, but was failing at it, and I think the dichotomy enriched the story and drove home the values that were important to Burroughs.  This point is driven home by Dejah Thoris, who sees through the wall he's built around himself. My favorite line of the film: "We may be worlds apart, but I know you, John Carter. From the moment you caught me out of the sky, I knew. I felt the heart of a man willing to lay down his life for others". That fits ERB's character to a tee.  Without the back-story, that line would not have worked....which brings us to the character changes to Dejah Thoris.  The main difference is the fact that this Dejah Thoris can actually fight, but I can't believe in this post Princess Leia, post Sarah Conner, post Ripley world that either ERB fans or film fans in general were expecting anything less, or would accept a Dejah Thoris who is physically helpless. This concept was outdated even in the late seventies when Marv Wolfman and Chris Clairemont were penning the "John Carter: Warlord of Mars" comics, and even then, having read the original novels during the same time period, I welcomed this enhancement. One has to remember that when "A Princess of Mars" was written in the early 20th Century, women were supposed to be prim and proper at all times, and "respectable" women rarely even worked out of the home. They didn't even have the right to vote. A woman who was basically helpless to the whims of the man who controlled her (either her father or husband) was the norm rather than the exception. Such outdated conventions would never work in a modern film, unless it was a period piece specifically made to highlight such inequality.The Therns are much more powerful in the film than in the original novels. But the Therns in Burroughs' novels are actually pretty weak when their secrets are exposed, and ERB never really went anywhere with them, other than to have their leader kidnap Dejah Thoris and flee from John Carter (continuously). Burroughs' original concept is compelling, but I think for the sake of drama one must make the "bad guys" much more powerful than the good guys so that they have a near insurmountable task to overcome. How are the Therns similar to ERBs? They're using a false religion as a global scam to exploit the entire civilization and keep themselves in power, so the subtext is pretty similar.Zodanga isn't even mentioned in "A Princess of Mars" until the last 5th of it, and this simply wouldn't work in a feature film.  But Burroughs original pro-environmental message remains intact.  Barsoom is a dying planet, its oceans have long since dried up, and Zodanga is selfishly consuming the lion's share of the dwindling resources and making war on its neighbors rather than cooperating with them to find a solution. It was Stanton and Chabon's way of making the theme contemporary while still acknowledging the original source material.In summary, I think that overall the film is a much more balanced and coherent narrative than the novel it's based on, and it's remarkably true to the spirit of it, certainly truer than any other ERB adaptation in the last century.  And the pacing and scope of the film, as well as Michael Giacchino's magnificent score (that simultaneously manages to channel both John Williams and Basil Poledouris at their best - seriously, this is one of the best soundtracks of all time) bring to mind the classic films of the 70s and 80's, the kinds of films they don't make anymore but you wish they did, like "Star Wars" and "Superman" and "Raiders of the Lost Ark".  I loved all the actors in their respective roles, and thought Taylor Kitsch was near perfect as John Carter, but the real gem in this film is Lynn Collins' performance as Dejah Thoris. I was initially skeptical when I found out she had been cast as "the most beautiful woman on two worlds", but she OWNED the role, both physically and performance wise.  She IS Dejah Thoris.I simply can't recommend this film enough.  After my first viewing, I was numb; on my second, I soaked in and savored every frame of it.  On the third and subsequent viewings, I literally wept at how good it was. The only thing preventing this film from being considered a classic is the fact that not enough people have seen it yet, but that situation will change.  Mark my words: like "Blade Runner" and other films that initially met with a cool reception, the decades are going to be kind to "John Carter".

reviewText: Like a lot of folks, I read the John Carter series as a kid.  Then I read them again as a young adult.  And I re-read them again a few years ago (I'm now in my 50's).  I'd seen the lame attempts at trying to bring ERB's John Carter to the silver screen and kept wondering "When is a real studio going to take interest in this?"And finally, a "real" studio (Disney) has stepped up to the plate and brought the world a worthy adaptation of ERB's John Carter saga.Is it a perfect adaptation?  Nah...But it is pretty close.What didn't work for me:* Many of the longer shots were too tightly framed.  Barsoom needed a sense of greater space.* Taylor Kitsch has adequate acting chops, but the character of John Carter is a hard man.  IMHO, TK just didn't have the gravitas to pull it off effectively.  He was pretty, but I just didn't see hard-won military experience and intense emotional loss in his face.  (This leaves me wondering why the director didn't consider either Mark Strong, Willem Dafoe, or another, more life-experienced actor, since they would have been more effective in portraying JC than Kitsch.  Kitsch's JC really needed a few more miles on him.)* Barsoom was entirely too bright (minor physics queep, I know, but the director/editors should have toned down the day shots to better approximate the actual Mars).* The bromance between Tars Tarkas and JC seemed heavily downplayed.  In the books, these two were fast friends and reliable battle partners.  It was there in this movie, but seemed to be brushed off to the side a bit.* The lead-in segment was 5-10 minutes too long.  It needed to be edited down. (Although I did enjoy the humorous bits.)What did work:* The story: While an obvious blending of different parts of the first two books, as an adaptation, it hung together pretty well.* The technical execution and art direction were first-rate-bordering-on-brilliant, especially the airships.  The other sets, props, and even the Tharks, all had that definite Barsoomian something.  Woola was awesome.* Lynn Collins is the embodiment on Earth of Dejah Thoris in all of her smoldering, fierce, egg-laying glory.* The end segment.  Shorter and more effective at getting JC back to Barsoom.Overall, I thought it was okay, but it just didn't invoke the sense of alien awesomeness that the books do.  I'll definitely buy the BD when it comes out (especially if it has an additional 46 minutes of footage featuring more Dejah...)  I'd definitely like to see a sequel though, to see if the director can round things out a bit more and maybe bring a darker, more adult sensibility to life on Barsoom.  A little less swash and a little more buckle, I'm thinking...BTW, folks that insist on comparing this to Star Wars, Avatar, et al. may certainly be correct in comparing film-to-film.  As for who's deriving from whom though, they should keep in mind that ERB wrote his JC series 100 years ago.  And it's highly unlikely that Star Wars, Avatar, or what-have-you, would even exist in their present forms if ERB's John Carter series had not been written to inspire those stories' creators.
summary: Not without its problems, but I liked it...

reviewText: When I first saw trailers for John Carter I more or less ignored them, certain that Hollywood would pillage another work of popular literature. Bored on a Sunday afternoon, I decided to stream John Carter after reading the reviews here. John Carter is based on the first two Barsoom books by Edgar Rice Burroughs, a wildly popular novelist of the late nineteenth and early twentieth century who is best known for the Tarzan novels. His sci-fi fantasy/adventure series was less well known in its time, but like the Tarzan novels is still read.John Carter follows the plot and character development of A Princess of Mars and Gods of Mars far more faithfully than I expected. Granted, the source material isn't Milton, but many a popular novel has been stripped of what complexity it has by the Hollywood machine asumptions that American teens and adults cannot follow even the simplest plot. John Carter keeps the plot intact. The look of the movie is perfect as are the two leads: they look every inch the Barbarian Princess and the Civil War veteran respectively. The CGI effects helped the story rather than hindering it or overshadowing it.All in all a great popcorn movie or rental that is suitable for family viewing with children over the age of reason. There are skimpy costumes for both men and women, but no nudity and the violence is cartoon violence rather than a gore fest. Fun!

reviewText: ... to make this above average action film one of the most colossal "bombs" in cinematic history.What the hell happened here?  The theater I was in was pretty full, the local reviewers were pleasantly indulgent towards it, it wasn't universally reviled or hated by everyone.  Why did it fail so catastrophically?What we have in the movie is basically the quintessential MIGHTY WHITEY action/adventure film, featuring a badass caucasian man placed in a foreign world and becoming the greatest warrior/leader/tap-dancer of them all and bringing peace to the realm.  Considering this story was written around 1917, when those sort of stories were still all the rage (Lord Jim, Robinson Crusoe, etc) there was really nothing they could rightly do, other than to make the helpless natives white too.Pretty much all the common clichès and tropes associated with films like Dances With Wolves, James Cameron Presents: Dances With Wolves 2: The Smurfs Edition in 3D, are in this film.  The way it's played straight by all the cast almost puts it beyond reproach; it's less like a tired rehashed story requiring almost no effort to write, and more like the honest, genuine efforts of a first-time writer or filmmaker.  Whether the filmmakers are doing their first movie or not is irrelevant.Simplistic as all the elements are, it's only fair to approach them simplistically, and for a simple story, characters and dialogue are surprisingly good, just on the very brink of being dumb, plodding, but avoiding it either by being sparse and plain, or by sheer earnestness.  Even John Carter stops being a boring little twit at some point in and fits more comfortably into his role (though a better actor would have done marvels).The aliens themselves are at their best when they're utterly unphased by any turn of events, as if what they said was absolutely right; they are not the cause of the disaster and horrors, but simply feeding upon the naturally occurring collapse of civilizations.In all, it's hardly consistent with a catastrophic Hollywood bomb, and certainly deserves more than the sort of money churned by even worse action films like Battleship.
summary: An ancient cabal of mysterious aliens conspiring...

reviewText: The subject of countless articles over its stratospheric budget and poor advertising campaign, Disney's JOHN CARTER is poised to generate new fans when the much-ballyhooed picture hits video. In fact, not only is director Andrew Stanton's fantasy a great deal of fun, but it's one central performance shy of being truly spectacular.Adapting Edgar Rice Borroughs' "A Princess of Mars" alongside writers Mark Andrews and Michael Chabon, Stanton - a Pixar animator here making his live-action directorial debut - does a fine job working familiar genre conventions into an exciting, occasionally enthralling, otherworldly adventure.John Carter (Taylor Kitsch) is a former Confederate soldier improbably whisked away to Mars, aka Barsoom, where a civil war rages between the kingdoms of Helium and Zodanga. Complicating matters further is a mysterious, and powerful, beam of energy that the lovely red Martian princess Deja Thoris (Lynn Collins) is close to unlocking the full potential of; in order to stop her, the evil Therns - puppetmasters of the planet - have decided to install one of their minions as King by having him marry Deja. It's up to Carter to stop them, and also navigate the alien wilds of a planet populated with odd creatures, including the insect-like, green Martian "Tharks," who ultimately aid our hero in his quest.Packed with smashing action sequences and likeable characters (as well as a plot that's perhaps a bit too convoluted for its own good), "John Carter" is one of those films that its studio, for whatever reason, simply didn't seem to understand. Marketed as an "edgy" type of genre vehicle (with anachronistic rock music used in its trailers), the picture is really an old-fashioned, classically constructed fantasy in the obvious vein of, among other influences, "Star Wars" (with a dash of "Dune" rearing itself, notably in an unused opening to the film where the Princess, staring into the camera, introduces her alien world to the viewer). There are faithful sidekicks (the delightful, canine-like "Woola"), unlikely allies (the Thark leader, voiced by Willem Dafoe, among them), a good amount of humor and impressive special effects to match.Perhaps Disney took a clue from the movie's central performance in their marketing - the picture's glaring weak point. Kitsch looks like he attended the "Christian Bale School of Batman Acting" here, delivering his lines in a hushed, monotone voice and offering not an ounce of charisma in a part that could've been a star-making performance for countless other young actors. Rarely ever cracking a smile, Kitsch's Carter is brooding to the point where you have a hard time understanding what the princess (a lovely performance from Collins) actually sees in him. It's an epic miscalculation that leaves the film with a black hole at its center, and leads one to also wonder why Disney has had such a hard time finding male leads to anchor its recent franchises (the similarly bland Garrett Hedlund was only slightly more effective in "Tron: Legacy").Despite Kitsch, "John Carter" is still an entertaining cinematic journey of the Saturday matinee variety, anchored by Michael Giacchino's most satisfying score to date and a particularly awesome use of 3-D.Although the film was converted to 3-D in post-production, the movie simply looks amazing in Disney's 3-D Blu-Ray package: depth of field effects are evident in nearly every scene, with crisp detail and almost no ghosting whatsoever that I noticed. The movie manages to maintain its bright visual pallet and come across as demo-worthy material, making the fact that it wasn't actually shot in 3-D a revelation.The package also includes a regular Blu-Ray, DVD and digital copy. Special features include a half-hour look behind the scenes, a brief profile of Borroughs' writing, a commentary with Stanton and fellow crew personnel, bloopers, an optional "Second Screen" interactive function, and a number of deleted scenes.I'm not sure "John Carter" is ever going to be looked at as a classic, but it certainly doesn't deserve the bad reputation it's been saddled with. Once viewers get a chance to actually see the film and not just base their views based on its negative publicity, it's likely to entertain sci-fi fantasy fans of all ages.
summary: Spectacular 3-D in a Movie Much Better than its Reputation Suggests

reviewText: This is a movie I was too curious about to let the critics keep me from giving it a chance on DVD. Boy, am I glad I did. The story is excellent, and follows the original Edgar Rice Burroughs books very well. It is a complicated story with lots of unusual vocabulary (Barsoom = Mars, etc.), but if critics had exercised half a brain cell, or if the Disney marketers had done their jobs, we might have had a box office titan on our hands rather than a movie being run down as a flop. Because the movie is good! It has the substance, style, and story of a great adventure tale; it's wonderfully realized in every detail; and the story keeps twisting and turning until the end, all very coherently.Critics have become very unreliable lately. There are few I trust, and too many scoring systems give stupid blog critic as much weight as reliable real critic. And then we get the dogpile effect of the lazy critics, who read other critics and don't think for themselves. This all added up to a critical problem for "John Carter," but an undeserved one. This is better storytelling than "The Amazing Spider-Man," and better effects, just for example.Do yourself a favor, read a little of the original books, then watch the movie. I think you'll be glad you did.
summary: Don't miss it, despite the poor marketing and dogpile of critics

reviewText: I never had any intention of watching this film, but my dad asked me to watch it with him the other night so I did. I absolutely loved it! I was pleasantly surprised! I liked the whole idea of the movie being told as a story that wasn't actually finished. I thought that was very clever and came together nicely at the end. This movie was a visual treat with excellent special effects, and the action was well-paced and entertaining. I also enjoyed the humorous bits, and the love story was a nice little tie-in. I was worried the love story might get tossed aside, but I'm so glad it didn't. The acting was superb and the story had heart. At no time during this movie did I feel like it was just something churned out to make money at the box office. It really seemed to be a labor of love. I am picky about my sci-fi flicks, and I am so glad I gave this one a chance. I'm ready to watch it again!
summary: Didn't want to see it but glad I did!

reviewText: I saw this movie in the theatres and it was wonderful there; as a Blu-Ray in 3D, the theatre experience is faithfully translated.  The 3D effects work very well on the small screen and enhance the story rather than distract or detract from it.  This is definitely one of the better 3D movies to get on Blu-Ray.As for the movie itself, the other reviews here do the movie justice--this is a good, nearly great, movie that should have done much better in the theatres and should have had better reviews.  The world of Barsoom (Mars) is completely and convincingly created and the storyline is interesting.  There's no time to be bored and from the very start, you find yourself cheering for John Carter to meet the Princess and fall in love with her.  The acting is good and the effects are not as cartoonish as the really underwhelming Avatar 3D.Definitely worth purchasing for the home collection-it may not be Citizen Kane, but this is a far better movie than Avatar, a Dances with Wolves ripoff often given high ratings and recommended for home purchase.  I hope that future 3D movies are at least as good as John Carter.

reviewText: I went into this film having never read the books, though I knew something about the world. I did for example know what a Thark was going in. And having seen it I have to pay this film the highest compliment I can give: I want to read the books. I fear that a sequel will never be made, and while the film doesn't end on a cliffhanger per se it does feel rather like the ending of the Fellowship of the Ring. And that is sad because of all the movies out there getting sequels at the moment I can think of no world I'd rather go back to than this one.The world is the main selling point of this film. Mars (or Barsoom) is an ancient world, dry and dying. It is filled with beautiful red deserts (which I feel could have been a little more red but still...) and strange peoples. The strangest are probably the Tharks: nine-foot tall green aliens with big tusks and anger issues. They are led by Tars Tarkas, an excellent Willem Dafoe who apparently acted out the part on stilts. The Tharks are what the Na'vi should have been. They may have some of the characteristics of the 'noble savage' but they are also violent and not particularly friendly to outsiders. In other words they have the capacity to be noble but they can also be a genuine threat.If I occasionally compare this film to Avatar or other films it is an unfortunate necessity. Many science fiction epics have stolen much from John Carter. This has led to many complaints of 'having seen it before' and 'it's ripping off other, better films.' Many of these critics don't realize that John Carter is the work that has been ripped off, not vice versa, and even for those who do it doesn't matter. They are film critics after all, not literary ones. The most obvious case of the movie 'ripping off' a 'better' movie is in the arena sequence. This looks exactly like the sequence from the end of Attack of the Clones. Even though it is done better and makes more sense here, I can't deny that it looks like a blatant rip off to those not in the know. But on the whole I was surprised how new and fresh it appears. The ships and costumes are amazing. They used an admirable amount of restraint in making them feel used and lived in. The motorbike-type ships offer the best example of this. The wings fold up and pop out only when in use. In every film I've seen for the last fifteen years the action of opening/closing the sails would be a big complicated affair to show off how cool the technology is. Here it simply pops open. It feels like a real piece of technology that one might use rather than a cheap gimmick. As to the costumes, they are uniformly excellent. They feel lived in, and if they are slightly campy they never go overboard.I'd call the story fairly basic, although there is much detail given along the way. There is an evil general called Sab Than who wants to take over Mars and so he wishes to marry princess Deja Thoris of his rival city. Pretty standard stuff, and he seems a thoughtless brute right out of Flash Gordon or some other adventure serial. Where things get interesting is in the people controlling him. For he is not the film's main villain, merely their puppet. The true villains of the piece are the Tharns, a race of immortals who can disguise their appearance at will and who feed off the destruction of worlds. They've given great power to Than since he seems most likely to achieve this end. He's a good choice too since he causes such a big commotion that people don't think to look beyond him for even darker motives. The really nice thing about the Tharns is that they aren't really brute force villains. They don't destroy the planets, they simply arrange for the inhabitants to do so. They are a quite genuine threat, and when they're done with Mars their next stop is Earth. I don't understand why that little fact has been left out of the trailers.It is through the Tharns that John Carter ends up on Mars. They have the ability to transport themselves between worlds and Carter ends up on Mars by accident after killing one. Here we get one of the film's few missteps. The scenes on Earth take up about twenty minutes and are not particularly engaging, despite Bryan Cranston as a Union officer trying to recruit Carter into the army for some undeveloped reason. Oh yeah, it's 1868 and John Carter is a Confederate veteran from Virginia. Kinda important to know that. Fortunately, once he gets to Mars there is rather more life in the film. John finds that he is insanely strong and has the ability to jump really high due to the lower gravity on Mars. Once there he ends up stuck in one bad situation after another as he acclimates himself to the world. Naturally it's not long before he runs into princess Deja who is fleeing her forced wedding.Character-wise Deja is the real standout. Many people have compared her to princess Leia, but while this comparison is not without merit she is very much her own character. She manages to come off as tough and noble without it feeling forced. I often find female action heroes to be lacking a certain credibility that the guys acquire more easily, yet in this case I found the girl more believable a fighter than the guy. Partly it comes down to the inconsistency of his superpoweredness, but there is also the fact that Taylor Kitsch just isn't a very good actor. He certainly doesn't ruin the film, but he doesn't particularly impress either. That's probably a good part of why the Earth scenes felt flat. They could have really used a better leading man in this role. Fortunately the supporting cast more than make up for it. As with most epic films of this sort the lead character is a somewhat blank slate simply to provide a focus of normality in the crazy world. I've mentioned most of the supporting cast already, but especial props must go out to Mark Strong and Willem Dafoe. Mark Strong is the lead Thern, and for a character who never emotes or acts even remotely menacing he manages to be quietly terrifying. But in some ways he has it easy since he is in an comparatively uncumbersome costume. Willem Dafoe was acting on stilts in the middle of the Arizona desert knowing all the while that he would be digitally replaced in post-production, yet his Tars truly feels like a living character. The other actors do their part well and while there is a fair amount of overacting there are no really bad performances here. Even Kitsch manages to be decent if unimpressive.The rest of the production is similarly first-rate. Effects, scripting, editing - all top class. The musical score is very nice, though they do tend to repeat just one theme instead of creating several. The action scenes have been criticized as sub-standard, but I don't see it. For me the key mark of a good action scene is that I actually care what happens in it. On that mark they certainly succeed. If they could have used more inventive plotting, well that's a fairly minor flaw. A more substantial problem which critics can't seem to get over is the nature of the world. People are flying around in airships powered by light, yet they're still fighting with swords. This is one of those things you can just either accept or not. I have no problem with suspending my disbelief, but I get that others can't. To which I simply have this to say: this movie isn't for you. This film is likely to have a fairly narrow audience, although I imagine it would be popular with the majority of kids. Those who can appreciate this kind of thing, and can ignore that it's set on Mars, are likely to find that it is amazingly good fun.I'm rather amazed that this film got made at all. it is not the sort of movie studio execs like to see. Aliens, a campy story (on Mars no less), and a rather eccentric group of characters, all with no big star. It's amazing it ever got funded. People seem uninterested in seeing it, which is very unfortunate as this is a film which deserves to succeed. I want to see more of the marvelous world of Barsoom and the further adventures of John Carter. But Disney seems uncertain of how to market this, as evidenced by the removal of the iconic "From Mars" from after John Carter's name. This is a film which you will either love or not. And there's nothing wrong with that. Some people love sushi, but I can't stand it. That doesn't mean that sushi is bad and everything I like good. The simplest way to figure out whether you will like this film is to ask yourself whether the idea of swordfights in airships and green aliens on Mars appeals to you. If it does then the odds are that you'll like this movie. If you're not sure, give it a shot. you may be surprised. But if that just sounds silly and ridiculous then avoid this movie. It is exactly what it appears to be: a scifi action-adventure with aliens, flying ships, and sword-fights.

reviewText: I read a ton of Edgar Rice Burrough's books years ago when I was in college, including his "Princess of Mars" series.  They are fun action-adventure, escapist reads.  They are not and do not claim to be great literature, but at the same time they have staying power.  I mean, who hasn't heard of Tarzan?  Anyway, his "Princess of Mars" series is lesser known, but equally fun and engaging.  They, like Tarzan, are great summertime reads!  I was therefore excited to see that Disney was releasing "John Carter" (which is based on the "Princess of Mars").  I don't remember seeing much hype about this movie before it came out in the theater, but I went to see it anyway, and I really, really liked it.OK, I readily admit that some of the special effects are little hokey, but all in all it's a really fun show!  There are all kinds of aliens, there's danger, intrigue, mystery, comic relief, loyalty, a hero, and even some romantic tension tossed in to flavor the mix.  And, if you are into steam punk at all, you'l like the effects.  They have a very strong steam punk flavor to them.The basic story line (without revealing anything major) is that John Carter, a Civil War hero, suffers great personal loss, so he flees to the western territories and sets out to find gold.  He is a person adrift.  He detaches himself from everyone and everything from his past.  He is a person of strong character, but has become disillusioned.  He then finds himself on Mars (you'll have to watch to see how that happens).  Mars is a smaller than Earth, and has less gravity, so John Carter, an Earthling, has great advantages when it comes to strength, speed, etc.  Once on Mars it's not long before he stumbles into the middle of a war and finds himself confronted with a decision about whether to commit himself or not.I found the characters, even the digitally animated ones to be realistic and engaging.  And, if you are like me, you will love Woola.  Woola is, according to John Carter, a "nice...monster dog".  You'll see.This movie is not dark like many sci-fi movies tend to be these days.  It's fun, hopeful, and a great romp.  You'll love the ending!I was going to award this movie 4 stars when I started writing my review, but as I went on I convinced myself that it's actually worth 5!As for an appropriate audience...um, I'd say that it's probably best for viewers over the age of 12.  My 13-yr old daughter and I watched it together, and we both liked it.  Then my college aged daughter and I watched it and she really liked it too.I hope this was useful!  I recommend that you give "John Carter" a try.
summary: Bomb at the box office, but a score at my house!

reviewText: I finally got around to seeing John Carter. When I first saw previews for the movie, its resemblance to Star Wars was uncanny. Then I found out the movie is based off a series of books by Edgar Rice Burroughs that came out in the early 1900's.So it turns out, Star Wars resembles the books which in turn causes John Carter the movie to resemble Star Wars. It's a whole chicken and egg thing.But anyway, I'll start right off with saying that if you have read the books, be prepared for some changes to the story. Personally, I found the changes, such as the look and role of the Therns, to be jolting. The problem with reading a book and seeing a movie is you expect the same thing. So when things are switched up, it becomes a little confusing as you try to unlearn what you already know.If you never read the books, I think this movie will be a lot more enjoyable. There is plenty of action, great characters, and a decent plot. Andrew Stanton does a great job transitioning his animated directing experience with Pixar into a live action/animated film with John Carter.And yes, as you watch it, you'll sometimes feel the uncanny similarities the movie has with Star Wars. What with words like Jeddak being thrown around and names of creatures like Banths, how could you not?My one gripe comes with the ending, but I think it has more to do with a lack of confidence in getting a chance to do a sequel to the movie. In the first book, it ends with a clear cliffhanger. The movie almost does the same thing, but in its final moments it resolves the potential cliffhanger and wraps everything up. Something tells me the higher ups at Disney requested this in the event the movie bombed.And, well, it did. So it was probably a good decision that they did that overall.At the end of the day, if you like good action, stories with princesses, and brave heroes, give John Carter a try. Sit back, have fun, and enjoy the ride!
summary: Star Wars, John Carter is your father!

reviewText: With some minor alterations, this could have been an incredible movie. As it stands, it was a lot better than its box office revenue would lead you to believe. First, lets talk about the good. The premise is actually pretty interesting. Without giving too much away for those who haven't seen the movie, lets just say the movie raises questions about the origins of humanity without directly addressing that question itself. Some things are better left to the imagination.Also, the notion that a human would have super-strength on Mars is reasonable even while the creators take that idea to the extreme. But considering its a movie, I can accept the leap in imagination. The storyline itself deals with environmental change and energy problems, which is obviously relevant to most Americans, and integrates these issues seamlessly into a somewhat muddled central plot that involves a superficial character evolution from damaged self-absorbed adventurer to savior of a Martian princess.While I criticized the movie for being superficial, I must confess my main issue with this movie is superficial in the extreme. The movie is about saving a princess I really didn't care for. In the American classic, A Place in the Sun, male viewers will find themselves empathizing with the male lead because he falls in love with an Elizabeth Taylor at the height of her beauty while being trapped in a mediocre life with a mediocre wife. This princess inspires no such feelings, and while she's definitely attractive, she's not somebody I would risk my neck for.In the end, it's an entertaining movie that is only mildly thought-provoking.

reviewText: I stayed riveted to this wonderful film of adventure, drama, and discovery for the whole two plus hours.  I can only hope that Prometheus is this well done.  I laughed as John Carter arrived through a worm hole in the 1870's or early 1880's and found himself in about 1/5 G Mars.  He bounced around and fell down, lost his balance and had to learn to walk all over again.  Then he stumbles upon the natives -- kind of Mar's version of Earth's native peoples.  They come with their adorable, but at first quite scary version of a bulldog and hippo.  It moves like lightning.  He soon amazes the natives with his prodigious jumping ability and becomes a clan member.  Well, the story keeps on moving from adventure to adventure and meetings with the ancient, earth like aliens.  Aha... they seem friendly... and I'll leave you at that.  This movie was full of evolving plot and remarkably lacking in bloody violence.  It was as big a positive surprise as I have ever seen and perhaps one of my favorite five movies of all time.  As a long-time science fiction fan and amateur astonomer, I can tell you it is destined to be a classic.  I hope there are follow-ups too. The plot line leaves lots of questions open and possibilities for youngish John Carter and his career, rule, and progeny.  One last little surprise.  The Martian version of a dog has a long way to go too.  Every really good film needs a surprising and wonderful animal like that to steal the show a little at times and add some humorous relief.  That's what I really loved about this film so much.  It didn't take itself so seriously that it ended up as a massive failure like the movie Dune.  Star Wars too had this same type of sense of adventure and comic relief at times.  If you loved Star Wars, you'll love this too.
summary: John Carter wonderful --- Critics seemed not to have seen it

reviewText: In reviewing a movie with an original storyline, there is a lower standard, as it doesn't have to be compared to anything. "John Carter of Mars" is based on a series of books by Edgar Rice Burroughs (even more famous as the author of the 20+ Tarzan books) written starting about 100 years ago - from 1912 into about the 1940s. So there are (presumably) millions of fans of that series who have read it for decades. They are the core of the target fan base for this movie, and the first question is "How does this movie stand up against the experience of reading the books?"I first read (part) of the Mars series about 45 years ago. I tried it again about 20 years ago, and just recently read the first five books again. Edgar Rice Burroughs did not write with the intention of creating great literature. In fact he started writing after some other business ventures had fallen apart. Reading some pulp novels of the day, he literally thought "I can write better trash than this trash"! LOL It turned out he was correct. His books were exciting. His ideas were fresh. He was possibly the first very successful author to use a lot of "world building", although his writing came just after the publication of the early Oz books, which were also quite successful in that regard.However, Burroughs books were also very formulaic. Original readers who got them a year or two apart probably didn't notice it as much, but if you sit down today and try to read the Mars books one after another, you'll quickly notice that you are essentially reading the same story over and over again, just with changes in characters and other window dressing. It can be important to remember that Burroughs wrote to earn a living, not to create art. So would he have approved of this movie? If it entertained customers and put some bucks in his pocket, he absolutely would have!The "John Carter of Mars" movie does not closely follow the plot of any of the Mars books. However, what movie does? Even the very well received "Lord of the Rings" movie trilogy at times took incredible liberties with the plot of Tolkein's books. Did that make them less spectacular or enjoyable? No. The same is true with this movie. What it gave me as a 45 year fan of the series were substantial dollops of the creatures, races, landscapes, technologies, and familiar plot elements. The hordes of Tharks were particularly spectacular. They came across as "real people", just as the aliens in Avatar did. The CGI is detailed and seamless. We had familiar plot elements such as Carter and Dejah Thoris being captured by Tharks, and Carter defeating a Thark and taking his place in their society. The airships of the red race were present, and were as impressive as they were beautiful. Burroughs had an arena scene in the books, and so did the movie. Burroughs had wars ... so did the movie. There were enough similarities that I could feel the sense of Burroughs' plots, if not the details. Since that is about the best you can hope for with a screenplay adapted from novels, I give them good marks in this area. Plot elements from the all of the first three Mars books are included in this movie.Now, what about the plot we actually got in the movie? I liked it. We had two reprehensible sets of bad guys. Carter is given greater depth of character in that he is a reluctant hero. He really just wants to be left alone to pursue his own goals, and over the course of the movie has to be dragged and cajoled into becoming the hero. (This is a departure from Burroughs' character). I like what was done with the Therns. They play a similar role in society to that depicted by Burroughs, but are made into that plus something more in the movie.The movie nails the Thark society. The hordes of barbaric, four armed giants are depicted stunningly as individuals, and as a society in a manner extremely true to the Burroughs vision in his novels. The action sequence where Carter fights a rival horde virtually single handed is right out of the books and is spectacularly rendered in the film. I give the movie an A+ in its depiction of this critical element of transition from book to film.Overall, the filmmakers did a truly impressive job of depicting Martian landscapes, cities, ruins, creatures, and races. In the books, Martian races went around naked, wearing only harnesses needed to hold weapons and other mobile possessions. Not wanting an R rating, Disney DID have to put some clothes on these folks, and they did. LOLI enjoyed this movie in the theater, and I was not disappointed by this Blu ray presentation. I'd been wanting to upgrade to a 3D TV for some time, and had been watching the prices on a certain model for many weeks. The TV finally hit a price I liked, so I used the excuse of the release of this film in 3D, along with the Avengers and the new Avatar 3D, to pull the trigger on that purchase.This movie is a stunning visual achievement in home theater 3D Blu ray. Every element of the film is crisp and detailed. The 3D effects are not "in your face", but they certainly add to the viewing experience. Virtually this entire film is CGI, but every object is so detailed that you are completely immersed in the fantasy of this film's environment. The large flying ships are simply gorgeous. The landscapes are detailed and do nothing to break the illusion that you are seeing action on another planet.It seems to me that all of these major Blu ray releases get the sound right ... I have yet to find complaint with one ... and this is no exception. The dialogue is well balanced. It is not overwhelmed at any time by the volume level of the music or the effects. I do have a quibble with the score, but not one that is unique to this film. It seems that a LOT of action spectaculars in recent years have rather pedestrian scores. There are no major themes in this score to latch on to so that when you hear it again, you'd say, "That's John Carter!". The same was true, I thought, of the X-Men films. Think back to the days of the big John Williams scores for Star Wars or Superman or Indiana Jones. When those play, they are identifiable. Earlier films like "The Magnificent Seven" or "The Big Country" ... identifiable. Later films like the 1989 Batman ... identifiable. This score sounds great, but there is no stand out strain to make it uniquely memorable.Obviously I'm a fan of this movie. I just regret that it didn't get the box office pull needed to turn this into a series. The creators did a remarkable job with it. Visually, it is easily in the top few CGI efforts ever, to this date. The story is captivating. The acting is solid.Highly recommended.

reviewText: Well I just got home from seeing the movie.  I must admit that I never had the pleasure of reading the books, but a friend had praised them to me and got me really hyped for this movie.  The premise seemed fascinating and inspired.  Knowing that the books were written so long ago, was also very impressive to me.  I was ready to be taken on anawesome adventure.The movie was moderate fun, but really nothing special.  I didn't pull my heart strings.  I wasn't wowed by the visuals.  I don't know how much this is owed to the written source material or the Hollywood determination to change things, but the world of Mars just didn't look all that special.  I didn't even have much of a red tint to it for goodness sake.  I thought vehicles and architecture were somewhat bland and looked like they had been pulled from the inspiration of the crappy look of the Star Wars prequels.The acting was decent and the human cast was easy on the eyes, especially the princess of mars.  I don't go into movies expecting the world, but this fell short of what I had allowed myself to expect.For most people I would tell you to wait and rent this one or catch it at your "discount" movie theater when it's at the end of it's run.  I think people who have an intense love for the source material can make themselves like this movie a little more than the rest of us, or they can mourn over whatever changes were present.  My friend that is in love with the books seemed very pleased with the movie, while the rest of our 12 person group found it just "ok"
summary: It just didn't leave me with any special feelings.

reviewText: I think the reason that a lot of people did not like this is because they kept saying I've that before. been there done that, probably because they don't understand that the John Carter of mars books were written in the 1930's and every other science fiction story or movie owes everything to this story.  Without Edger Rice Burroughs the world of Science Fiction would not exists as we know it today.  He was the first to really take us to another world in a way that was unique.  I have read all the Mars book and also his Venus books and, of course, Tarzan books.  He was a pioneer of science fiction and adventure stories.  Do you know that here in California in the area known as the San Fernando Valley there is a city named Tarzana?  That is not coincidence.  His family estate is located there and it is where he wrote all of those wonderful stories.  The Tarzana Post Office has a glass case dedicated to him and has lots of rare thing inside pertaining to the man and his stories.  I thought the movie was great and did a credible job of paying tribute to an amazing man and his wonderful stories.  I wish they would make more.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Did anybody actually know anything about this movie after it was released? All I knew was that it cost $250 million to produce and had grossed $73 million by June of 2012 indicating that the Disney company had a real bow-wow on their hands. Did anybody know that it was a science fiction fantasy? That it was based on a story written by the same guy who invented Tarzan? I don't think so.But I did see a number of favorable reviews in Amazon and the price was right so I took a shot and ordered the Blu-ray. What kind of a title is that? Who knows from "John Carter"? Michael Clayton, OK, same thing except that people knew George Clooney starred in it and that was enough. Even that one cost $25 million and grossed a little over $50 million so it just cut it. And "Michael Clayton" is a damned good picture in my book."John Carter" is a grand adventure in the old science fiction/fantasy tradition -- what we referred to as "space opera" years ago. The story by Edgar Rice Burroughs is only one of a series of stories with this character. At the beginning, John Carter is a deserter from the Confederate Army who is captured by Union soldiers. He makes an escape, hides in a cave and sees strange markings and a medallion in the hand of a dying man. He is holding the medallion as he repeats a word being muttered by the man: "Barsoom." He is immediately transported to the planet Mars, the name of which is "Barsoom" to the Martians. The story takes off from there. The visual effects are state of the art, although the story is a bit muddled and unclear as to who is fighting whom.  The quality of acting is on a level superior to at least two of the Star Wars films (episodes 1 and 2)  It is grand entertainment in the old space opera tradition. A friend of mine who knew about the Burroughs story used to joke that when he retired he would move to Mars and open a saloon there called the Barsoom Bar Room.I did enjoy the movie which is visually quite impressive. It is interesting that the title given at the beginning is simply "John Carter." At the end, at the start of the credit roll, the title is given as "John Carter of Mars." That was the original title but, for some reason, "of Mars." was dropped. Whether the original title would have helped sell the picture, well, as they say in the business, that's blood under the bridge. Apparently there were plans for a series of movies based on the John Carter stories. I think we can forget about that.
summary: Grand Space Opera Adventure That Didn't Sell
Title: N/A

reviewerName: Bryan Byrd "reviewer of bad films and good books"
reviewText: Disclaimer: This review is from the theatrical release.  As such, I cannot comment on the as yet unreleased DVD.  My review concerns the entertainment value of the film only.As a Burroughphile from way back, I suppose I should breathe a sigh of relief that JOHN CARTER isn't a disaster.  Despite the liberties taken with the basic storyline, there are still enough essential details remaining to say that the film at least tries to adhere to ERB's classic novel.  I believe they even get more right than wrong.  But I also think I'm on solid ground when I say that many fans of the original will feel as I did - JOHN CARTER is entertaining in its own right, but the magic ofA Princess of Marsnever made the jump to the big screen.Of course, that's the old fogey speaking, who fooled himself for a moment that he could go back to being ten years old for a few minutes (and judging from my fellow-movie-goers that Saturday morning, I wasn't the only one).  But as far as my eleven-year-old son was concerned, it was a great day at the movies.  And why not - JOHN CARTER is quite the spectacle.  An Earthman, mysteriously transported to Mars, who first falls in with a race of four-armed savage Green-men, and then lands smack dab in the middle of a civil war between a distinctly humanoid race of Red-men.  And a princess - there's always a princess in a Burroughs story - and I have to say that this princess, as portrayed by Lynn Collins, ebodies all the charm and beauty I've always associated with Dejah Thoris.  The rest of the screenplay does, at times, become overly complex, but in its esssentials...well, you've probably seen it played out a thousand times before - if Burroughs didn't invent it, he certainly brought it into the twentieth century.This twenty-first century version is a bit loaded, I think, with some social ideas that don't really belong here, but much of that I'll leave up to the individual viewer to determine because your assessment of that will likely depend on your viewpoints prior to seeing the film.  They are minor, and the ideas of the bad guys who are only interested in plundering the planet's resources as well as the anti-war sentiment may be worthwhile - but they were inserted by someone other than Burroughs, and in my opinion, unecessary in order to tell an adventure tale.There will - and should be - a positive reaction to this film.  Those who are drawn to Action/Adventure/Science Fantasy epics will enjoy it and I also think my fellow Burroughphiles will grudgingly give it a thumbs up too.  But I can't say that it's inspiring the same way that I felt about the book those many years ago, nor can I really see it inspiring anyone else.  Considering I thought the book was near-mystical experience at the time, it's not surprising I'd have high demands from the film.  Best to put those in your pocket, if you feel the same, and go see it with a youngster and watch it through their eyes.  That's as close as we'll ever get to being ten again - and really, that's not too bad.
summary: 3 1/2 Stars - Entertaining...yes, but sadly no classic

reviewText: This is a review of the movie as it stands on its own. I have not read the book and I am not familiar with anything that happened prior to watching this 2 hour and 13 minute long movie. I watched the Instant Video (streaming), so I can't comment on the contents of the DVD/BluRay and their special features.The movie had a lot of action and special effects, which often increases the entertainment value. This part I have no problems with.However, there were problems with the characters. The lead actor was very weak for an epic movie of this caliber. He was barely two dimensional, and not very convincing. The post-production team tried hard to give him some depth with the flashbacks filling in his back-story, but the lead actor was just unconvincing.The lead actress was not as bad as the lead actor, but still, it was an average performance at best. The rest of the human characters were either undeveloped or too one dimensional. The CGI characters were actually acting better than the humans and that's not something you want said about your blockbuster movie.Speaking of the CGI characters, I couldn't help but get Avatar vibes, and steampunk bandwagoneering. Not that this is necessarily a bad thing - that's how Hollywood works after all.Speaking of Hollywood, another issue I have with this, and many other movies: it is easy to see patterns of where things are heading. In recent memory, the only exception I can recall wasDistrict 9 [Blu-ray] where they danced upon movie plot cliches and swerved in completely different directions.Overall, I would recommend someone to watch this movie. It's not bad, but it's not great.
summary: Lots of action, weak lead actor, not much depth in human characters

reviewText: When I saw the trailers for John Carter of Mars in the theater, it looked like another mindless summer CG action movie. Aren't trailers supposed to make you want to go see a movie? It seemed like a bad mashup ofCowboys & Aliens, Star Wars Phantom Menace andOddworld. It wasn't helped by the pounding orchestral version of Kashmir. Led Zeppelin songs are becoming somewhat of a movie trailer cliche now (used recently in The Girl with the Dragoon Tattoo remake, Sucker Punch). After watching it at home though, boy, am I glad to be wrong. This is a really fun movie and I gladly recommend it to action/sci-fi fans!Helmed by Pixar's Andrew Stanton who directed Wall-E, Finding Nemo, Bug's Life, and wrote all 4 Toy Story films, those are some impressive credentials. This is a period piece, set in the late 1800's and based on the work of Edgar Rice Burroughs (whose other creation is Tarzan). This is old-skool sci-fi/fantasy (think Jules Vernes and H.G. Wells) and the film has a very steampunk/vintage look to it to match, down to the color saturation in some scenes and film grain. The similarities to Cowboys and Aliens and Star Wars are not accidental. Jon Favreau was supposed to direct this film. There's a lot of CG in here. Much of the art design looks like Star Wars, especially the ships, because Peter Chiang headed up the art department on both. Filmed in the American southwest, there are lots of beautiful shots of canyons and geological formations. Mark Strong is always good as a bald bad guy.I won't give away too much of the story. John Carter, a man with a broken past, is a reluctant hero thrust into the role of savior of Mars (or Barsoom, in the story). A Civil War veteran and already a skilled fighter, his abilities are greatly magnified on Barsoom due to the difference in gravity, allowing him to leap long distances and fight with superhuman strength. Along the way, he meets a beautiful British-accented princess (played by the gorgeous Lynn Collins who's actually American) and befriends a race of green Martians.Aside from the obvious violence, there's not too much for parents to worry about. (It's a Disney movie after all). It's gunfights and swordplay. There's even a cute dog-monster thing. Worth watching and I'm definitely going to watch it again. It's not a thinking man's movie. Just enjoy it for the action, taut visual design, and story. I hope the DVD sales do well because I'd love to see another film made from these novels.
summary: John Carter didn't get a fair shake at the box office -- Give it a chance on Blu-ray

reviewText: This is one of the most enjoyable sci-fi movie I've seen so far with a fun storyline and great visual effects, one that sci-fi fans and children would enjoy watching. There aren't any background info on set designs, alien designs, costume designs or CGI development stage. Maybe it's shown on Disney's Second Screen but I haven't had the chance to load it yet. The Deleted Scenes were not complete and are quite "rough"; with visible green screen, "rough" CGI rendering and sketches even...unlike the Deleted Scenes shown on the Star Wars prequels.Lastly my advice to you guys is to keep in mind that the original story was written in 1912 so keep your mind open...don't try to complicate things by thinking that the storyline is ridiculous or it's illogical coz human beings can't breathe on Mars or it's foolish coz there aren't any aliens living on Mars. Just sit back and enjoy this movie...after all, it's a Science Fiction movie...

reviewText: I loved reading Edgar Rice Burroughs when I was younger and especially loved two of his series - Tarzan and the Barsoom series.  These books transported me to faraway places that I would never see and I imagined myself as Jane or the princess of Mars or other characters in his MANY books.  I am an avid reader and luckily Burroughs was a prolific writer.  His books allowed me the ultimate escapism onto exotic worlds."John Carter," the movie, is an amalgamation of his Barsoom series (Barsoom Series Complete Collection, especiallyA Princess of Mars.Taylor Kitsch is perfect for the lead role, playing handsome but a little goofy, and Lynn Collins as Dejah Thoris, princess of Mars is a beautiful, strong womanoid.Best of all, though, were the special effects.  Three separate intelligent species on Mars plus the animal/monster life plus the steampunk feel of their transportation made for a hugely enjoyable movie for me.  It brought back so many memories of summer afternoons under the cottonwood trees on my grandparent's farm, reading all of Burrough's adventures, and creating my own mind pictures of how I imagined Mars (Jasoom) to look.  Great fun!

reviewText: This was awesome.  Some parts could've been better, but all in all, I'd put it in the top hundred action/adventure films of all time.  The terrible shame is that because this did so poorly at the box office there won't be any more of them.  That said, I'd suggest not going into this with any major expectations--it's not Star Wars or Raiders of the Lost Ark--but it is a fun ride.  Should've been called "Princess of Mars" though (like the book).  "John Carter" is a terrible title.As can be seen from the majority of reviews, most people really liked this film.  But as others have noted, there were some big flaws in its marketing.  Disney is developing a knack for screwing their own films.  They've come out with several films in the last decade that should've done better--deserved better--than the response they got.  I've worked with Disney in the past, and anyone who has had to work with them can tell you: they have their own way doing things.  I worked for a company that did closed-captioning for Disney, and they were the biggest pain in the neck.  Despite knowing nothing about this kind of work, they insisted everything should be done a certain way simply because the guy in charge of that department had his own opinions, which as it turned out were based on one conversation he had with a deaf friend of his wife's.  Forget all the research and testing my company had done; because his wife's friend liked such-and-such, every Disney film would be captioned that way.  I suspect this kind of thing permeates the Disney way of doing business.  I can just imagine that the person who deals with marketing heard something his daughter once said, and therefore, the multi-million dollar marketing campaign gets designed by a ten year old.  Well, whatever the case, they need to reassess their methods, because there are a few franchises that never got off the ground due to their own mishandling.  And unfortunately, the creators of these films lose out, the companies involved lose out, and we the audience never get to see what could've been a great series of films.

reviewText: "John Carter" is largely based on stories published in 1912, ultimately released in a novel called "A Princess of Mars". Consequently, there has been much discussion that James Cameron's ultra-popular film "Avatar" was also inspired by the same stories. While there are similar themes, "John Carter" seems to be a much more fateful representation and "Avatar" took many liberties and creative reroutes.John Carter is an American Civil War confederate army captain that is, through a course of events, transported to a strange planet called Barsoom. He later learns that Barsoom would be what we on Earth would call, Mars. He is gifted with leaping abilities that it seems nobody on Barsoom has. Because of this, he finds himself involved in a complex and long raging war for the future of the planet.While "John Carter" is gifted with great visuals and a complex storyline, it is also heavy-handed in the drama and complexities. Much of the film is taken up explaining the intricate connection between Earth and Mars and then the intricate factions of the people who are involved in the battle and why. The movie gets bogged down with a little bit too much explanation and over dramatization from the characters. The movie tried to have fun from time to time, as if it knew it was giving the audience a heavy-handed movie, but it wasn't enough.Ultimately, "John Carter" is being dubbed the first blockbuster of the year and that could be the case, but once the other blockbusters start rolling out, it will be quickly forgotten. The action scenes and events in the movie are fleeting. The humor and joy seems to be an after thought to the intricacies of the storyline. The storyline is a good one and I enjoyed the thought that went into how everything worked. I also enjoyed how the creators spent some time getting us involved in the characters, but they may have overshot in their efforts, and because of that, the movie lacks the fun it needed to truly make it memorable.
