reviewText: When a company known for creating franchising opportunities fails to create a toy line for a family-oriented action film, you know something's not right. Not being an insider, I don't know what was going on at Disney, but I do know someone decided this film should be a box-office fail.No toy line? Even "Avatar" had a toy line, and it wasn't a kids' flick.This movie had so much to offer, but it was set up to fail. Then the hyenas piled on, whooping and jeering about how they wouldn't ever have to hear about this movie again. You know the ones-- hipsters who LIVE online, to whom the "sword and planet" genre is unconscionable, who don't like anything unless there's an app for it. To understand what I'm talking about, all you have to do is visit the message boards over at IMDB.It is a good movie. I saw it twice in theaters-- once by myself, and once with my 7-year-old boy. He loved it. I mean LOVED it. Are you listening, Disney? I'm talking about your target demographic, here. He walked out of the theater explaining why certain things happened at the end of the movie so they could have a sequel. He wants a Thark. He wants all the toys.Oh wait, yeah. There ARE no toys. NO TOYS, for a $250 million DISNEY film? What's up with that? There aren't even t-shirts. And now Disney is short one executive, and I can't help wondering if the forced-fail of John Carter in the marketplace wasn't an inside maneuver...Oh well. I apologize for my conspiracy theory. I can say of the movie itself that, in the theater the CGI was so seamless you probably won't realize how much of what you are watching came out of a computer. If you're even remotely of the "steam punk" bent, you owe it to yourself to see "John Carter".If you like science fiction that is expansive and enveloping, you owe it to yourself to see "John Carter". And if you were a fan of the books, I can't imagine why you would stay away. "John Carter" defied the odds and made it to the big screen after 70 years of development hell. Respect that, if nothing else.When it comes out on Blu-ray, it's coming to my house, where my son and I can watch it again.

reviewText: This is my favorite Taylor Kitsch movie.  I would put it ahead of "The Covenant".  And certainly ahead of "Battleship".  Here he plays the role of John Carter, a character created by Edgar Rice Burroughs.  Although the original novel was written one hundred years ago, Disney has done a wonderful job in adapting the story and the sets to have modern appeal.John Carter is a veteran of the US Civil War.  While prospecting for gold, he takes refuge inside a cave and finds himself transported to Barsoom (Mars).  Because Mars has a lower gravitational pull than Earth,  John Carter is able to use his superior physical strength to jump higher and run faster than the natives.  While in Barsoom, he gets caught up in the power struggle between two powerful factions.  Using his physical abilities, he ends up saving the city of Helium and winning the affections of Princess Dejah.  They end up marrying.  Eventually, he ends up mastering the ability to travel between Earth and Mars.  During his visits to Earth, he relates his adventures to Edgar, his nephew.Once again, I do not want to spoil the story for you.  Suffice it to say that this is a well-made movie.  The special effects are up to the high standards you would expect from a high-budget Disney movie.  The acting performances are what you would expect from an all-star cast.  Taylor Kitsch is a rising star and this is an example of what he can do when given good material.  HBO veterans Ciaran Hinds, James Purefoy, and Polly Walker find themselves together again, after working together several years ago on the set of "Rome".  Dominic West and Mark Strong play the antagonists.  And the lovely Lynn Collins rounds out the cast as Princess Dejah.This is a thoroughly enjoyable movie.  And because it is a Disney movie, you can let your young children enjoy it with you.  See, you can make an action-packed, entertaining movie without making it unsuitable for children.  Highly recommended.

reviewText: Neat story, beautiful girl, exotic surrounding evil immortals with bad habits what's not to like.  I enjoyed it so much that I read the Edgar Rice Boroughs source material.  This suffers because you've seen a lot the effects elsewhere.  I think that it might be more fun to read the books (there are five stories - short pulp fiction - $.99 for all five on your Kindle ) then see the movie.  The Martian Princess, Deja Thoris (Lynn Collins) is quite striking with dazzling blue(violet?) eyes in a red and tatto'd face probably all done with the computer but still a sweet heart and not a shrinking violet with a sword in her own right.  John (Taylor Kitsch) I think is a pretty good leading man although between this and Battleship he's probably selling burgers and fry's on Hollywood Blvd.  If Kitsch is a stage name it's a poor pick (Means junk in German)

reviewText: The creatures, topography & acting were great. The story had so little to do with the book A Princess of Mars, I was stunned. I was also unpleasantly surprised by the rip-off of the Return of the Jedi chase scene with the flyer. If you know nothing remotely about the character of the lead roles or the storyline then this could be rated a good show but they assassinated the characters as portrayed in the book.My wife said to me, "Well if you just remove Edgar Rice Burroughs from the movie & the movie people had come up with this on their own wouldn't you think this was good." My reply was of course, "you mean if Edgar had never lived & they came up with the creatures, topography, alien races & the leads had no characteristics to go with them so they could write any story they wanted & assign characteristics to the roles as they see fit? It seems like that is killing Burroughs all over again & if you're going to do that then you can't advertise that it's based on a Burroughs's book or refer to A Princess of Mars at all. You've removed their hoped for initial fan base too." I'm sick of Hollywood using classic literature as a front to draw in people & writing a story that has little or nothing to do with the source material.The show should do well with those that haven't read the books, don't know the characters as written by Burroughs & really just want effects & a wow factor. Fans of Burroughs will be turned off by this travesty of an interpretation of A Princess of Mars. I can't recommend it to Burroughs fans, myself included.Still the acting is great, the creatures looked exactly as described in the book & the topography was too. Why they assassinated the leads characters was totally baffling except for writer or director ego. They thought they could do better & they are always wrong. Burroughs created everything good about this movie & he didn't create the flawed storyline. They particularly did a hatchet job on the Red Men of Mars & Tardos Mors & Tars Tarkus. 2 Amazon stars for me but maybe 4 stars for those that don't know anything about the book.
summary: What might have been but isn't
Title: N/A

reviewText: I was not aware of the John Carter stories until recently. They predate fictions like Lord of the Rings, Dune, Star Wars, Star Trek, Alien, Avatar, Stargate, etc. All of these stories have taken something from the John Carter series or have been inspired by it. Those who say that John Carter is "derivative" or a "rip-off" simply do not realize how ignorant that statement actually is.Despite my middling expectations, I was actually pleasantly surprised by the film. The polarizing reviews are reminiscent of the original reviews of "2001: A Space Odyssey", "Alien", "Bladerunner", and "Stargate". These have all gone on to be classics, or cult classics at the very least.This film is beautifully shot, and reminds me of some of the older epics like Ben Hur and The Ten Commandments. The sense of grandeur in some of these scenes is amazing, and begs to be seen on a large screen. The music is also incredibly beautiful. Technically and aesthetically, the film is outstanding.There is no acting that is distracting (for good or bad). In other words, no one's performance will make you say "Oh, he's good!", or "Oh, this acting is terrible". The acting and characters are intrinsically tied in with the story, and are never unbelievable (if you can suspend your disbelief for the sake of a good science fiction).And that's the point. If you're a fan of science fiction and fantasy, you'll most likely love this film. If you don't, then you should probably stick to your modern dramas, romantic comedies, documentaries, or reality TV.I highly recommend this film. It was epic, sweeping, touching, and dramatic. I hope you enjoy it.
summary: A Wonderul, Epic Science Fiction Film

reviewText: I wonder if the scriptwriters bothered reading the novels or just got pieces of ideas here and there. The beginning is totally wrong and many other scenes are invented rather than taken from the novels which, a bit dated, are still fun reads and highly recommended. The movie succeeds best on its CGI elements. The acting is ok nothing extraordinary (ie, typical of the vast majority of today's films) but I must say that Lynn Collins is hardly "incomparable" (as she's continually described in the novels) as Dejah Thoris. The role could have been better cast. This is one to rent (especially once you've read the novels) and watch once as I doubt you'll care to see it again.

reviewText: I missed out on the theatrical experience with this film, and I really hate I missed it.  On the big screen this movie would have been even better than the BR version.  And the BluRay version was spectacular, clean crisp visual unlike I've seen on other BR movies.  I vaugely knew what to expect before seeing the movie.  But with a 7 year old little girl who acts like the Disney Channel some type of addictive drug(no kidding, we also think it's affecting her personality for the worse), we've seen commercials, trailers, behind the scenes, parts of the movie and everything else thrown at us from the Disney Channel about this movie over the past 7-8 months.  If you don't watch the Disney Channel, you missed where the core marketing's focus audience is/was.  It was a great movie.  I am a big fan of everything SciFi, and this movie was great in it's own right.  I'll admit many plots points or some visuals seemed somewhat "seen that before" feel to it, but that's the point right?  The original writer's imagination from 1917 helped expand the sci fi imagination of others for a domino effect for us to enjoy so many other space operas, wars and epic battles are now classic in their own right.  We rented the BluRay of this, but I'm gonig to have to buy this one.  It's a keeper.  My wife enjoyed it. my kids enjoyed. I enjoyed it.  A good 'clean' space adventure romp to Mars and back we'll want to experience again and again.  Though with the Goddess, and few details reminded me just a little of Dave Duncan's "The Seventh Swordman" trilogy, but then again... that book didn't come first.  And if you haven't read the book (like I have not yet), it will get you interested and want to read the book (The "Princess of Mars" novel of course)!  Very underrated movie, that should have at least broke even with it's huge budget but grossing in at $179 million isn't bad either, just the budget was so... much higher than that.  Yes, Virginia... there is a Mars.  (Somebody had to do it...)

reviewText: John Carter will more than likely be the first big flop of 2012. With its $250 million budget, the 79 years it spent stuck in development hell, and one of the worst marketing campaigns since Grindhouse, John Carter certainly has its work cut out for it. While the blockbuster film may not be quite as bad as some expect it to be, it will more than likely rub audiences the wrong way and hurt its chances at the box office.John Carter is a lot like Star Wars: Episode II - Attack of the Clones in the way that its special effects are really outstanding, but everything else is kind of boring. Every inch of dialogue feels like it goes on forever and seems very drawn out. Short responses and one-liners are kept to a minimum. Everyone has a story to tell, a device to build, a scientific method to explain, a home to get back to, a war to prevent, or a marriage to run away from. It just winds up feeling a bit too over explanatory at times and about forty five minutes too long.Even though the majority of John Carter takes place on Mars, it almost doesn't really seem to matter. There are three or four really outstanding action sequences, but it's like the drama between characters is more important than this fantastic new world John finds himself in or the otherworldly technology he now finds at his fingertips. "There's a battle going on right over there! We should probably jump in, right?" "Probably, but let me tell you the history of my people first, why I don't trust you, and why I think you're crazy for saying you're from Earth." It has the same issue that last year's The Adventures of Tintin did in the way that when the action hits it's memorable, exciting, and exactly the type of thing you like to pay to see but everything in the middle continues to drag. Some sort of understanding of this new world is required, but this felt like a little much.What the action film is able to get done right is done in the best of ways. John Carter is pure ecstasy to look at. Mars is in a word; breathtaking. That structure John, Dejah Thoris, and Sola run into out on the water before John and Dejah go inside and discover the ninth ray is just an amazing sequence overall that practically parallels the first visit to Pandora in Avatar. There's the battle sequence where John takes on an entire army on his own while we're shown the memory of his previous family and of course the coliseum scene with the two white apes. These three sequences are reason alone to see this extremely expensive dose of eye candy.The cast is just really astounding, as well. Taylor Kitsch proves he's able to handle the leading man role with ease even if he does seem to be doing it with Christian Bale's Batman voice and you can't really go wrong with Willem Dafoe, Thomas Haden Church, Mark Strong, James Purefoy, and Bryan Cranston in your supporting cast.It's not that John Carter is a bad film. In fact, it's a lot better than you're probably expecting. It even has shades of some of the biggest action and adventure films of all time. Aside from Star Wars and Avatar, I found myself recollecting Raiders of the Lost Ark and even The NeverEnding Story. There is greatness at its core, but there is a lot of weakness to get through to actually reach that destination. Its 132 minute duration is exhausting, the pacing is extremely slow at times, and the film seems pretty dull and boring during its slower moments. I'm pretty sure every child was crying at some point that came to the theater that night. Despite being visually stunning and featuring some spectacular special effects, John Carter is structurally boring the majority of the time. Long before I had the chance to see this, I had guessed it would be the Green Lantern of 2012 and that's a pretty accurate comment to describe this film. I'm sure Mark Strong could vouch for that.

reviewText: As a youngster I read every Edgar Rice Burroughs book I could find and I am fairly certain I read them all - John Carter of Mars is one of the book series he authored, along with other series including: John Carson of Venus, Pellucidar & Tarzan being amoung the better known.Disney did a good job adhering to the book which opens the series and believe me, given the book content it was no easy task to pack in every nuance of the 1st book in the series into a single movie, but to those who never read the book series it leaves a great deal unexplained.  To Edgar's avid readers it was simply a joy to see the characters come to life on the screen.3D was not necessary for the story and didn't really do it for me.  The CGI was excellent and true to the various creatures as described in the novels, especially Woolla.  No slight to the actress playing Dejah but the book series often referred to her as the most beautiful woman on 2 planets with wars being fought over her - and, very scantily clad (translated, lol,  just about naked), not how I would describe the movie Dejah Thoris Princess of Helium - the actor playing John Carter was quite good.In a nutshell the story is about an American former confederrate officer and educated gentleman from Virginia who after the ravages of the civil war seeks his fortune in the wild west looking for gold.  A former professional soldier with a great aptitude, talent and experience at fighting (as well as liking a good fight) -is pursued by Indiams and hides in a cave which the Indians will not enter due to mystical properties therein and he awakes to find himself mysteriously transported to Mars, called Barsoom by the natives (while his corporeal body remains on earth hidden in the cave no less).  He finds that the lesser gravity of Mars coupled with his personal fighting skills make him a force to be reckoned with amoung the various warlike species on intelligent life on Barsoom (Mars).  He quickly learns the languages of Barsoom.He is constantly encountering hostile intellegent creatures, kicking butt and displaying his greater strength etc. but as a man of honor and a southern gentleman he wins over many a former foe and wins the heart of the most beautiful woman on 2 planets the Princess of Helium (one of the many warring kingdoms of Barsoom).Bottom-line I enjoyed the movie and will purchase the dvd when it comes out - I gave it 5 stars because the task of translating the book to the screen was (to me) a near impossible task and Disney Studios did a very difficult task quite well all things considered.Read the books - then see the movie - I assure you sci-fi fans out there will be hooked.
summary: Edgar Rice Burroughs Book translates to the Big Screen

reviewText: Let's get one thing out of the way: Disney totally blew it on the advertising side when it came to "John Carter," a Grade-A family adventure film, which is why it was so difficult to get folks into the theater in the US. However, this same film was No.1 across Europe for 2-3 weeks, breaking box office records in several countries, so the European marketing team certainly knew what draws people into theaters (and it is not posters of white apes and silhouetted Tharks of all things)! People want to see the winsome Princess Dejah Thoris (Lynn Collins) and the handsome hero, Taylor Kitsch (the incorrigibly charming "Gambit" from "X-Men Origins: Wolverine").There's no denying that Taylor Kitsch is THE action star of the year, what with three starring film roles in the first half of 2012. There's also no debate that "John Carter" has more heart, excitement, action and thrills than any other adventure film in many years. I've seen this film 38 times in the cinema (yep!) during the theatrical release and I couldn't wait to have it to watch any time I please. All of the performances are fabulous, from our world-weary yet bound-by-honor ex-Cavalryman (Kitsch) who is transported to the world of 1863 Mars (locals call it "Barsoom"), to the merciless plunderer, Sab Than (Dominic West), to the villainous mystic, Matai Shang (Mark Strong). There's also Lynn Collins as the most intelligent, valiant and lovely Disney princess of all, Dejah Thoris, a worthy Princess Of Mars, and the clever and dashing Kantos Kan, played by James Purefoy. Willem Dafoe is wonderfully warm as the Tharks' Jeddak (ruler) Tars Tarkas, played in perfect opposition to the cold and ruthless Tal Hajus (Thomas Haden-Church); this tandem is matched on the feminine side by the pure-hearted Sola (Samantha Morton) plagued by her evil nemesis Sarkoja (Polly Walker). And then there's everyone's favorite lizard-meets-dog, the playful Woola, who lavishes his protection (and slobbering) on his beloved John Carter.The PG-13 rating is mainly for a brief scene of torture which might upset small children, but while it might be unsettling, it is handled quickly and is there solely to advance the subplot. There is a very minor amount of cursing (nothing by comparison to most films these days) and, for any squeamish boys in your home, very little of the mushy stuff. "John Carter" is truly a most perfect action/adventure film for the entire family, beautifully translated from the novel of 100 years ago. Here's hoping for a couple of sequels because viewers will want to travel back to Barsoom along with Captain John Carter again and again.
summary: Thrills and excitement from beginning to end!

reviewText: Yes, H. G. Rider had already written his Allan Quartermain novels as well as She, but the birth of the first action hero wasn't until 1912 with Edgar Rice Burroughs's science fiction fantasy (published in a mens magazine) A Princess of Mars (two years before Tarzan the Ape Man). Here we see the first super hero/fighting man that inspired not only Flash Gordon, Buck Rogers, Rocky Jones, Commando Cody, Captain Kirk, Luke Skywalker and Starbuck but also inspired Superman, Batman, Captain America, Green Lantern, The Lone Ranger, Thor, Iron Man, Green Hornet and Indiana Jones (with a little Allan Quartermain dashed in for flavor!). Larger than life heroes battling impossible odds, possessing special skill sets or an arsenal of weaponry (usually "borrowed" from the bad guys) and then there's the beautiful princess that needed rescuing and the arena of death plot device are all from the feverish mind of Mr. Burroughs.John Carter, a Virginia gentleman dies in a cave during an Indian War and then wakes up on Mars wearing only his birthday suit, which is okay because everyone else on Mars (Barsoom) prefers their birthday suits as well (harnesses and insignia are usually all any of them wear) and then he goes about conquering the bad guys that later inspired Ming, the Draconians, the Cylons, the Klingons, the Romulans, the Emperor and even Darth Vader; this list is endless because it would also include Sinestro, Lex Luthor, Ra's Al Ghul, Red Skull, Dr. Doom, The Mandarian, Loki, Baltar and Butch Cavindish. You see where this is going...There are fifteen-foot tall, four-armed creatures with nasty underbitten tusks, flying skiffs, swordplay, incredible jumping and wicked explosions...oh, and the incomprable Dejah Thoris being kidnapped as a matter of routine (much the way Jane was in Tarzan); there are cavalry officers, apache Indians, warring tribes, psycho priests, forgotten gods, dictators, assassins, thieves, mad doctors, chessmen, would-be rapists, warriors, weird mating rituals, great white apes, vast deserts, inter-special mating (and the children thereof) and the occasional introduction by Mr. Burroughs himself. And that's just the 11 books that comprise the Martian Tales.This movie actually blends elements of the first three books, A Princess of Mars, The Gods Of Mars and The Warlord of Mars, and is a feast for the eyes. The imagery reflects the literature in many areas, regardless of the usual theatrical changes experienced from the translation of book-to-screen. I was thoroughly impressed, moreso because I've grown bored with Disney's inability to rise above dorky kiddie fare; however, Disney allayed all of my fears of a dumbbed-down travesty and gave me something that sits proudly among the children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren of celluoid if which it inspired. Of course, Disney now has Marvel and its lengthy host of heroes and villains to lavish the screen with like the Avengers (Captain America, Iron Man and Thor).Herein lies the swordplay of Flash Gordon and Luke Skywalker; herein lies the much-lusted after princesses Ardala, Aura and Leia (don't forget Padme, can't forget her!); herein lies the grandiose battles of Mongol, Tatooine and all points spaceward; herein lies giant monsters and deadly arenas that leering villains like Ming, Count Dooku, Killer Kane, the Klingons or Jabba the Hut are entertained with prior to their downfall; herein lies the skiffs, gadgets and back backs of Commando Cody, Buck Rogers, Bobba Fett and Imperial Biker Scouts; herein lies the genesis of so much that we take for granted.I've heard people tell me that John Carter rips off Star Wars, Star Trek and blah blah blah, but this only shows the limits of a literature-starved America within the vast wasteland of dullness.John Carter, cavalry officer of Virginia, Warlord of Barsoom and betroved of the incomprable Dejah Thoris is the great-great-grandaddy of all the action heroes of the 20th Century pop culture.Thank you, Disney, for doing something totally cool!A Princees of Mars was previously made as a low-budget Scy Fy TV movie (2009) starring the still lovely Traci Lords as Dejah Thoris and Antonio Sabato Jr. as an Iraq War-era John Carter; nothing at all like the recent John Carter but rather faithful to the plot of the first book.John Carter is Charlton Heston's real name but he changed it so it wouldn't be confused with the Burroughs's character; Heston's career seemed to parallel his literary namesake (Colonel George Taylor of Planet of the Apes is another of those classic action heroes).There is an even longer pedegree of the origin of the great action hero of legend (King Arthur, anyone?) we could delve into, but we'll leave this exploration for now and revel in the excitement of yesterday's hero exploding on the screen today.5 stars and beyond!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I went in to  "John Carter" filled with trepidation.  I often avoid these big, splashy CGI spectacles that never live up to their promises and I was sure that this film was going to be nothing more than lots of cinematic eye candy and short on substance. Added to that there was a lot of lackluster critical reviews.  Well, all I can say is that this was a grand entertainment and I am so glad I caught it on the big screen!I've heard some critics say the plot was a mess and overly convoluted. Really?  My suggestion to them is "don't text while watching a movie, you might miss something".  I found the plot fairly well done and actually made sense (if only the last Star Trek film had that going for it) and was interesting to boot.I also read that the look of Barsoom (Mars to you and me) was dull and uninteresting.  Hmmm, never been an admirerer of the stark and raw beauty of the American southwest I guess.  Personally I found Barsoom to be beautiful, alien, exotic and familiar all at the same time. After all, the Mars rovers have confirmed that the Red Planet does indeed look like our American southwest and I for one happen to think both places very scenic.Some critics have said the story is dull and lifeless.  OK, put down the crack pipe and step away from the video game console.  "John Carter" has a great fast paced plot with lots of interesting twists and turns. I also thought the characters were nicely drawn, if not overly complex, and that the alien races on Barsoom to be very interesting with fascinating customs which only made me want to learn more about them.Other critics have complained that they have seen this stuff before in movies like Star Wars and Avatar.  Wellllll, it seems as though those two directors (among other film makers and writers) have been looting the works of Edgar Rice Burroughs for quite some time so I guess there is bound to be a feeling of deja vu.Have we really become such a culture that is so easily jaded?  Can we no longer feel that sense of wonder and feeling of adventure in a film like "John Carter"?  Maybe we are too use to storylines being spoon fed to us in easily digested bites and cannot follow along with a film that isn't zipping past our eyeballs at 186,000 miles per second with flashy explosions at every eye blink.  If true then how sad that such a wondrous film will get pushed to the wayside in favor of something like Transformers 8.
Title: N/A

reviewText: There's a line about a character from the movie Sin City that goes: "He just had the rotten luck of being born in the wrong century."That sentiment somewhat applies to John Carter, in that while its effects are as modern as they come, the script feels like it grew from the 1980s, and I mean that as a compliment.  It was a fantastic time for action/adventure, sci-fi, and fantasy films. John Carter is impressive in its creation of a world, but it's also impressive in how deftly it avoids many annoying trappings of modern films of its like.  Sidekicks aren't annoying, there aren't any pop culture references, no wink at the camera nonsense.  It manages to not take itself too seriously, while also sticking wholly to its own world.Story in quick form:  a former Confederate soldier on a gold hunt ends up being transported to Mars, which contrary to popular belief is teeming with life--life that wants to kill other life.  Much as he wants to avoid war, Carter is swept up in one far, far from his home.That description does little justice to the movie.  War?  Not a fun subject, and often its the climactic "charge!" scene to many of today's sci-fi and fantasy movies.  John Carter keeps the pace strong throughout with good humor, amazing effects, and action scenes you can follow easily, from tower-hopping to airship-traversing sword fights to a little dog-monster that manages to be adorable while biting people's heads off.I fell in love with the movie because of the jumping most of all.  Because of the lower gravity on Mars and Carter's muscle density (or something), he's a lot stronger and more spry on Mars than he was on Earth.  He can leap all over the place and it's when he's doing this that the movie's magic comes to life.  Jumping between airships, jumping between towers, jumping from battle to battle--you want to be doing the same.The effects are amazing, the score is a classic--if I had to complain, I'd say there are a couple clunky lines and the beginning is a little messy, though it quickly straightens out.  What's stronger than all that is the heart of this movie, and I don't mean in the sappy family film sense.  I mean there's a heart of courage, strength, a sense of old school right and wrong that I normally don't get invested in, but here it was all so fun that I couldn't help enjoying it.  The movie really came together when you realize just how insidious the situation of the war is, and how important it is that John Carter is an outsider coming into this situation.  He's someone who can change it.Overall, don't come into this as cynically as I did.  The movie had to win me over, and it did, but it shouldn't have had to.  John Carter is about having a good time. If you're looking for that, you'll find it here. My DVD's already pre-ordered.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This was a terrific movie, well worth watching, in spite of all of the pundits trying to kill it off.Lynn Collins was just luminescent as Dejah Thoris.  The subtle tattoos and jewelry and costuming, combined with her native intelligence and athletic grace and power made for a beautiful modern version of the Princess of Mars. Her irises were enhanced (probably digitally) to a shimmering blue, which was a really nice effect (I think her eyes are normally gray or hazel green, from other photos).  The Edgar Rice Burroughs (ERB) version of Dejah Thoris would have been boring to watch, much like Kim Basinger doing nothing but scream and get tossed around like a sack of potatoes, playing a Victorian era Damsel in Distress in the first Batman movie.Much of the story may seem derivative unless you consider that ERB created them first 100 years ago, and his ideas have been liberally borrowed by many subsequent generations of science fiction writers and movie makers.  It has since become a canon of science fiction that Mars was once inhabited by a lost civilization that faded away as its water and atmosphere faded away.  "Star Wars" and "Avatar" are among many movies that have taken large chunks of the original ideas of ERB's Barsoom series - the swashbuckling battles between airships, the Arena Battle with monsters, the existence of a powerful force in this strange new world, and the multiple races/species of intelligent creatures coexisting and fighting against each other.The storyline of the movie is actually a combination of ERB's "A Princess of Mars" and the second book in the Barsoom series "The Gods of Mars".  The trip to the Valley Dor and the mysterious Therns do not appear until the second book.Disney appears to have done everything wrong to market this movie, and the amount of vitriole directed against the movie, probably planted by Disney insiders, has been totally disproportional to the actual quality of the movie.  It's almost as if Disney is fighting an internal battle to not make any more of this series of movies (three were planned).  Which would be a complete shame because I really like this movie.Could the movie have been better?  Well they could have picked a bigger male star with more charisma than Taylor Kitsch, who was OK in this role, but not overwhelming and was outshined by the glittering Lynn Collins.  It would have been interesting to see one of the shiny uber-handsome and very large Hemsworth brothers, Chris or Liam, in this role, or even Sam Worthington.  Dejah's father Tardos Mors and Kantos Kan were played by none other than Caesar and Mark Antony (from the HBO series "Rome") - Ciaran Hinds and James Purefoy - which I thought was an odd paring, a bit too easily recognizable for people who watch a lot of movies.But otherwise, it's a great movie, and I hope people go and support it while it is still in the theaters, and I for one am planning to get the DVD/BluRay when it comes out.  Let's hope against hope for a continuation of this series.

reviewText: A long time ago in a galaxy not so far away...Edgar Rice Burroughs wrote a great sci-fi adventure story calledA Princess of Marsthat would become one of the most influential science fiction fantasy stories of the 20th century inspiring George Lucas to make the epicStar Warsfranchise nearly 60 years after it. It has taken a full century for Burroughs' imaginative epic fantasy to come to life on the big screen but John Carter has arrived in theaters DOA thanks to a series of costly marketing blunders by Disney of equally epic proportions.Despite its numerous failures to attract an audience, director Andrew Stanton has delivered a first class epic fantasy film that brings the pages of Burroughs' highly imaginative world of Barsoom to life in living, breathing color with vibrant special effects and computer animation that could easily have become Disney's Star Wars franchise with the proper marketing muscle behind it. Unfortunately we will probably never see the further adventures of John Carter inThe Gods of MarsorWarlord of Marsor any of the other chronicles in Burroughs' classic pulp series because the audience for whom the film was targeted has no idea just who John Carter is and is far more excited to see this summer's Hunger Games, also based on a popular series of teenage literary novels, than a hundred year-old character from a book they've never even heard of.Perhaps the biggest tragedy is the over-simplified title changed by Stanton himself. Who is John Carter? Why should anyone care about him?Well, he's Taylor Kitsch who played Gambit fromX-Men Origins: Wolverineand his co-star Lynn Collins from the same film is ideally cast as the beautiful Princess Dejah Thoris of Helium. John Carter is a confederate captain from Virginia who travels to Arizona to find gold, only to find himself astrally transported to Mars after being fatally shot by Apache Indians. There are plenty of metaphors here between the natives of both worlds that evoke Dances With Wolves and Avatar as John Carter becomes the propheseid hero and savior of Barsoom which the native Tharks call their red planet. With an inspired cast of supporting actors with Willem Dafoe as the voice of Tars Tarkas, a nine foot tall, four armed green Martian, Dafoe sounds exactly as I would have always imagined the voice of Tars Tarkas to sound like and brings the character to life with his impassioned performance. Other inspired casting choices include terrific supporting performances by Ciaran Hinds and James Purefoy who are reunited again from working together in HBO's excellent seriesRomeas Tardos Mors and Kantos Kan respectively. Dominic West from HBO's The Wire also rounds out the inspired casting as the villanous Sab Than seeking the hand of the Princess of Helium to unite a planetary civil war and become its ruler.John Carter is filled with action, adventure, special effects, animation, heroes, villains, monsters and a princess, it has all the fundamental ingredients of a classic Disney film and is a faithful adaptation of Burroughs' novel, and Disney and Stanton have delivered a spectacular film that has fallen flat on its face as a $250 million box office disaster that is being critically compared to 1995's sci-fi flop Waterworld. It must make over $400 million just to break even, another unrealistic expectation reminiscent of 2010'sTron: Legacyby the foolish suits at Disney who clearly have no clue how to run the studio nor do they know anything about what they have on their hands or how to mass market their product and for that heads should roll and Disney's marketing department all deserve the grim fate that awaits them.As for the fate of John Carter, who knows, but all indications so far seem to imply that we may never return to the red planet on the big screen again. Fortunately the written pages of Burroughs will last forever for those of us that still remember them...Long live John Carter of Mars!

reviewText: Although I read many of the Tarzan books and found them exciting and far superior to the movies I have never read a John Carter book even though I'm a dedicated science-fiction fan. I've referred to this as a fantasy movie rather than a science fiction movie as simply a personal call based upon my impressions of the movie.I did not see it in theaters nor did I see any of the trailers referenced in other reviews so I essentially watched it for the first time free of any prejudice. The first time I watched the 2-D version as my wife is uncomfortable with the glasses. On that viewing I thought it was an impressive action movie and provided a fine evening's entertainment. The video and sound is impressive and the dialogue is usually understandable.The second time I watched it in 3-D and had a really good time with the movie. The 3-D effect is good and I discovered that familiarity with the movie enabled me to enjoy it more and I just had more fun with the story, the video quality, the sound and the special effects. This was a gratifying experience and I'm glad I've got the 3-D version.True to the Disney standard it is free of bad language and sexual overtones and is suitable for most audiences. I found it a very enjoyable movie experience and recommend it highly.
summary: Fun and Entertaining Fantasy Action Movie

reviewText: No movie can equal the book it was made from.  Words don't translate easily into film.  The film itself is very good, very well made.  It is not an exact reflection of the first JCoM book, unfortunately, it is something of a mishmash, so 4 stars. The charm of the book is partially in ERB's Victorian attitudes, which reflect fairly accurately how a Civil War soldier would actually have felt.  It is hard to imagine that this book could have been written before my father was born.  I think the movie would have done better had it been a little closer to the book, but that's just my opinion.  It's worth seeing.

reviewText: Reviewing movies is in my opinion like reviewing food and that's really hard. Everyone likes different things in varying amounts done a certain way and they sure are picky about it.This movie kind of bombed at the box office but has done brilliantly on the disc sales and rental market. The same thing is happening with Pacific Rim incidentally.  John Carter  (Formerly John Carter of Mars before Disney got scared about the word Mars after Mars needs Moms bombed so incredibly badly.) is an 18th century western science fiction fantasy adventure based on a famous book. Ha, now that line summed it up.  :-)It looks lovely and is visually appealing with a powerful soundtrack theme and great overall design. Has a lot of unique ideas and objects. There is a good cast, it's well acted and has interesting characters. Action, a few jokes a few heartfelt moments and lot more action.This is one of those movies that if it's on I can just watch it again. Even after the 20th time. As for food review comparisons I think it's one of those movies that if you go in with an open mind and no predefined expectations you'll enjoy it for what it is. Unless you have an allergy that is.  :-)
summary: Great family movie and I love it.

reviewText: The irony of the poor box office and critical reception of this nevertheless entertaining film is that, while it may have been indifferently marketed by Disney (like THE ROCKETEER, another favorite of mine)it was also released far too many years after any (non-geriatric) fan base remained to support it due to the fact that, like THE LORD OF THE RINGS before it, the technology simply did not exist until recently with the advent of CGI to make it believably plausible in execution (even the great Ray Harryhausen would have been hard-pressed to do a convincing stop-action animation version with so many of the principal characters being non-human).  As an unfortunate result so much time has passed by now that, with the exception of Tarzan, most of Burroughs' great creations have largely faded from popular memory, and after a procession of so many Star Wars, Avatars and Prometheuses (Prometheii?) JOHN CARTER is now is inevitably perceived as imitative rather than innovative, which is a grave disservice to a terrific series of books and a pretty good film....
summary: Now that they can do it, nobody wants to see it...

reviewText: I watched this on DVD, feeling a bit put out that I hadn't seen it on the big screen.By the end of it, I felt even WORSE because it's so great! Maybe if it had featured 'Mars' in the title, to attract those who knew nothing of him, or who'd missed the previews, it could've drawn more people. And maybe it could've lost about ten minutes, to bring it well under two hours.But those minor quibbles do not detract in any way from the greatness of this film.Clearly, I had fallen prey to bad press leading up to the cinematic release. I see a lot of films and the high prices mean I have to let one or two slip by.This is what happens. A few bad reviews are written, often by people who don't ever like these kinds of films. Then they're replicated around the world, ad nauseum, via the internet. Some news websites often employ people who sit at desks and do no more than rewrite what's already 'out there'. They call themselves 'journalists'-- they're really little more than copy boys.So what a handful of reviewers said-- stacked on top of the high cost of the movie-- created a negative 'buzz'. Reviewers who follow are affected by this. They don't want to go against the grain because they don't want to be seen as out of the loop, or out of their minds.Then people who have never seen the film, and have no intention of doing so, join in via blogs and online forums and social media. Before long, you end up with a mass of negative opinion that it's almost impossible to combat. The net is infamous for allowing complete strangers to kick someone or something while it's down.This is what occured with the Green Lantern movie. It had awesome special effects, and was resonably true to the comic. It was not as good as Thor but it was pretty damn great; certainly better than the re-booted Spiderman. But it too was affected by overwhelmingly negative coverage-- again, by people who hadn't stepped foot in the cinema.I can only wonder what it's like to be part of making a stunning film, months and years of work, only to have it shot down by people who largely don't know what they're on about.People need to be smarter when they're considering what a good film is, and whether they want to see it. I've learned my lesson.I think that in the future, John Carter will be seen as one of the classic science fiction films of the 2010s.
summary: GREAT TO SEE SO MANY LIKE-MINDED PEOPLE HERE

reviewText: This was a terrific movie of Edgar Rice Burroughs lesser known John Carter (Barsoom) series! His vision was so far beyond the imagination of the people in his day it's incredible! People couldn't imagne flying machine's, four armed lifeforms, etc.  As a result this series was left behind with the poputlarity of Tarzan.  If you are a fan of ERB's and aware of the Barsoom series you will be entertained and appreciate this movie. If you have never heard of the Barsoom series you will still love it. Great story and great action all told in a cohesive plot you can follow.  While not really true to the plot of ERB's books the movie captures the essence and feel of the books better than most movie to book conversions. Planning for this movie has been in the works for decades. Good CGI finally made it possible. They finally made a believable four armed race possible and they did a great job! Blows away the over hyped Planet of the Apes for CGI effects as well as the storyline and plot. Makes for a great movie with the right ratio of disbelief and emotional attachment.  I only wish the movie industry would do a truely true version of Tarzan (plus additional movies in the Barsoom series). With the current CGI a really good version or Tarzan, set in the appropriate time period is now possible. (If you've read the books you know what I mean) Nothing in the past has come even close to the first two Tarzan books as ERB's wrote them. Too bad the appropriate appreciation of ERB's imagination and talent aren't realized today. Unfortunately the movie industry seems to always think they need to rewrite a books plot and story. They almost never make an improvement.  Sorry I got off on a tangent. Overall John Carter is a great movie. Even if you have never heard of Edgar Rice Burroughs you'll love this movie for the plot, pacing and feelings the movie invokes.
summary: Great Movie-Does justice to ERB's vision

reviewText: I read the John Carter on Mars books many years ago while I was in college. A few months ago I came close to paying $19 a ticket for my wife and I  to see it opening weekend but at the last moment I decided to consider the very poor newspaper reviews of the movie and wait for it to come out on DVD. I almost bought the DVD.... thankfully at the last moment I saved my hard-earned cash and watched it on pay per view.  There is really nothing to recommend this movie. The plot is pathetic and introduces some immortals who are manipulating the course of history on Barsoom. I don't recall this element in any of the books and they serve no purpose- other than to annoy and disrupt the flow of the already poor story- here except to provide the technological means for John Carter to find himself on Mars. I prefer the version in the books- I believe it was through a dream, or something like that- in a fantasy movie not everything has to have an explanation.Special effects naturally dominate this movie but here again the movie fails. The "airships" did not capture the feel of the airships in the books and they didn't even remotely look real. The Tharks were o.k. The fixed sets looked horrible- the cities etc. Never do we feel we are anyplace but Arizona or New Mexico.The acting was horrible as was the dialogue.In sum: save your money and your free time. Don't waste either on this movie.

reviewText: American author, Edgar Rice Burroughs, is well-known for creating sci-fi fiction and adventure books in his lifetime.  Best known for creating "Tarzan", Edgar Rice Burroughs is also known for his sci-fi tales about Mars known as "Barsoom".In 1912, he would write the novel "A Princess of Mars" which would introduce people to a new hero named John Carter and for five more decades, he would go on to write eleven more novels based on the character and many generations of sci-fi fans would grow up reading Edgar Rice Burrough's sci-fi stories.  And for many people, Burrough's "Barsoon" stories would inspire many sci-fi authors such as Robert A. Heinlen, Arthur C. Clarke and Ray Bradbury.  Including filmmakers such as James Cameron and George Lucas.And many would try to create a film adaption of the film for nearly a hundred years, but the technology to create something so ambitious with spacecraft, monsters and a large alien race was not exactly an easy film that studios could even consider, so many times, owning the rights to make a film based on John Carter fell through.  And in 2006, there was discussion of another attempt to make Burrough's "A Princess of Mars" a movie but with the title of "John Carter" and was originally planned to be directed by Jon Favreau and produced by Harry Knowles.  But Favreau would go on to work on "Iron Man" and so, the next man in line to work on the film was Pixar's Andrew Stanton.Stanton had written many of Pixar's blockbuster animated films such as the three "Toy Story" films, "A Bug's Life", "Monsters, Inc.", "Finding Nemo", "Wall-E" and since he grew up enjoying Edgar Rice Burrough's and he has done a magnificent job in writing films, as well as directing "Finding Nemo" and "Wall-E", why not give him the opportunity to direct Disney's most ambitious sci-fi action film.  So ambitious that "John Carter" was budgeted at $272 million.The film's screenplay is by Stanton, Mark Andrews (storyboard artist for "Spider-Man", "The Iron Giant" and the "Star Wars: Clone Wars" TV series) and Michael Chabon (who wrote the novel "Wonder Boys" and the screen story for "Spider-Man 2″)."John Carter" would feature stars such as Taylor Kitsch ("Battleship", "X-Men Origins: Wolverine", "Friday Night Lights"), Lynn Collins ("X-Men Origins: Wolverine", "The Number 23″, "The Lake House"), Willem Dafoe ("Platoon", "Spider-Man", "The Boondock Saints"), Thomas Haden Church ("Spider-Man 3″, "Sideways", "Easy A") and Samantha Morton ("Control", "In America", "Morvern Callar").VIDEO:"John Carter" is presented in 1080p High Definition (2:40:1).  If there is one thing that videophiles can remain confident in Disney, is that they strive for perfection, may it be animated or live action films.  And "John Carter" does not disappoint!  The video quality is absolutely beautiful and vibrant.  The colors of the various costume design, the scenery of Mars to the detail of the skin and even CGI aliens and monsters are magnificent.  Black levels are nice and deep and the clarity is amazing.While watching this film, I detected no artifacts, banding or any major issues with the video.  If anything, "John Carter" looks magnificent on Blu-ray!AUDIO & SUBTITLES:As for the lossless audio, "John Carter" is presented in English 7.1 DTS-HD MA, English DVS 2.0 Dolby Digital and French and Spanish 5.1 Dolby Digital.As for the lossless track, "John Carter" like the video is just amazing to listen to.  This is an immersive soundtrack!  You literally hear (and feel) everything around you.  From the overhead ships, the many crashes, booms, blasts, you can feel confident that the surround channels are active, especially LFE.  This is a film that will definitely utilize your subwoofer.  Great direction effects, ambiance is also well-featured.  "John Carter" sounds absolutely fantastic on Blu-ray!SPECIAL FEATURES"John Carter" comes with the following special features:Audio Commentary - Featuring audio commentary with director Andrew Stanton and producers Jim Morris and Lindsey Collins who go through every detail about the making of the film and everything you need to know about casting, visual effects and more!Disney Second Screen - If you have an iPad or laptop, you can sync the film and enjoy additional content.Deleted Scenes with Optional Director's Commentary - (19:02) Featuring ten deleted scenes including an alternate opening and with optional commentary by director Andrew Stanton.100 Years in the Making - (10:43) A fascinating featurette about Edgar Rice Burroughs and those who tried to bring John Carter to the big screen for the last hundred years.  Featuring re-enactments of Edgar Rice Burroughs, director Andrew Stanton, filmmaker Jon Favreau and many more.360 Degrees of John Carter - (34:33) A production diary featuring the costume and makeup department and following director Andrew Stanton through a day on the set of "John Carter".Barsoom Bloopers - (1:48) Gag reel from "John Carter".EXTRAS:"John Carter" on Blu-ray comes with a separate DVD featuring the film.  The DVD is presented in widescreen 2:40:1, English, French and Spanish 5.1 Dolby Digital, English DVS 2.0 Dolby Digital Language track and subtitles in English SDH, French and Spanish.  Also, a slipcover case is included.JUDGMENT CALL:Before watching "John Carter", I am aware of how badly this film did in the box office and I have read the various news reports on the finger pointing of why the film failed.Was it because Andrew Stanton, who knew how to write and direct animated films for Pixar, was not ready to take on the job for such large scale film?  Was it because the concept of "John Carter" has been rehashed in so many other films such as "Star Wars", "Avatar", "Flash Gordon" and other sci-fi films?After finally watching "John Carter", I felt that part of the problem was that the film was not marketed well and while John Carter is a name that will entice Edgar Rice Burroughs fans familiar with his work, the goal of a lot of action films is not to solely market to the Generation X or the Baby Boomers but for the Generation Y.  A generation who are used to vampire films, big budget superhero films and sci-fi films such as "Avatar".  And "John Carter", while familiar to us who are familiar with Burroughs work, may sound like a politician to today's generation.And the problem that the film suffered from was an over-reliance on John's relation to the alien characters and not enough on the storyline about John Carter.  I know that there was a lot of trimming with this film, but I wonder how much important scenes were cut in order to make 132 minutes.  We are given flashbacks of John's wife and child, but it would have made a bigger visual impact if we saw what happened and how it would make things worse for John Carter.As for the war between the Heliums and Zodanga, one again...this feels rushed.  While we are given a narration at the beginning, it's not enough.  You need to build upon the antagonist and show why he is so evil.  And it's been mentioned many times before how George Lucas has borrowed from Burrough's "Barsoom" stories.  But one thing he made sure was to show people how evil the empire was and how Darth Vader was the ultimate evil, but also someone behind the scenes.  There was nothing that made us know the level of evil within the character of Sab Than, Jeddak of Dozanga.  All that was established was the Thern and how they love to instill chaos on a planet.For a sci-fi film, may it be a Predator, an Alien, an evil empire or whatever, the antagonist must be shown to be a great evil and thus, the viewer can root for the protagonist.  But it doesn't happen this way in "John Carter", why doesn't Princess Deja Thoris want to go back home?  It's because she is being forced to marry the enemy.  For today's viewers, they are so used to seeing the greater evil either kill a love one, destroying a planet or annihilating a race, there is just no way that an arrange marriage is "enough" to be believed for today's sci-fi fan.And this is the problem that "John Carter" has met with audiences.  This is story based on a 1912 novel which has been rehashed many times and because the people behind the film are great fans of Burrough's work and want to respect the work of his novels, there is no straying away from the storyline. Listening to the audio commentary, there was a moment where Stanton and others talked about how they were big fans, but sometimes a film needs to be changed from its original novel in order to make things modern.  And despite the fact that it may offend those who grew up with the film, the fact that we see this happening with super-hero films such as "The Avengers", "Spider-Man", "X-Men: First Class", to name a few, the writers get away from the original comic book series, maintain the characters but modernize the screenplay for a modern audience.The focus seemed of keeping the storyline intact, but giving today's technology a chance of bringing the story of "Barsoom" to a wider audience who may not be familiar with John Carter or the characters of the novels, is a major gamble.  And while watching the film, I realized more and more that the film was devoid of any emotional attachment to its primary characters until we reach towards the end of the film.  And this is surprising to me as Andrew Stanton has always made characters a priority, may it be in the "Toy Story" films, "Wall-E", "Finding Nemo", "Monsters, Inc.".  There was always an emotional attachment to the characters and in this film, it was geared more towards the popcorn action fan and showing that John Carter can kick some butt.As for the Blu-ray release, as expected from a Disney Blu-ray release, the video quality and the lossless audio are fantastic and there are a good number of special features, including a fascinating audio commentary, a featurette on how it took nearly 100 years for a "John Carter" film to be released and other special features to keep viewers busy watching this Blu-ray for several hours.Looking back, especially having grown up reading "John Carter", not through the novels but the old '70s Marvel comic book series and my feeling when I heard of the film being made was more of a "would anyone care in this day and age about "John Carter?". While myself and others who grew up reading the novels or comic book series would say "yes"! , after watching this film, I felt that the staff did a good job in bringing Edgar Rice Burrough's sci-fi classic to the big screen and bringing life to the characters, monsters, aliens and air vehicles, but visual effects and action sequences can only go so far.  I still feel that Andrew Stanton is a talented filmmaker and an excellent writer, but there was a reason why this film was not made for so long and it's not just because of the technology, but it's because so many of the stories elements have been done on other sci-fi films, rehashed over and over and "John Carter" suffers from sci-fi banality.But by no means is "John Carter" a horrible film.  "John Carter" manages to have its fair share of fun and enjoyable moments and I felt it managed to be a sci-fi popcorn action film that was created to be nothing more than what it is meant to be.And while I felt that the storyline of the film was average, the overall quality of the video and audio is not. "John Carter" looks absolutely magnificent on Blu-ray and I'm confident that videophile and audiophiles will be impressed by this Blu-ray release.  I'll even go farther in saying that this Blu-ray release of "John Carter" is probably one of the best looking and sounding Blu-ray releases of 2012 so far!Overall, if you are looking for a family sci-fi action film, "John Carter" may not have done well in the box office, but giving it a try on Blu-ray, you may find yourself enjoying it!
summary: If you are looking for a sci-fi popcorn action film, "John Carter" is a film you may be looking for!

reviewText: My son and I went to see this movie in 3-D at a theater in Eau Claire, meeting in the food court prior to going into the theater. It was a very enjoyable movie full of action and the 3-D effects were good though perhaps not the finest I have seen. The special effects in the movie were superb, the storyline was exciting and all in all it was one great movie.Sadly, the night after viewing the movie my son passed away so after 35 years of going together to see movies, a tradition we kept alive since before he was 2 years of age, it will be the last movie we will enjoy seeing together. Im just glad that it was a really good one that both of us enjoyed immensely.So, from before the movie "The Scanners" was released, a tradition has passed. I only hope that wherever my son is that he gets to enjoy watching action packed movies just like the literally hundreds we saw together on this mortal coil.I highly recommend this movie to any and everyone. Especially to those of you who actually read the books featuring John Carter. Ya don't have to see it in 3-D, the movie would stand alone in traditional format very easily as the action packed, special effect filled film that it is. I am going to pre-order a blu ray copy for more reasons than simply wanting to own a great, very fun movie to watch. I will also order it out of the memory of my best friend, a son I thought of more as a brother than my child, and simply one heck of a great guy that a lot of people will miss...like just about everyone who had the pleasure to have met him.But for those of you just looking for a great movie to buy and watch, I highly recommend this movie. And also, go to the library and read the book series. They remain as great reading despite it being over a hundred years since they were penned.GREAT MOVIE!!

reviewText: I have no idea what happened to make this film flop like it did because it is one of the greatest adventure films I have ever seen! That is unless you take a chance on this film and discover the wonderful fantasy world of these beloved stories and send a message to Disney that we all would like to return to Barsoom!The film begins in the old west with a tired soldier looking to make his fortune.  He has some adventures with Bryan Cranston (yes, THE Bryan Cranston) before being spirited away to Mars where he finds danger, friendship, glory, and...well I shouldn't give away too much.  You should just stop reading my third rate review and buy this film and give it a shot.  I PROMISE you will not be disappointed.

reviewText: Having been a fan of Edgar Rice Burroughs' writing since childhood, it was with great trepidation that I approached the news that not just Hollywood, but Disney Hollywood, were finally bringing 'A Princess of Mars', the first book in ERB's 'Barsoom' series, to the big screen.I couldn't be happier with what they achieved.There were certain changes and consolidations made in this movie (no spoilers from me - see the movie, then read the books!), but nothing to stop me from thoroughly enjoying it on the big screen twice (so far).  The acting, writing and execution of this film were all absolutely awe-inspiring, but nothing about this movie was so jaw-dropping as the fact that it completely tanked at the box office.If Disney's marketing department hadn't dropped the ball (as they did with their 1991 overlooked gem, 'The Rocketeer') and left the title as it appears at the end of the film, 'JOHN CARTER OF MARS', it might have made the film more accessible to people who had absolutely no knowledge of this archetypal and iconic science-fantasy legend.  With the exceptions of a few elitist, die-hard ERB purists who carped about every little change, I don't know anyone who's seen JCM and disliked it.  JCM could've been multi-marketed as an adventure, a sci-fantasy, comedic (~not~ a comedy, though), and above all else, a love story, but Disney acted like they didn't know what they had on their hands.  That is truly a shame, because, even putting the books aside, the movie they made is phenomenal and it got lambasted unfairly.So, I implore you to at least watch, if not outright buy, 'JOHN CARTER OF MARS' when it comes out on BRD and DVD.  You won't regret it.And just maybe it'll let Disney know that the rest of the books are still waiting to be given the treatment this movie unfairly was denied.
summary: Ignore the Ciritics - WATCH / BUY THIS MOVIE!!

reviewText: This is an extraordinary, and phenomenally entertaining movie.  Right in keeping with the creative genius of "Star Wars",  and "Avatar" or even "Ben Hur."  I can hardly wait for the sequel which I hope Disney/Stanton will make.  Excellent acting and what a story to follow.  Interplanetary travel via a medallion powered by blue light and battling for your life and others.  How many of us have gazed up at the stars and thought if I could only go there now and see what life is like on that star, that speck of light up there?  Well, this movie takes you to Mars and you are transported right along with the hero, John Carter by chanting a few words of an ancient chant while touching that medallion and suddenly, incredibly, you are there!John Carter, a mere mortal on earth, a soldier, from the state of  Virginia,  becomes a superhuman being on Mars.  He can fly. He can fight hordes of creatures, horrible monsters, devious, scheming, villanous immortals,  and rescue a warrior princess and fall in love. War, and  peace unfold in thrilling action packed scenes.Clever plot, excellent insertion of writer Edgar Rice Burroughs as John Carter's nephew and delightful use of humor plus amazing electrifying  battle scenes.  This movie  should have been lauded and included in  Academy Award honors or Cannes Film Festival.  I don't know what the critics were thinking.  This is an awesome film.  Kudos  to Taylor Kitsch (John Carter)  and Lynn Collins ( the beautiful warrior princess) and to the entire cast and to Disney.  Come on and make "John Carter 2"Highly recommend.  Good adventure.  Good fun.

reviewText: Having assumed all the negative press was on the mark, I rented a DVD of Carter at our local grocery for .99--and was pleasantly surprised to find this was a fun adventure movie.  My wife and I had only recently watched the two seasons of Rome and were delight to see Caesar and Mark Anthony reappear on Mars in something close to their same roles. The physics was nonsense, of course, but the actual pace and complexity of the story was measured and as good as any classic western.  Carter, the movie, has been given a bad rap.  It ought rightly to capture more of the attention it deserves--just for being a well-spun yarn.If the movie had weak points (Ok, maybe Taylor Kitsh was a little under-dimensional--but even that worked), they were nothing to the critics who gave it an eager thumbs down and the seeming frightened old women shuffling the deck at Disney.

reviewText: While there's some departure from the original novel here, the insertions and additions work very well and, I dark say, even make it better in certain respects. The set design, special effects, and all the rest are stupefying, on par with STAR WARS or any other first tier science fiction film. Yet, JOHN CARTER does not rely on simple wows to carry it: The storyline and script are equally well-done. This film also portrays alien life forms as well or better than any other production that I've seen. You don't have to completely understand the mythos behind the novel to enjoy this film, and the various Classical, Biblical, and mythological allusions add something to the story.Quite a miscellany of cast: Taylor Kitsch, Lynn Collins, and, perhaps most of all, Willem Dafoe as an 8-foot-tall, 4-armed Martian (!) all play their parts very well. The start-to-finish narration that takes the audience by the hand, relating every detail and event (right up to the Disney logo) is a device that would usually be ruinous, but it's both helpful and humorous, adding another quirky appeal to JOHN CARTER. Only a Disney film with Colin Wilson on its production team could produce something so memorable.Incredible!'nuff said!
summary: You're in for a Real Treat

reviewText: I have been reading Edgar Rice Burroughs books for over 60 years. I found John Carter to follow the story line and wonder of the books marvelously. reviewText: Oh, my God, all these four and five star reviews are written by family members of Disney, right? No wonder this film bombed. Juvenile from beginning to end, and Carter's jumping "flying" scenes right out of all those Asian Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon flicks where people sailed through the air on "erased" ropes and tethers. So why did I watch the whole movie after I knew it was a total loser in the first ten minutes? I'm a sucker for superb special effects and no one can take that away from the makers of this silly, near indecipherable waste of good talent. In my rarely humble opinion, the whole cast was miscast. Nothing personal, the people are good actors, just too pretty, too young, too whatever. The movie lacks dirt, dust, grime, and grit, if that makes any sense. The whole thing is too clean, too shiny, the CGI too perfect. It's the difference, I suspect, between this Disney/Pixar epic, and Industrial Light & Magic who do the more sophisticated CGI films. Why STAR WARS (ILM) at its worst, was never boring, slow, or lacking the "wow" factor. Whereas John Carter strives for Lord Of The Rings quality but falls flat on all accounts. I know it's really being picky to say so, but even young kids know that neither of the two moons of Mars are spherical. And in every night scene here, there they are, always in the same place, spaced the same distance apart, no drama, no sense that we're really on another planet. Okay, one big positive to end with. I did like the ending. Strangely enough. The final plot twist was clever, but comes way too late (like at the very end of the movie)is way too little, and can't even begin to save this film from the "coulda been great" junk pile. Even with the outstanding special effects, I can't recommend this antiseptic, almost sterile presentation.
summary: Crouching Creature, Hidden Drags On and On...

reviewText: I loved the film and eagerly look forward to the DVD.  I will bow to no one as a fan of Burroughs because I am a third generation reader, having first editions of some of the books from grandparents, and I have passed this love to children and grandchildren.  I have collected a great deal of Edgar Rice Burroughs material, but I hold most dear a letter from him in 1947.  As a kid I had the gall to send him a story idea, something I realized later that few professional authors are happy to receive.  ERB was very gracious and sent me a letter expressing his appreciation and complimented me on my imagination as an eleven year old.  He encouraged me to keep writing which I have in one form or another.I had seen the awful John Carter of Mars film on the SyFy Channel and frankly worried about how this film would be handled.  I need not have worried as Disney did an excellent job.  Not exactly like the original novel, A Princess of Mars, but very close and all my favorite people were there.  We have the great beauty of the planet which I cannot see why some critics felt was boring.  It was an honest depiction of the planet Barsoom which I read about as a kid and later reread.  John Carter is pretty much as I imagined him, "the incomparable" Dejah Thoris is a beautiful warrior princess, Tars Tarkis and other Tharks are exactly as I envisioned they would be and it was so good to see Woola.  As a kid I wanted a Calot for a pet.  I liked certain things added to  the film not in the book.  Such things as Civil War flashbacks that gave us a picture of why John Carter was the type of person he turned out to be once on Mars.  The story was very well done and the special effects met the visions I had when I read the original books.I have seen the film more than once, and outside of family members who knew details from me, I found that describing certain aspects about Mars in the original books helped make this an enjoyable film for those who had never experienced ERB.  It is also possible that Tarzan films, so often rerun on TV. hurt John Carter  because of expectations.  We do need to advise people that the Tarzan in the films, as much as we loved Johnny W., are definitely not the Tarzan in the books.  Burroughs himself was not that happy with those films, however they were money makers. We think he would have loved this film.  I am critical about the marketing as and feel that Barnes and Noble and other stores should have been able to release the works of ERB much earlier than waiting for the film to come out.  At least that is what happened where I live.  Just as The Hunger Gams wetted the appetite for kids to see the film, which I personally was not that sold on, there would have been a greater desire to see John Carter.  I also believe it would have been wiser to keep the original title, A Princess of Mars.Sadly I have heard that Disney has dropped plans for a sequel.  A real shame as this could have been a series to have rivaled Lord of the Rings, Narnia, Pirates of the Caribbean and even Star Wars.
summary: This life long Edgar Rice Burroughs fan loved the film.

reviewText: A heck of a fun film that most people will never see. It's too bad Disney wimped out and didn't market it well or enough. It's also too bad the director or screen writer tried too hard to explain everything about Mars before the film even started.But once the first confusing 5 minutes or so are over, it's an amazingly good adventure movie. Lots of action, wonderful characters and creatures (in particular the Martian dog and any Thark, male or female) and a bunch of good action and CGI. The film is just plain beautiful to look at--dying planet or not, you're ready to go to Mars by the end of it. And the sky ships are just amazing--I could have watched those all day.If they'd skipped the humorous but unenecessary framing device of having Edgar Rice Burroughs in the film, and just gone right to Mars, it'd probably have done much better. It's too bad the filmmakers didn't have more confidence in the material and the story itself, to say nothing of the actual title, A Princess of Mars.I'm willing to bet the hordes of people who went to see Prometheus would have been much happier after seeing John Carter.

reviewText: JOHN CARTER (a/k/a JOHN CARTER OF MARS, Dir. Andrew Stanton, 132 minutes, 2012, based on the novelA Princess of Marsby Edgar Rice Burroughs) was one of the most swashbuckling, rollicking fun films I have seen in these long years. I absolutely LOVED it like I love few other films.The folks at Disney have not been sleeping, I can tell you! Neither was Burroughs, who spun this off into theThe John Carter of Mars Series (5 Books)series of novels (a/k/a "The Barsoom Series", Barsoom being the Martians' word for Mars). Sadly and oddly, this film would flop like almost no other Disney flop. Let's hope it hits cult status rapidly, which is the least we can do to show our appreciation.Briefly, Captain John Carter (an incredibly hunky yet otherworldly young soul named Taylor Kitsch who somehow manages to occasionally look like Josh Brolin) is a Civil War cavalryman from Virginia, fighting for the South. Full of spunk and vinegar, through machinations I won't really ruin here, Carter finds himself on Mars facing a tall green four-armed warrior chief, Tars Tharkas (Willem Dafoe) of the Tharks. Carter's struggle to adapt to the gravitation of Mars is one of several sequences that will make you howl with laughter.Honestly, you'll have fun seeing how quickly and elegantly this comes about - but I won't tell other than to give you one clue. When John Carter realizes how he got there he equates it with a telegram. This will feed hugely into the storyline.Carter - who is affectionately nicknamed and called "Virginia" because he made the error of mentioning it - becomes adopted into the giant green tribe. They try to stand out of the way of an ongoing war between two giant factions of normal humans - blue-blooded Martian humans, of course. The relatively good guys are led by an impressive Tardos Mors (Ciarán Hinds), father of Princess Dejah Thoris (a very beautiful Lynn Collins).Manipulating space-time in a most psychopathic way is a bunch of baldheaded creeps led by Matai Shang (Mark Strong) and we must hate them, because what they are doing to Mars they plan to do to Earth very soon. In any case, not wanting to mess this up for you any further, I can only insist that you get this DVD and enjoy the heck out of it.I can't begin to list the ways this film might have been ruined. Kitsch is absolutely enjoyable and believable (though no one seemed to think he needed to actually sound like a Virginian). This could have turned into a meathead Bruce Campbell-fest. Those fests have their limited place, but not here. In no way is this wonderful adventure ruined, except perhaps a few sequences that might remind you too much of "Star Wars" though Burroughs wrote it like that anyway. Even the musical score is picture-perfect.Honestly, I do not know why these top-notch films (this is in the running for Oscars, mark my words) are ignored by the public. The TV teaser-trailers I saw were absolutely pathetic because Disney had no choice. One other thing: this film marks the record for being on somebody's shelf but never being made, until they started shooting in 2010. This had been in the works, in one company or another, since the mid-1930s. Can you believe it?Now it's been done great justice, and released on the 100th anniversary of its original appearance as a serial in 1912. Burroughs was so embarrassed by the whole thing he released it under a pseudonym. Yet it would become almost as popular as his other great creation, Tarzan. It was then Burroughs showed his true colors, and created more John Carter of Mars adventures.Don't miss this witty, hilarious family film that has a PG-13 rating purely for Taylor Kitsch's marvelous body and the time the camera spends on it. (No complaints from me.) For Goddess' sake, please don't miss this.With the talents of Samantha Morton, Thomas Haden Church, Dominic West, and heir apparent to Shia LaBeouf: Daryl Sabara as a young Edgar Rice Burroughs.

reviewText: Considering all the negative reviews, and the fact that Disney has cancelled plans for any sequels, I didn't have high expectations that this movie would be good, never mind just plain entertaining.  I was pleasantly surprised to discover that I liked it.  Which leaves me to wonder why so many took an instant dislike to it (mostly critics, although that can't explain why so many people didn't bother to see this movie on its initial theater release, thus sounding its death knell).  Yes, the story is a bit complicated (as it always is when people jump back and forth between time and space).  Yes, they could have picked a stronger actor for the lead.  Yes, they had way too many villains to keep track of.  Yes, it's not always a good thing to be cryptic about everything.  But still, the aliens were fantastic, the score was mighty, the special effects dazzling.  I'm definitely keeping it in my collection for future viewings.It was a good, but not great, movie.
