reviewText: As one of the internet's resident scribes on all things movie, I'll not be the first - nor certainly the last - to lambast the treatment JOHN CARTER received at the box office.  The short version of this sad history is that JOHN CARTER was the perfect popcorn flick that deserved better - better from fans, better from the studio who made the film, and (far, far) better from the critical community that mostly drubbed it a `disaster' for all the wrong reasons - and, hopefully, it will get better at some point because, arguably, there's no better inspiration for science fiction and fantasy than Edgar Rice Burroughs' 1917 novel that started the craze.Others have already gone to great lengths to dissect precisely how badly conceived was Walt Disney's marketing scheme for the picture, but, to be honest, I think the failings of the film to garner the success it deserved from the box office goes much deeper.  How do you take a book titled "A Princess of Mars" and, then, make a film that goes through so many name changes that it ends up with something as simple as JOHN CARTER?  Not even JOHN CARTER OF MARS, as it was briefly called by some executive who, at least, realized it might be worthwhile to reference Burroughs' original material?  I think a strong case could be made - and probably will be made in some astute article some day by a film scholar - that the property was put in the hands of folks who didn't quite know what to do with it.  Is it STAR WARS?  Is it CONAN, THE BARBARIAN?  Is it STAR TREK?In short, JOHN CARTER was based on the best example of pulp fiction available to all of mankind.  Burroughs' original classic served as an inspiration to not only the best writers in the science fiction & fantasy field, but it led folks like George Lucas and Steven Spielberg to want to make movies in their respective universes.  Burroughs' prose has even been cited as an inspiration to Carl Sagan and even astronaut Terrence Wilcutt.  While the question will remain for ages why the film wasn't as successful as it deserved to be, it stands to reason that the original creation will continue to inspire countless folks in the years ahead.Taylor Kitsch does an admirable job bringing the principle character of Carter to life on the silver screen, and the lovely Lynn Collins steals every young boy's heart as the princess herself, Dejah Thoris.  The film was heavily supported by special effects, as many of the inhabitants of Mars had to be mastered with CGI.  Willem Dafoe was the most noticeable voice talent as Tars Tarkas, while James Purefoy performed respectably as Kantos Kan.  The effects were all top-notch - though a handful of sequences appeared a bit too elementary for my tastes - and they were integrated fairly seamlessly with the live action.While much could be made about the ineffective marketing by Disney's usually stellar advertising staff, I tend to think that the confusion over the property itself - just who is this John Carter character? - really killed any momentum the picture could've achieved.  In fact, the film never tracked all the well in the lead-up to its release, and if that doesn't indicate some fault on the part of the advertisers then I don't know who to blame.  Clearly, Burroughs' creation has an audience.  Disney never quite tapped into it, and that's probably because no one involved in drafting a marketing plan was even familiar with the franchise.  Instead, they relied on the picture - which dabbled liberally in the adventures on Barsoom (aka Mars) - and they were undone as a consequence.Having read most of the first novel, I can say that the story that made it to the silver screen is a respectful adaptation, but it strayed from the source material like any adaption does.  There was so much more to these various tribes and cultures in the book that may've made for a greater plot - not to mention the depth of characters that were reduced to general devices instead of fully fleshed creations - and, audience attention span being what it is, I can understand why some folks may've struggled a bit to grasp it all.  The central good-versus-evil story could've used a bit more beefing up, but, at the end of the day, I can't help but wonder how much of it seemed a bit too much like `fluff' for kids (not that there's anything wrong with that!).Lastly, I thought the pacing of the film suffered a bit in the middle third of the picture.  There's a fair amount of set-up that occupies the first third, and, where most second acts build on the drama and mystery of these introductions, JOHN CARTER sort of struggled and groped around a bit to find the story it wanted to tell.  The third act is, mostly, a traditional adventure picture, and it works very well on that level ... but the uneven presentation of that second act may've helped stifle strong word-of-mouth from audience members mostly unfamiliar with the material.  I can remember thinking that, after I saw the film, the story as presented might worked better had it been expanded to either two or three films; the end result of this would've been to give storytellers more space to work with fleshing out the people, places, and history of Barsoom - much in the same way Peter Jackson did with THE LORD OF THE RINGS films - but, alas, it wasn't meant to be.With as much as Disney spent on JOHN CARTER, it'll always remain a bit of a mystery as to why the finished product wasn't as successful as it could've been.  I think we'll be debating it for the ages, but, in the meantime, there's absolutely nothing wrong with enjoying the film as is: a rip-roaring return to old school entertainment ... where men are men ... dogs are, well, big dogs ... and there's a princess and a bunch of rather obvious villains thrown into the mix.  While it only hints at the magic from the original STAR WARS trilogy, JOHN CARTER will hopefully continue to be discovered and rediscovered in the generations yet to experience it.STRONGLY RECOMMENDED.
summary: JOHN CARTER: Great Film, But Horribly Mismanaged Property

This beloved story is rich and well presented to the viewer.  The feature and extras are subtitled in English for the deaf.

reviewText: First of all, I agree with the majority of reviewers in that John Carter is nowhere as bad as many "professional" film critics alleged. Disney seemed to denigrate its own movie before it even came out. It's a shame it did, because John Carter is worth viewing if you like sci-fi/fantasy.I also give the filmmakers a lot of credit for keeping the story on Mars, as in the original Edgar Rice Burroughs book, and not changing it to another planet. The Martian landscape as a background works really well and makes for some beautiful imagery.That said, the plot is a bit convoluted. There's a lot of talk about a 9th ray and aliens changing history, but it seems largely inconsequential next to the more traditional and immediate plot of the hero recruiting natives to save the princess. John Carter himself is imprisoned about half a dozen times, each time for a few seconds or so, which ruins the tension and suspense of each imprisonment.The film also suffers from uneven pacing. Some parts move very quickly, while at other times my attention started to wander. Some of the highlights - including the stadium fight with the White Apes featured in much of the promotional material - end up being very short, whereas John Carter's initial leaps on Mars seemed to go on forever. I could see this being a much more popular film if Disney decides to do a special edition re-edit (which is unlikely, unfortunately).Overall, it's a pretty fun film, but flawed in some important ways. Worth renting once, but probably not worth buying.(Oh, and Lynn Collins as the Martian Princess Dejah is absolutely smoking and perfect in the role!)
summary: Beautiful movie, despite some plot flaws

reviewText: This movie bombed at the box office. Might as well get that out of the way at the beginning. It was a financial disaster. That, however, has very little to do with the movie itself. Put aside the stupid naming and the bizarre advertising choices. Lets look at the movie itself.The movie is actually remarkably faithful in tone to the book Princess of Mars even while changing some of the specifics. Instead of trying to update Edgar Rice Burroughs vision, it simply embraces it. And that's probably my favorite thing about it. The creatures and devices are fantastical and the scale of the cities is epic.There's also plenty of action. Sword fights, flying, jumping. It's all there. And the plot, while simplistic (it's a blockbuster) is easy enough to follow.It's the characters where things fall down. Outside of John Carter and Dejah Thoris have decent character arcs, but no one else gets developed at all.Strangely John Carter seems both too long and too short at the same time. At 2 hours 20 minutes the story drags at times, yet some aspects feel like they were never properly fleshed out.Personally I think I would have cut down the framing story to a minimum and used that time to build up the secondary characters a bit more.Overall then it's a fun movie, but ultimately not very memorable. The best I can say for it is that it did inspire me to add the Barsoom series to my reading list.
summary: Looks Great, But Weak On Character

reviewText: You know, the BD and DVD were just released today, and there are 300+ reviews. Folks, we're not just supposed to wax on about what we think of the movie - we're supposed to review the whole experience.So, here it is. The Disney film adaptation of John Carter of Mars. This is a film that was attempted in the past and the technology simply did not exist. My first encounter with the John Carter character was the 1970's Marvel comics (which I still have in storage thankfully). He was the strongest, fastest, and considered to be the best hero earth had to offer to Mars.Barsoom is simply amazing. Every small detail, right down to the punishment brands, was not put into the film because it looked cool - it was there because it made for a action packed motion picture designed to introduce this 100 year old character of literature to a new audience. So, some exceptions might have been made during production. Go read the books (Princess from Mars comes first) and then watch the film. Then make up your own mind. I simply loved it.This is one of those BD releases I wait for - amazing cinematography and editing along with... wait for it... a 7.1 DTS-HD, and it plays wonderfully though the right system and a great HD TV.As for the behind the scenes, we get a doggie bag filled with little but interesting featurettes: deleted scenes, bloopers, commentary, but nothing new.If you make claim to be a fan of pulp and classical sci-fi and you have an awareness of the character, I think you'll likely enjoy this fun romp across the expanse of Mars. No awareness of the character is needed, so any genre fan would do well to check this out.>>> This review is brought to by a person that actually watched everything in the BD release and not from someone who just waxes on about the theatrical presentation of the film. /rant  <<<

reviewText: John Carter was on my radar due to a lot of the negative buzz regarding the marketing of the film. Interestingly, that never happend, but what did start happening was I became more and more engrossed in a different world filled with fully realized cultures and characters. I enjoyed the movie so much, that I've been reading Edgar Rice Burroughs Mars Trilogy.  I highly recommend this movie.

reviewText: Having devoured a lot of Edgar Rice Burroughs' pulp fiction as a boy in the early sixties, I have always been amazed at how little of the sense of adventure that permeated his writing ever came out in his various screen adaptations.  Some were good films in their own right (the first couple of Weismueler Tarzans, the last couple of Scott Tarzans, and even Lambert's jungle man of later years), but were simply not Burroughs.  Moreover, the exotic settings on Mars, Venus, etc. were mostly avoided due to their effects requirements (the one Pellucidar film, "At the Earth's Core," being below average at best).  So, I was quite interested in checking out "John Carter," which was tackling perhaps the most effects-heavy of Burroughs' series as well as his best (in my opinion).  After reading some reviews (a few positive, most mixed, and a couple of, frankly, snarky and unworthy efforts aimed at defaming the film's director), I caught "John Carter" in 2-D with my wife.  We were both very impressed.  It's beautiful, exciting, and a real tribute to how modern technology and a good feel for the subject matter by the film-makers can create a masterpiece!  Moreover, I felt that I was finally seeing and experiencing the Burroughs I had read.I went back to see this movie again in 3D (which didn't add a thing, indeed, I though it was actually better in 2D) and enjoyed it even more the second time around.  It's sad to think that there will probably not be sequels due to the poor box office (for whatever reason, but certainly not the film's exceedingly high quality).  I would have loved seeing the original trilogy done to this level of excellence, with a series carried on to at least "The Chessmen of Mars," the fifth of Burroughs' Martian books and, for my money, the best thing that he ever wrote.  I can only compare what is happening to "John Carter" to what took place long ago with regard to "The Wizard of OZ."  That was the most expensive film that MGM had ever made and a big box office flop, which doomed the many wonderful sequels that Baum's great book series might have spawned.  MGM eventually recouped its investment through re-releases (not available today, though perhaps the DVD/cable markets are somewhat akin) and the film went on to become the beloved classic that it is now almost universally considered to be.  I can only hope that "John Carter" will see a similar future of proper honors.  If so, though not the financial boon to its makers that it should have been, it will at least give them the recognition they richly deserve for creating a true masterwork.  I know that its DVD incarnation will always have a treasured place in my own extensive film library.
summary: Finally, a Buroughs Film Adaptation Done Right!

reviewText: My wife and I watched "John Carter" and "Hunger Games" in the theater the same day.  I had read the Barsoom series in high school in the 1960s, and she was nearly through the "Hunger Games" books. We both liked "John Carter" better as a movie, and chose to go watch it again as soon as we could.  There are differences from the book -- the Therns in particular right off, but I consider that an acceptable "update" in view of what we have come to expect of sci-fi since 1917. The CGI creatures were great! Very believable. The Green barbarians don't look like Frazetta's; they look much better. I did not expect the humor, but it was fun and in the right amounts in the right places. The Martians wear more clothes than in the books, but hey, it's Disney; it doesn't hurt the story. We also loved the Art Nouveau flavor of the Martian architecture, tatoos, armor, etc. The palace in Helium was stunningly beautiful.No, Carter here does not come off as charismatic as, say, Brad Pitt's Achilles, but he's a lonely, depressed Civil War vet who's lost his family in a particularly tragic way, and a man of action, not of philosophical words and exquisite sensibilities.  It works for me just fine.  I also enjoyed Ms. Collins as a capable, intelligent woman, who doesn't overdo it as if she had a feminist revenge chip on her shoulder: her Martian princess is confident in who she is and is "at home in her skin," as some say. Beautiful, over-acting women with lots of attiude but no athletic skill to go with it can be really annoying and ruin an action movie, but Collins shows how it should be done. Other supporting actors (including some familiar, competent Brit faces) are also reliably "on key."We don't have a 3D tech TV, or I'd get the 3D.  This was the first movie I tried to watch in 3D and actually enjoyed it that way, but without 3D the colors are more vibrant, so both are good. I sure hope the word gets out so it is eventually successful enough to make a sequel. And somebody better make a decent video game, too!
summary: Damn the Pro Reviewers!  We loved it!

reviewText: I will be upfront in saying that John Carter is not the best Disney movie I have seen.  But if you like your movies with tons of action, where your senses are on total overload throughout the entire duration, then John Carter is for you.John Carter is based on a series of old novels by Edgar Rice Burroughs which tells the story of Confederate war military caption John Carter (played by Taylor Kitsch) who by happenstance, goes on an adventure that it truly out of this world.In the story, Captain John Carter is a honorable man who has dedicated this military career to helping to protect western settlers.  But he ends up losing his compassion after tragic events happen in his life.  Now disillusioned, he vows to help no one.  But in his quest to find gold, he discovers a medallion that takes him from Earth to Mars (also called Barssom) where another war is going on between two cultures - the Zodangans and the Helimites.  The Zodangans plan to wipe out the Helimites with the help of a strange blue power given to them by Martai Shang (played by Mark Strong), the King of an advance race of people called the Therns.  The Therns can change apperance at anytime and blend into any culture to alter the course of events as they see fit.Carter is initially captured by a group of four armed, green creatures called Tharks who are just waiting for the Zodangans and the Helmites to kill off each other off so that the Tharks can take over Mars.  To end the war, the Helimite princess Dejah Thoris (played by Lynn Collins) has been pledged in marriage to Sab Than (played by Dominic West), the evil king of the Zodangans.  But Dejah runs away to save herself from a loveless marriage and ends up meeting John Carter.  Carter finds that by helping Princess Dejah, he can heal himself from the past and maybe find a new life on Barssom (Mars).The main problem you will find with John Carter is that there are so many characters, and storylines, and cultures, and languages, and plot twists and turns in the movie that it is all a little too much for the audience.  It's like a wild 3D video game where the audience is on complete overload for two full hours trying to figure out what is going on while enjoying all the 3D effects.  This movie may have a complex storyline because Disney is staying true to the original books. Since I have not read any of the stories, I am not sure this is the case.But despite the complexity, John Carter is a spectacular movie to watch.  The 3D was beautiful and the fight scenes are grand and thrilling.  My son was engaged for the entire two hours - there is no way that anyone will be bored while watching this movie. Most of the movie is computer generated graphics that show a make believe Mars (Barssom) that is visually wonderful to watch containing complex flying machines, intricate cities in the sky, and epic battles.And the movie does not take itself too seriously. There are moments where John Carter does things (like learning to walk on Mars in zero gravity or going to the wrong city when he attempts to save the princess) that make the audience burst out laughing.  And there are so many fight scenes in the movie that at one point even Carter makes a joke out of fighting yet another epic battle.For parents, even though John Carter is a Disney movie, it is rated PG-13 for a good reason. There is plenty of cursing in the first 30 minutes of the movie. And the movie is full of violence from beginning to end.  If your children are use to viewing video game violence, then they should be fine with seeing John Carter.  But just a warning that there was one scene involving a branding iron that was particularly hard to watch.My son totally enjoyed this movie, even though the end was so complex, he (and a lot of other people in the audience) were scratching their heads trying to understand it all.  The way the movie ends, a sequel to John Carter will probably be in theaters in the near future.John Carter is rated PG-13 and opens in theaters TODAY, Friday, March 9th.  If you are going to see it, please pay the extra money to see it in 3D.  It is totally worth it.
summary: John Carter is a spectacular movie to watch.  The 3D is beautiful and the fight scenes are grand and thrilling....

reviewText: As a long time fan of Edgar Rice Burroughs and especially his Martian series of books beginning with "A Princess of Mars" I was thrilled to see this movie finally happen, with the special effects technology needed to bring ERB's imagination successfully to the screen.  I think Burroughs would be greatly pleased with this production.  If you love science fiction adventure on a grand scale, you should love this one.  Yes, some film-makers after Burroughs' time "copied" many of his concepts and stole his thunder, but this is the original story that inspired them all and is well worth seeing on its own merits.  Definitely 5-stars in my book!

reviewText: In "John Carter" we meet characters and themes which marked the birth of modern science fiction and inspired both scientists (such as Carl Sagan) and writers (Clarke, Bradbury, and countless others) in the century which followed the original publication of Edgar Rice Burroughs' novels.  Disney's treatment doesn't slavishly parrot the novels, and includes material from more than one of them, but is as true to the original as the images in the minds of most of the millions of readers who have enjoyed these stories since their first publication (as "Under the Moons of Mars") in 1912.There's a sharp irony in the fact that Disney, the epitome of the Hollywood Establishment, was so badly burned by the Hollywood Establishment when almost universally bad reviews (and that can be read both ways) kept moviegoers away from what may be the finest Disney release in years.  If you're a fan -- and why else would you be reading this page? -- consider your purchase of this DVD a vote, perhaps not for Disney but for Barsoom, for Burroughs, for the classics of science fiction, and for those who invested so much time, effort and money in this film and might be persuaded to continue the "John Carter" series of films in the future.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Disney Blu-rays are generally top notch in the transfer of quality, and this remains true for John Carter. Visually, this movie is truly stunning. The CGI and special effects are fantastic, and the various alien critters look really cool. It's true that the creature design is also a bit on the goofy side, but it works really well with the style of the movie. The locations that were chosen to film were excellent, and greatly resemble what I would imagine the red landscapes of Mars to look like.In terms of story, John Carter is very entertaining. I never read the novel ("A Princess of Mars"), so I can't say how true it is to the original source, but I liked the background for the protagonist. It's a very cool take to have him from the civil war era, and his background is fleshed out perfectly for the (very strange) task at hand. His experience with resiliency, combat, and surviving in vastly different cultures suits his unintended expedition on Mars perfectly. Furthermore, it's a clever trick to explain his rather remarkable abilities on Mars (super strength and crazy jumping) as a result of the difference in gravitational forces on Earth and Mars.Unfortunately, the pace does start to get bogged down in the middle of the movie, which seems to happen far too often in the "epic movie" genre. But not to worry, it's not long before things pick up again, and John Carter finishes on a high note.
summary: A visual, pulse pounding treat for Star Wars fans

reviewText: Only Disney could take the works of one of the greatest fantasy writers of the 20th century, Edgar Rice Burroughs, and screw it up so badly as to make it almost unrecognizable. The first mistake was casting "unknown" actors in all of the key roles. Who wants to pay big bucks at the theater to watch a "major" motion picture that does not have any "major" stars in it? There were 11 books in The Martian Tales of Edgar Rice Burroughs. The second mistake was taking bits and pieces from 4 of the books and trying to make it into 1 movie and then coming up with an ending that Burroughs never wrote in any of the books. Now, the scenery, action, costumes, special effects were all amazing; that's the only thing Disney got right in this movie. In my opinion what Disney should have done was take the sets, props, locations, etc.. and make a "made for TV" series out of the 11 books. They could have easily done 22 or 23 episodes and had 1 or 2 seasons of The Martian Tales. Don't waste your time or money on this Blu-ray/DVD set if you have never read The Martian Tales, and if you have read the books, be prepared to be disappointed.
summary: Another Disney failure, but not because of the material..

reviewText: I am obviously in the minority on this one. I watched Blu-Ray version of John Carter last night. I was so disappointed. My first mistake was to pull out my copy of 'A Princess of Mars' when I saw the ads for the movie. I don't know how many times I have read this book but the first time was as a teenager. So I am watching the movie with a favorite book fresh in my mind.I recognize the melding of two books in the series. What I fail to see is why. It is as if the director had only read the Cliff Notes versions of the two books. Also he and the production designer had never seen the Frank Frazetta drawings that set the imagery of Mars for so many generations.In casting, the actor who played Carter did not come close in appearance or stature. Deja Thoris, was okay but only okay.Costume design; I realize they couldn't use the Frazetta drawings as a start and get a PG-13 rating, they probably couldn't get a 'R', but really. What pops into my mind is a lighter version of the costumes from 'Dune'.CGI design; who in their minds say the Tharks as skinny. Or equates tusks with demented cow horns. The flying machines were acceptable. I can see how the designers would arrive at that from Burroughs' descriptions. They were far more visually complicated for flying machines than believable. More similar to making a clipper ship fly.I really looked forward to this movie. Wife and son otherwise occupied so I wouldn't be interrupted, popcorn ready, surround sound on. I guess I set myself up for disappointment.To end on a positive note, the Disney Blu-ray disc performed flawlessly. My recommendation to Disney; if this is to be a franchise, start over.
summary: The director never read the book

reviewText: By now most everyone knows that Disney's John Carter, after a long history of on-again, off again adaptation to the big screen that spans almost as many years as the stories themselves, was pummeled at the box office. However, as some correctly predicted, it was a big hit overseas -- and premiered at #1 on Blu-ray and DVD last week.One must wonder how many formed their opinions about the film based on the widely reported lack of ticket sales. There has been lots of finger pointing for the losses, but perhaps the fault wasn't the film so much as with the timing. Did theater audiences want another scifi-fantasy epic franchise? Who knows?John Carter is not a perfect film, but it is very far from a catastrophe. Visually, the stunning imagery, especially on Blu-ray, cannot be denied. The years of work and the big budget shows on screen. Meticulous details abound that make the film very rewatchable. I was struck by the clear glass in the air ships -- it was uneven, as if the glass was hand-made. The look combined high tech with the 19th century (which did remind my wife of Treasure Planet, another very good Disney feature that fizzled in theaters).The film's shortcomings are so well-documented, you don't need me to recount them. On the positive side, there is some humor, especially the "Virginia" running gag. One of the best characters in the film is James Purefoy as Kantos Kan (yes, it's hard to keep track of the names and I had to look it up), who amusingly forces his own capture in a climactic battle scene.The toughest roles are the leads, and Taylor Kitsch fares no better than the more well-known Jake Gyllenhaal in Prince of Persia. Neither actor can be held totally responsible when they're shouldering such a massive movie. The princess role, which proved problematic to the filmmakers, who had trouble reconciling her 100-year old persona with contemporary expectations, is handled with deft skill by Lynn Collins.The film has some great shape-shifting villains offering lots of potential for future adaptations. There is also a fascinating parallel narrative centering on Edgar Rice Burroughs as a character in the 19th century, learning the secrets of Carter as he unknowingly dodges the bad guys (I would have liked to have seen more of this story thread).The point is, John Carter is a rousing spectacle that is a must-see for action, scifi, fantasy and adventure movies in the Spielberg/Lucas style. Whether we'll ever see more of this world, in perhaps an animated TV version, is certainly unlikely from where the property stands today.But the same could have been said for Tron and Newsies. Just by reading the many amazon reviews, a lot of passionate fans are already championing the movie. Maybe more time will tell...
summary: Was it really such a misfire? You be the judge!

reviewText: I first read "A Princess of Mars" before I was 10, well over fifty years ago, and I was immediately hooked on Burroughs although, strangely enough, I never got into the Tarzan stories. It didn't take me long to acquire my first set of the ERB Mars novels and I've read them over and over and over and . . .  The prize of my 800 or so volume collection of fantasy, horror and SF books is a set of the ERB Mars novels with the Frank Frazetta dust covers. I waited all these years for someone to make a passable movie of the John Carter saga and that's what this one is - a passable presentation of the Carter saga.  Why someone feels determined to rewrite the classic Burroughs story is completely beyond me. The original in all its grandeur is pretty much beyond surpassing but the screenwriter (as almost every modern screenwriter does) feels they can improve an original that has withstood almost one hundred years of readers.  Here's what I thought was good and not so good -The opening scenery with its introduction to John Carter was pretty well done.  Although it didn't strictly follow ERB's script, it was close enough for the viewer to get the same idea as to where John Carter came from. The opening scenes with the Tharks were really well done although I've always pictured the Tharks as a little beefier. The dead sea bottoms and the deserted cities were exceptionally well done and the presentation of Woola was priceless - brought tears to my jaundiced eye.  Those who never read the John Carter stories can't recognize that the meeting of John Carter and Woola is every bit as portentious as the first meeting of Spock and Kirk, Holmes and Watson, Morse and Lewis, and even Tarzan and Jane.  As a rule the scene was very well set in the beginning.But then we depart from Burroughs' original plot line and the story starts to lose its original coherence.  The Therns appear out of nowhere with very little introduction of what their place is in Martian society. Tardos Mors and Mors Kajak were given just enough screen time for the non-afficianado to wonder just who they were. The atmosphere plant scenes were pretty much left out - interestingly enough, these were about the only passable scenes in an otherwise disaster of a predecessor production. Whine, whine, whine.The really sad part of this whole thing is that from such a promising first hour or so, the movie died when they left the original story plot.  If they had just stuck with Burroughs' original, they could have stretched this into three or four really block-buster movies (as was done with the Lord of the Rings trilogy recently).  As for poor, pitiful me (and all the other original John Carter fans) we'll have to wait another ten to twenty years (if we live that long) to see if someone attempts to bring this truly classic story out of the rubble that it's now in and do it right.  I gave it four stars mostly because it's the best attempt yet at telling Burroughs' story and I think I'm rating the original novels more than the movie.

reviewText: I didn't go see this film in a theater, because I dreaded what Hollywood, and particularly Disney, would do to a beloved favorite book. Later, the DVD became available at a reasonable price so, with some trepidation, I ordered it. Imagine my joy and satisfaction at what a massive labor of love this movie turned out to be. I'm no big fan of CGI effects, but as I watched this miraculous film, I realized that it couldn't have been done until now. Incredible affects aside, the screenwriters gave enough attention to character development to make you actually care for the principles involved. I think in time, despite the apparent lack of financial success this movie has had, it will gain a following and become a beloved treasure like another superb Disney effort that comes to mind, The Rocketeer.

reviewText: The CGI, props and sets carry the movie. The script although based on the fantastic stories of ERB is what holds this movie back. By analogy would you buy a 30 year old computer and be entertained by it's functions? No. The book and it's predecessors were based on a subject that we didn't know much about at that time and for an audience that had knowledge of the subject area that a 10 year old would now laugh at. The dialogue especially seemed too dated and Hollywood dumb speak like. The rest of the script when compared to scifi, fantasy and other futuristic films that have come out these past two decades also seemed old and dated. A movie and it's inspirational book are two different mediums - it's OK to allow the movie to be scripted as a separate identity yet still pay homage to it's text inspiration. Know and write for the audience.
summary: Book & Movie Should be Different Entities

reviewText: Note: I saw this movie in 3-D via XFinity On Demand.Based on a series of books by the writer of Tarzan, John Carter is a fairly good action-adventure-science fiction film. The acting is solid, especially from usual villain Willem Dafoe playing against type, like he did to wonderful effect in the Oliver Stone classic war film PLATOON. The storyline is engaging enough, and the visuals are very impressive, especially in 3-D. The music is also quite good. So, why the three stars?Walt Disney Pictures has always been a family-friendly company, and while some of their latest PG & PG-13-rated films include mild-to-moderate profanity, they HAD NEVER, EVER, EVER combined the Name of God with a mild curse word, thereby taking His Name in vain...until now. WHY???!!! Why did you have to screw up in this regard, Disney? God saith in His Holy Word, "Thou shalt not take the Name of the Lord thy God in vain; for the Lord will not hold him guiltless that taketh His Name in vain." AND WHAT WAS IT WITH THE STREAM OF URINE?!!! That visual, while avoiding nudity, was very, very, very crude and unneccessary. I am so disappointed in Walt Disney Pictures for producing a movie with these two elements in it, two horrible firsts for a company founded in the 1920's on solid family-friendly entertainment. This is my main beef with the film.Such a pity that we might never see a sequel or sequels to this movie due to it being a box-office bomb. And you might want to keep young children away from this film due to the strong religious profanity and the disgusting visual I mentioned that occurs early in the film.Walter Elias Disney would be ashamed that the company he founded made a movie that includes a religious profanity and a nauseating, though brief, visual of a man urinating.
summary: John Carter Of Earth. Looks Like Another Fam-WHAT?!!! A Religious Profanity?!!! URINE?!!! WHAT HAPPENED, WALT DISNEY PICTURES?!!

reviewText: I waited to review this movie. I have now seen it twice on DVD- giving it a good 4 weeks before watching it again.  And I have the perspective of having read at least 5 of the Barsoom books when I was a kid. And that is where I would like to start. Movies can never contain everything that was in a book- it is absolutely necessary to strip away the non-essential detail in order to preserve the spirit of the story- and sometimes details must adjust to fit what works in the movies.  The question becomes this: does the movie capture the spirit of the original story?  And the answer here is: Absolutely- in fact I have never seen it done better. I have seldom seen it done as well.  The critics were wrong- the script was very well done, the special effects excellent and the casting was superb.Lynn Collins was absolutely a perfect Dejah Thoris- I remember even when I first saw her in the movie "They got this exactly right".So why did this movie not do better? Some blame bad marketting, others just say that it was an anachronism- we no longer really relate to a story that was published almost a century ago. That we have changed too much.  I am going to suggest that the second group are closer to the mark than the first.  I would like to suggest that there is a natural ebb and flow in the things which we treasure.  Right now the ideals and images in The Princess of Mars (John Carter of Mars) do not appeal to most of us.  10 years from now we may very well feel very differently. In fact, 10 years from now we may be berating Disney for not having made more of the Barsoom stories into films.Not every great treasured classic was a box office smash- take Jimmy Stewart's "Its a Wonderful Life" for instance.
summary: We were not quite ready for this great story

reviewText: I'll tell you that Edgar Rice Burroughs was one of my childhood linchpins. He, more than anyone else, instilled in me a love for pulp adventure. And not to play favorites (except I guess I'm gonna) but as much as I relished Lord Greystoke, I'd always preferred Captain John Carter by a hair. It never seemed fair that while Tarzan had garnered so many film adaptations, this swashbuckling Virginian never even got close to a whiff. Until now.JOHN CARTER is admittedly a nebulous film title; I hear you can blame the failure of MARS NEEDS MOMS for Disney's push to disassociate the ERB project from the "Mars" label. JOHN CARTER is based (somewhat faithfully) on A PRINCESS OF MARS, the first in Burroughs' eleven volume Barsoom series, with bits from the second volume, THE GODS OF MARS, also peppered in. It's crazy that Burroughs published A PRINCESS OF MARS in serialized form a century ago. But there's a timelessness to John Carter's wild exploits. Gratifyingly, a planetary romance from 1912 still has legs in 2012. No matter the era, it's awesome escapism, a grand adventure. And as an ERB devotee, I can't help but grin big because, just as in the book, Burroughs himself (nicely played by SPY KIDS' Daryl Sabara) bookends the story.JOHN CARTER is Andrew Stanton's debut with directing live-action films, and I think he brings just enough of that heart and that Pixar sensibility that he'd invested in FINDING NEMO and WALL-E, although, no, JOHN CARTER won't be regarded as a classic on the same tier as those two animated gems. But there's a humanity in the story, and dazzling visuals, and unexpected humor. I love the running gag about John Carter's name.***possibly some minor SPOILERS now***The cinematic version of John Carter has been tweaked some. Unlike the gent in the books (who always had his shucks together), the John Carter we view onscreen has baggage. A devastating personal loss has rendered the former Captain of the 1st Virginian Cavalry a shell of his former self. In the untamed Arizona badlands, this Carter is a man without a cause. He only cares about amassing gold. He vigorously rejects the government's "request" for his services as an experienced military man, even though he is told by a gristled army colonel that "Son, we are up to our chin straps in Apaches." In 1868 Carter's headlong flight from a U.S. cavalry troop leads him to a haunted cave. Moments later, in that cave, a mysterious device catapults him to another world wherein, once again, his services as a fighting man would be required.Let me backtrack a bit, though. I have to mention a sequence on Earth in which Carter, captured by the U.S. Army, persists in one break-out attempt after another. While this is largely played for laughs, this sequence embodies the make-up of Burroughs' heroes. John Carter, Tarzan, Carson of Venus, and others all demonstrate that never-give-up demeanor. I'm so happy they put this sequence in. And it was pretty funny.There's another fun segment soon after he lands On Mars (or "Barsoom") in which John Carter learns of the enhanced abilities bestowed him by the planet's lower gravity. Even more than his sudden colossal strength, it's Carter's newfound ability to leap prodigiously that captured my imagination as a kid. There were three things I was anxious to see going into this film, and the film has visualized them marvelously. There's the geek-out thrill of finally seeing the incomparable Dejah Thoris fleshed out. There are the 12-foot-tall Tharks convincingly brought to life. And there are John Carter's astounding leaps. That's levitation, homes. I guess you could throw in the awesome monster dog, Woola, as well.On the barren, war-ravaged wastelands of Barsoom, a Thark's curiousity saves John Carter. Tharks, like most of the planet's indigenous lifeforms, are six-limbed creatures. Tharks are tusked, green-skinned barbarians noted for their savagery and contempt for weakness. Carter is captured by Tharks, his life spared by Tars Tarkas (voiced by Willem Dafoe), a Jeddak (king or leader) who secretly nurses a bump of compassion. Tars Tarkas is like a delighted little kid, wanting to show off Carter's sensational leaps. And you can't blame Tars Tarkas. There's just something joyous in Carter's defiance of gravity. It buys Carter some time.The film's neat retro sci-fi vibe surfaces early on when the narrative introduces the war between the invading forces of the Zodanga empire and the beleaguered city of Helium, touted as the last bastion of a free Barsoom. I soaked in the wonderful set designs and those wicked cool airships. And, somewhere hereabouts, we meet Dejah Thoris. Wonderfully portrayed by Lynn Collins, Dejah Thoris is presented as a fierce warrior-scientist of Helium, as well as its beloved princess. Except that, rather than wed Sab Than (Dominic West), leader of the encroaching Zodanga army, Dejah Thoris runs away.I guess I could roll with the changes the filmmakers made. It's not astral projection but, rather, an ornament of either magical nature or super-science which hurls Carter to Barsoom. Matai Shang (Mark Strong), who doesn't appear until THE GODS OF MARS, does have presence as the overarcing big bad. The film makes him and his fellow Therns more as immortal, shape-shifting interplanetary manipulators than Barsoom's more localized secret rulers. It'll take more than fancy jumping to foil Matai Shang's machinations. It'll probably take a trilogy of movies.My friend, who hadn't ever read ERB, thought the film just so-so. He remarked that it was full of plot cliches culled from other movies like STAR WARS and AVATAR and such. I had to smack him upside the head and tell him that A PRINCESS OF MARS came out way before those movies. To me, JOHN CARTER is a welcome throwback, a good old-fashioned pulp adventure featuring a hero who, for a change, isn't dark or gritty or cynical (okay, Carter starts out a bit cynical). While Taylor Kitsch doesn't quite capture John Carter's gravitas and inherent nobility, he's sold me with what he brings to the table, a terrific physicality and just enough dramatic weight. Lynn Collins, to me, is more of a revelation. I love her interpretation of Dejah Thoris, the resolve she infuses in her role. I love her looks which are exotic enough that I believed she was an otherworldy princess. That Collins is a black belt in Shito-ryu karate makes her that much hotter. That right there should make her a match for a fighting Virginian battling his way across the breadth of the red planet. Somewhere along the way, inter mundos, John Carter had found a cause.

reviewText: I first learned of John Carter from the Comic Books back in the 70's then later in the mid 80's I was privileged enough to read the original series from... now get this...... the original books published so long ago from a friend of the family who was a collector.I am as guilty as anyone of using Kindle for my books now but I have to say those old books the way they smelled the tactile sensation of holding those old beloved treasures really does something to make you remember a story and hold it precious in your memory.Now here we are all these years later in 2012 can you believe it and our technology has advanced to the point where they can properly make a movie of one of my all time favorite characters. Yes they did change elements of the story but not to the point where they have harmed the original in any way that matters. In fact they may very well have improved on it. It has been many years I will have to read the stories again.I just watched this in3D with my wife at home and we both wound up clapping like little kids at the finish the same as we did in the theatre in 2D the first time around. If this does not say how we feel about this movie nothing ever will.I never go to 3D movies in the theatre because the quality of the the theaters equipment around our area is so poor.I do buy 3D movies on Blue Ray here on Amazon though because they are so good on our home equipment.Lol I use a PS3 as my 3d Blue ray player the latest slim models are dead quiet and with the PS3 remote are better players than many dedicated players. Ahemm hello Samsung 3d blue ray player junk.... that was a bundled item to buy my T.V.Anyway the movie is very well done not one character is poorly portrayed and if you have a history of reading the books or comics don't worry this will not let you down.
summary: A favorite Story from long ago

reviewText: Biggest bomb in this entire film is the one dropped by the advertising department at Disney studios. They simply did not know how to market the film. The title is a big mistake. Should've been called "Warrior of Mars" or "Journey to Barsoom" or something that grabbed your imagination. Too bad. This is a fun, entertaining movie that  could have (and truthfully should have) been the start of a franchise IF had it been handled better. What a waste. Lots of talent on hand and the story is good, even if it's a familiar one. I thought that Taylor Kitsch was pretty good in the lead. The action and effects certainly were eye-popping. I think this movie will go on to be one of those that finds its legs (and audience) in the DVD/Bluray crowd instead of the theater crowd. Too bad for Disney that it won't make enough difference at that point money-wise to warrant a sequel(s).As expected for a new film on Blu-ray, the audio & video look & sound great. No complaints and the disc includes a DVD version of the movie as well. Extras include a director's commentary, deleted scenes, a blooper reel and lots more. A nice package of goodies to go with an entertaining main feature. 4 stars.
summary: fun film, unfairly slammed upon initial theatrical release

reviewText: Edgar Rice Burroughs, best known for his Tarzan books, produced one of the early science fiction series in his stories of Civil War veteran John Carter's adventures on Mars. Those familiar with Burroughs' original stories will get an extra kick out of this movie, which brings to life fairly faithfully the Tharks, nine-foot-tall warriors with four arms who find themselves caught in the middle of a perpetual war between the city-states of Zodanga and Helium; the human-like residents of those cities; and the variety of exotic creatures that provide transport, entertainment in the combat arena, and even companionship.Burroughs' tales were cutting-edge science fiction nearly a hundred years ago, based on a Mars craze ignited by wealthy amateur astronomer Percival Lowell and his vision of a canal-crossed Martian landscape which he convinced himself he could see through his telescope in Flagstaff, Arizona, a telescope which he had custom built for his purpose of studying Mars.  Although somewhat quaint by today's standards, Burroughs' luridly illustrated stories were influential for many years in stimulating the imaginations of youthful readers.  Among them was a Brooklyn boy who stood in a vacant lot staring at what he thought was Mars, fervently wishing to be transported telepathically to "Barsoom", Burroughs' name for the Red Planet.  This young boy was Carl Sagan, who grew up to be a famous astronomer, and a master of popularizing astronomy for the masses.Attempts at putting Barsoom on film had always foundered due to the impossibility of adequately depicting the characters and the physical environment of the Mars stories. Now, with CG animation and Blu-ray high definition anything is possible, and Disney has done a great job of creating a realistic environment for Burroughs' vision of Mars. If this film had been made ten or even five years ago it would have been a sensation, but now the movie-going public is sated with spectacular CG films. Nonetheless, John Carter provides a lavish and moving account of the exploits of one of the earliest heroes of science fiction. It is well worth a visit to the arid landscapes of Barsoom to experience the imagination of Edgar Rice Burroughs.
summary: John Carter - Modernizing an Old Sci-fi Classic

reviewText: Overall I thought this movie was very well done.  The only problem I could see was the story line itself was dated, knowing what we know about Mars and space.  The screenplay should have been modified to make it more believable.  They could have used a totally fictional planet and in that way open up any possibility.  John Carter himself was inconsistent with his abilities throughout the movie.  He could leap astounding distances and swing huge boulders around, but when fighting one of the natives he seemed weak.  His unique abilities didn't jive with what was going on around him.  The bottom line is that the story taken as a whole was good, the special effects were fantastic, and in the end I did care about the main characters.
summary: The Problem Is The Story Line

reviewText: Why did mainstream Hollywood media try to sink this picture? True, Disney did a terrible job at promoting it, but all I heard about John Carter was negative, that it was a big flop, a joke.  Not so!  This film will live on as a science fiction cult classic in my opinion, a nice shelf-worthy DVD for any true Sci-Fi collector.But you have to put this picture in its proper historical context and understand that these stories were primarily intended for young people, not adults. Most of these so-called "reviewers" failed to understand that, they reviewed this thing as if it were just another big-budget sci-fi extravaganza like Star Trek or Star Wars when, in fact, it was closer to Harry Potter or Lord of the Rings.Awesome CGI, lots of action. Scripting seemed awkward at times but they probably were trying to stay true to the original text of the book. The beginning was rushed a bit and you have to pay close attention to the narration to understand the set-up.Hard-to-read subtitles were used in early scenes with Martian creatures called Tharks. Thankfully, Carter drinks some kind of elixir that allows him to understand their language and the awkward subtitles were no longer needed.The movie is based on a good example of early pre-1930's classic science fiction.  I know many reviewers balked at the some of the silly contrivances and gadgets shown in the movie, but it was true to much of science as it was known in Edgar Rice Burrough's  time (early 1900's); imagine how dumb Star Trek or Stargate Atlantis will look 100 yrs. from now.Another point: Many of Burrough's stories were targeted towards older children and young adults; science fiction and fantasy were not considered "proper" literature in those days, but was enjoyed by millions of bored kids as good escapist summer-time reading; there was no TV in those days, radio was still in its infancy as was the motion picture industry.  Reading and stage theater were about the only forms of popular entertainment available.Never the less, I think it would have been better to retell this story in a more modern setting.  Instead of Mars, pick one of the recently-discovered planets in a another solar system; update some of the technological references and replace the hokey teleportation amulet with something more in-keeping with known physics. You can do all this an still be faithful to the original story just as we are still faithful to Shakespeare via some 250 modern films based on his plays (like West Side Story or Forbidden Planet).

reviewText: Well, just got back from seeing the film.  Wow, I was impressed, I guess when you spend $250 MILLION dollars, you better get your bang for the buck, and Disney really does here!  I loved the books as a lad, and to see the world come to life was pretty darn cool.  I'm getting to be an old fogey (45), and I find myself mostly scoffing at the "look at us we can make ANY effect we want with CGI go crazy" movies.  But, I got into it here.  As a popcorn movie, this is right up there with all the other over the top super budget, super special effects laden extravaganzas, so you know what you're getting into before you see it, hey, this is a review right?  I will buy this on DVD, and I guess my overriding feeling after just seeing this, is that they have brought to life Edgar Rice Burroughs book, and they have made a tribute to his wonderful imagination.  What a storyteller he was, just how he came up with this stuff is beyond me, but his books brought a lot of enjoyment to me once upon a time, and now, the film did the same, cheers.  Here's hoping that it makes back enough money, maybe even enough to try another film, by the way, really agreed with the "official" review that the guy did on this.

reviewText: Call me a cynic but over the years when I see a movie being made based on a book I like I expect the movie to be bad or at best mediocre. So it was with a sense of dread that I began to watch the Disney movie "John Carter" based on Edgar Rice Burrough's "A Princess of Mars." I guess you could say I was not too unhappy about the results even though quite a few things were changed in the movie and some of the major characters in the book were either removed or made into minor characters. "John Carter" doesn't reach the level of "Bladerunner" the movie based on Philip K. Dick's "Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?" but it doesn't fall to the depths of the 1984 "Dune" movie. Also I noticed that they wrote young Edgar in the movie just as a young Rudyard Kipling was written into "The Man Who Would be King" movie and it gave it a more human face to what was a huge budget CGI movie and I kinda liked that so I give it three stars because it's OK and if I could I'd give it three and a half because I sorta like it. I would hope that those people who saw the movie but haven't read ERB's books would take the time to read one. They are still good reads after almost a century in print.
summary: Not a great movie but good entertainment...

reviewText: It might surprise many people to find that many of our most revered adventure films hearken back to the era of the pulps for inspiration; the most glaring (and possibly best) example of that of course being the INDIANA JONES films. But there's also some brand-recognition that's at work at times to, more specifically with the recent (and amazingly awful) reboot of CONAN THE BARBARIAN. When director Andrew Stanton, director of two of the most beloved films in recent years (the beautiful FINDING NEMO and the Kubrick-with-a-heart genius of WALL-E, which I consider to be the best animated film ever made), decided to make his first jump into live-action films, he also looked back to the pulps. In this instance, he looked to the works of Edgar Rice Burroughs, the creator of Tarzan, and less-famously, the tale of a Confederate Civil War soldier thrust onto the Red Planet as originally told in the book "The Princess of Mars". While the film itself surrounds the adventures of the titular character, the real star of JOHN CARTER is Stanton and the deftness and joy that he tells this tale which, aside from a few missteps and some less-than-stellar characterization, is a rousing pulp sci-fi adventure extravaganza with some of the most eye-poppingly amazing visuals of a film since AVATAR.This film has a cast that is to die for... aside from its star. You have Lynn Collins as Dejah Thoris (The princess of the tale whose only other real claim to film is X-MEN ORIGINS: WOVERINE as Silverfox) who plays her as an intelligent, quirky, beautiful and deadly woman; Ciaran Hinds, James Purefoy and the voice of Polly Walker who all are there to bring the same charm or gravity that they brought to their respective characters in HBO's brilliant series ROME; Dominic West (best known from THE WIRE) as Sab Than, the would-be puppet tyrant of Barsoom; Mark Strong (the British heavy in just about every film from SHERLOCK HOLMES to GREEN LANTERN) as Matai Shang, the immortal who looks to control the fate of Barsoom; Bryan Cranston in an unrecognizable but important role; and the voice talents of Willem Dafoe (who also worked with Stanton on FINDING NEMO) as Tars Tarkas, Samantha Morton (MINORITY REPORT) as Sola, and Thomas Haden Church as Tal Hajus.Taylor Kitsch as Carter lacks a certain consistency in his characterization. He has charm and is ruggedly handsome, but he lacks the leading-man charisma a role like this requires. The writing by Stanton, Michael Chabon, and Mark Andrews, who have a number of characters to deal with, a great deal of plot and exposition and to combine all of this with some bravura action set-pieces hurts the film somewhat in terms of characterization and may seem like a waste of talent in some cases, but each actor has their moment to shine, no matter the size of the part. The real winner, cast-wise, is Collins, who is so strong in her performance that I want to see her in more roles, and would love to see a film based just around her character. But the film is strong enough on its other merits to maintain great interest in the characters and the story to see it all the way through and still have a terrific time.The biggest winner here is sadly the biggest loser of everyone involved here, and that is Andrew Stanton. He directs the film with an eye for spectacle, precision of detail, and most appropriately, a strong sense of fun; the best example of this is the scene in which Carter leaps from ship to ship eventually meeting and fighting alongside Dejah. It's an incredible moment in the film because of just how well each moment is orchestrated. He tells the story of the film with a visual assuredness that rivals that of more experienced live-action filmmakers, and the filmmakers assembled a fantasic crew of digital and practical effects artists so that the interaction between the human/humanoid actors and the CG characters is totally seamless. Unfortunately, the film was something of a colossal bust at the box office due to exceedingly luke-warm reviews, an epically poor marketing campaign, and the natural comparisons between this film and AVATAR. I would watch this film a hundred more times before I would ever even think of watching AVATAR again, but it's a comparison worth making. So because of all this, the "failure" of this film to reach the heights it was intended to hit is all on Stanton's shoulders, which may hurt his ability to continue making live-action films. Although, looking at the reviews on Amazon, this film might receive some new life on home video, and the disconnect that exists between the marketing of the film and getting audiences in the theaters may now start to dissipate via word of mouth.When all is said and done, JOHN CARTER is a exciting pulp-flavored visual feast with something for everyone, and I can only hope that everyone can watch it and enjoy it as much as I did.4/5 Stars.
summary: The real star of JOHN CARTER is Andrew Stanton.

reviewText: This movie about John Carter, a character from the 1912 novel, A Princess of Mars, is thoroughly satisfying in every way. The idea of entanglement, a single body occupying different spaces simultaneously (in this case, planets) goes far beyond Star Trek's warp drive or transporter to imagine a travel that was much more revolutionary. Even Schroedinger, who refined the concept of entanglement (Verschraenkung), did not articulate his theories until 1935. The novel tells the tale of Dejah Thoris, brilliant and beautiful Princess of Helium, a city on Mars (aka Barsoom). She is rescued by John Carter, a Civil War hero adventurer transported to Mars unwittingly to eventually change everyone's destiny. Lavishly produced and beautifully acted, the movie will go down in history as Disney's finest achievement and best-loved movie. It might take some time, however, to erase initial  box office disappointment. It barely broke even on a huge budget. But, like the Wizard of Oz, will endure to become one of America's most popular features. The characters are well developed and interesting. Some of the performances are first rate, including those of Willem Dafoe, Samantha Morton, Lynn Collins and Taylor Kitsch. The warm, three dimensional personalities they create are as resonant and endearing as anything in Twain. That's not something one can say about many science fiction movies. Certainly, Mark Strong's, Matai Shang, will not be exceeded for intelligent villainy or jaded intensity any time soon. You know a performance is great when it seems the actor was also the writer. I encourage anyone to buy the film in Blue Ray to savor the mesmerizing visuals in all their glorious detail. When it comes down to choosing one dream world over another, my vote goes to the movie that features its heroes and heroines "sailing on light" in exquisite, dragonfly-like airships.
summary: Burroughs, father of Tarzan, imagines quantum entanglement on Mars 22 years before anyone else

reviewText: If you didn't get a chance to see John Carter in theaters you really really missed out.  I've been there.  I used to listen to critics and I missed out on some great times at the movies.  I hope after you finally get around to seeing JOHN CARTER and you LOVE it, you'll regret listening to those critics and internet trolls and NEVER EVER do so again.  Why would anyone listen to those who decided, like a mob, to gang up on this great film, or those you who made snap judgments based on trailers only, only to bully it from obtaining box office glory - glory which it deserved like no other action-adventure film in recent history? (Overseas audiences apparently still think for themselves).If you're one of those folks who listened to the critics pile on this great film, and decided to stay away, now is your chance to right that wrong. Buy the Blu-Ray/DVD! I hope after you see JOHN CARTER, and this great FILM sinks into your being, you spread the word and that like wildfire, JOHN CARTER gets the respect and attention it so rightly deserves. It's already destined for CULT status, that much is guaranteed. (Hello Blade Runner!) I just hope it gathers enough of a cult following to generate a sequel - the other books in the series it's based on deserve to be put on screen.  Us fans need to get really loud and be heard.  I hope if you are a fan of adventure films, you give JOHN CARTER a try.You may be thinking, oh I've seen this story before.  But you haven't.  This film is epic and tragic and wonderful and happy and funny and though-provoking.  Bottom-line: it makes you feel like the child you were when you first started liking these types of films - films about adventure and a hero's journey. Up until now, you've only seen the version stolen by others (no disrespect meant - I love most of these films).  But this is the great, great, great grand-daddy of all science-fiction/fantasy action-adventure films.  This is it - the source.  There's something refreshing about seeing that finally put on film. Only took 100 years!It is not a CG-laden crapfest that so much big budget sci-fi has become. (Hello Transformers and Star Wars Prequels I'm looking at you!).  The action is focused.  The backgrounds are real and/or look real - not a scene in it looks like bad green screen work.  The characters have real emotions and motivations. The villains are evil and the heroes are good old-fashioned heroes - not cynical whiny jerks. Taylor Kitsch brings a lot to the title role. He's a reluctant hero and you really feel for when you finally grasp why he's so reluctant.  Lynn Collins transforms herself into a Princess that could show Leia more than a thing or to.  She's that type of character you so rarely see - strong, sexy and smart. Not helpless.  Not a bimbo.  Not a vacant-eyed supermodel.  Mark Strong and Dominic West make for a great set of villains. And the CG characters in this are AMAZING!  They don't come across as animated, they come across as real characters.  I can guarantee you that TARS TARKAS, SOLA, and WOOLA will stick in your memory as fully-formed Martian creatures who just happened to be caught on film.The story of John Carter has been ripped off by countless science-fiction films from Lucas of Cameron.  And the damn shame is, our culture is so uneducated, that the media and masses saw the trailers for John Carter and immediately thought they were just seeing a STAR WARS or AVATAR clone. How ironic is that? Edgar Rice Burroughs CREATED the genre of science-fiction-fantasy in 1912 with his novel A Princess of Mars, upon which JOHN CARTER is based. Yes, I said 1912.  100 years ago - imagine that. He created the names SITH, JEDDAK and BANTHS (Sound familiar Star Wars fans?).  George Lucas tells the story of how he couldn't get the rights to make Flash Gordon, which itself was inspired by Burroughs' Mars books, yet doesn't credit Burroughs for the names and ideas he outright stole.  So, if the arena scene in the trailer looks it's from Attack of the Clones, that's because Lucas stole the idea from Burroughs books in the first place! (Gladiator-style battle between man and beast, with a crowd of alien onlookers, check!  Burroughs was there first buddy-boy.)The media and internet trolls treat the films that stole ideas from JOHN CARTER like they are the originators of the tales and JOHN CARTER is treated like some also-ran. They just don't get it.  That needs to be corrected.  See this film and judge for yourself.I sincerely hope that you see JOHN CARTER and fall in love with the story, the characters, the score and want to go back.  I hope you are mad that you were tricked out of seeing this cornerstone to science-fiction/fantasy by all the negative reviews and bad publicity surrounding it's release. I hope you DEMAND a sequel and call Disney out not doing their part to properly market and promote of this amazing action/adventure/science-fiction/fantasy/romance.  This should have been a summer movie release. Don't get me started on how mad I am at Disney right now.  The only way they can correct it is to greenlight a sequel.  And the only way that's going to happen is for you to buy this DVD/BLU-RAY and spread the word.If you get time, check out the facebook group "Take me Back to Barsoom!  I want a John Carter Sequel!"  Thousands of fans have already started to rally around the idea of a sequel. If DVD sales are strong enough, maybe it will happen.  I guarantee when you watch the end of this film, you'll want to go back to Mars (Barsoom) ASAP and be VERY VERY curious to see where the story goes next. Book two is amazing. I want to see it on film.(Please note - I am a huge fan of all science fiction fantasy action adventure films. I love Star Wars, Star Trek, Battlestar Galactica, StarGate, Avatar, Blade Runner, Alien, The Thing, Conan the Barbarian.  The list is endless.  But my love for all things sci-fi-fantasy began with exposure to ERB's Barsoom (Mars) series of books.  JOHN CARTER is the foundation for all of this love. It may be old school, but as a fan, old school is where it's at. Pulp fiction is where it began. I hope fans of comic books realize this as well and check out John Carter.  In many ways it's like a superhero film - John Carter gains the powers that the early Superman had - super strength and super jumps!Explore the roots of this whole crazy fandom by checking out JOHN CARTER.  Leave your preconceived notions at the door.  Honor its legacy by making this - the original - your own.
summary: A must buy! I can't say enough about this great film! This is THE SOURCE for all science-fiction fantasy action adventure films!

reviewText: As some have remarked, John Carter isn't as bad as the critics claim. I can't say it's the best sci-fi I've ever seen but it is memorable.The basic story, without spoilers, is about a postwar Confederate soldier, named John Carter, who ends up on Mars by accident. He soon finds himself in the middle of a new civil war between the three peoples who inhabit the planet. For his part, John must decide what his place is in this new world.The best part of the film are the visual effects. They've done a really good job of world building the cinematography is high quality. They went for a steampunk look and feel (high tech/low tech) and for the most part it works. Also, the action wasn't overblown as is the case in a lot of the current movies.Disney did a good job of creating likeable characters and there are plenty of comical moments along the way. For the most part the storyline keeps you interested and in that sense the movie succeeds.So where does John Carter go wrong--and why do I only give it three stars? Two reasons, both of which are tied to the screenplay itself. The scenes can be very choppy at times. It really feels like the problem may be do to a screenplay that was rewritten one too many times leaving the story disjointed.Another big problem for me was all the characters and scenes that too closely resembled other movies--I kept getting flashes of Jar Jar Binks, Jabba the Hut and that blue-man scene from Braveheart. It was very distracting because it was so hard not to notice.Even so, it's still worth watching. Yes, it can be corny and a little recycled at times but its still fun. It was certainly worth the dollar blueray rental. If you like sci-fi and don't have super-high expectations, you'll probably enjoy it.

reviewText: I read all of this series several times over as a young man - as well as the pelucidor stuff from burroughs.  The movie breaks quite a bit from the book, transforms later series elements and includes them.  The acting as is so much the trend today is not at all true to the books but much more 21st century punk attitude (look at me, I'm great, I'm sexy and I know it - blah blah blah).  I hate that "swagger" that's injected into every movie of the last decade or so and seems to be the trend.  That belongs if you are a narcissistic ass or a pirate and in nothing else.  That was the only serious detraction from the film.  Some of the changes were updated to take into account more of modern science, and sci fi conjunctions.  Edgar had no good way to tell us HOW John Carter made his journeys to and from Mars or any reason why he would suddenly make the journey (in the books).  So we are given more of a realistic foundation for this.  The film maker was influenced by the John Carter comic books.  That's likely where the swagger injection comes from as that tends to be the case in comic books.  Over all though it was well done and it was great to FINALLY see this concept on the big screen.  I have no idea what took so long as this has got to be one of the most iconic series ever written.

reviewText: I never read the original books the movie was based off of, but when I rented the movie I was very much aware of the negative press that came from this so I was not sure what to expect. I wouldn't say I was pleasantly surprised with the movie, but it is definitely better than its been given credit for by mainstream media and critics. The overall story is decent, the acting is ok, and I never found myself bored at any point in the movie. What I watched didn't look like a $250 million dollar movie though, especially when compared to a movie like Avatar, that didn't even cost as much.A couple of things really hurt this movie. The first is the name. I cant understand how Disney could allow such a horrible name for a $250 million dollar movie. The name John Carter does not make people interested and was never going to get anyone to spend money at the theater. This is just stupidly obvious. I'm pretty certain that if the movie had been called Princess of Mars it would have made millions more just from that since the focus would be more on the beautiful princess than on Taylor Kitsch. The smaller issue for me is the setting. When the books were written our knowledge of astronomy was much less than it is now, so I found myself uninterested in going to the theater to watch a movie about all this life and fighting on Mars, when that's not even remotely possible. Avatar was based on a fake world so you could more easily connect to the story than John Carter, when its based on the planet next to us that we know is cold, barely has an atmosphere, and has no intelligent life.Once the movie was available to rent from home I was interested because I enjoy sci-fi, and it was definitely worth renting, but the horrible marketing for this movie really hurt it, and for some of us the unrealistic setting also detracted from the movie. It was nice in 1917 when the book was written, but just doesn't work as well in 2012. Its too bad because I think Andrew Stanton did a decent job making the movie, but I highly doubt we will ever see the sequels.John Carter is not really worth the $10+ to see in a theater, but it is worth the $3-4 to rent on a evening when you just want some decent entertainment.

reviewText: What movie combines the absolute worst writing, directing, and acting of the 21st century?  So far, "John Carter" gets my vote.  On Amazon, the customer reviews indicate a hit movie, with revenues dozens of times the budget.  But it lasted only two weeks in theaters, and I can see why.Edgar Rice Burroughs was a hack, but like Louis Lamour, he was a hack with vision, and a decent writer as well.  His dialog was a little stilted, but his vision was well above average, and his storytelling ability -- spellbinding.  But this movie has nothing in common with the "Martian Books" other than the names of the characters and locations.Plotwise, the movie seems confused, erratic, even drugged.  The dialog is base and pretentious, among the worst of any large-budget film I've seen.  And the vision is strained and trite.  It would have been a thousand times better if Disney and company had simply taken the plot, vision, and dialog straight from the books, simply editing out whatever was burdensome (and there is a bit of that).  But making up everything from scratch?  Why even bother to use the names from the Burroughs books?The Peter Jackson "Lord of the Rings" trilogy, with its inept dialog and mediocre attempts to fill in gaps in the books with meaningless action and supposition, was saved by superb acting (I wonder if his version of "The Hobbit" will be so lucky) and some wonderful settings.  But "John Carter" has none of that.  The acting is as unpalatable as the dialog the actors are faced with, and the settings are pure CGI.The plot, however, is the real nemisis of this piece of spoiled celluloid.  It's hard to tell where it is coming from at any given moment.  This is the lesson I hope Jackson has learned:  Stick to the original; there is a reason why it is so famous and beloved.  Somehow, "John Carter" seems like a haphazard attempt to combine disparate elements from the first three books, simply rushing along on a path to failure.  I heard that Disney intended this to kick-start a franchise.  Then why not let it play out as the original stories did?  They became a successful franchise.  "A Princess of Mars", a complete story unto itself, would have been a thousand times better.  After making up a new story and character for the first thirty minutes, the writers and director try to cram way too much into the remaining time.Last, but not least:  Characterization in this is so dull.  The obligatory "woman with a sword" (again, see Peter Jackson's LOTR, in which any woman can get the drop on Aragorn -- why didn't Sauron just send a half-naked babe with a blade after his mortal enemy?) replaces the Burroughs-era obligatory "damsel-in-distress", without adding anything of value to the story.  John Carter, instead of being the honorable "southern gentleman" becomes the "rebellious adult-delinquent".  And the extra weight of cramming too much plot and weird magic (nowhere in the books is there any magical device, nor a Thern on earth) simply takes away from the novels' delightfully slow revelation of character of the green and red men and women of Barsoom, and their culture (like when John Carter first calls Dejah Thoris "my princess", ignorant of the impact of those words between a red man and woman, or the significance of her calling him "my chieftain").  This flick is all black-and-white characters, none of which have any motivation, depth, or subtlety, led by  the protagonist constantly whining about wanting his "cave of gold".These reflections concern only the first hour of the movie, as I have no intention of watching the rest.  This may be the worst money I've spent since the "Kill Bill" dvds went on sale for $5 apiece.  And this was $14.99 -- what a travesty.

reviewText: If you don't already know by now, never listen to film critics. This movie is a perfect example of how critics are totally full of it. The only thing to criticise about this movie is how absolutely horribly Disney failed to market this film.
