It looked retarded. I finally rented it just out of curiosity and was completely blown away. The acting was top notch, the special effects were amazing, and the story was fantastic. It immediately made me want to watch a sequel, so I went online only to find that Disney botched the marketing so badly that they actually scrapped plans for a sequel because it didn't make enough money! Of course it didn't make money, they made it look ridiculous in everything they said about it. It's a serious sci-fi movie that they marketed as some kind of kids show. The only reason it got a pg-13 rating is because all the people on Mars bled blue blood when they were eviscerated and hacked to pieces. If it had been red this would have had a hard R rating. It was extremely violent and had many adult themes that would not only not appeal to kids, but it would piss off any parents who took thier kids to see it. Disney's marketing department is run by morons. Unfortunatley that may have ruined what could have been one of the greatest sci-fi franchises EVER. reviewText: I have to admit that, like many, I took a pass on the theatrical version, mostly out of apathy.  I was turned off by the Conan the Barbarian outfits and the seemingly cheesy CGI work that I saw in the trailers.  However, after watching the film on Amazon Instant Video (admittedly, I still went the cheap, non-HD route), I walked away quite impressed with the movie.In short, as many reviews have noted, many of the themes in JC are familiar.  In fact, folks like George Lucas clearly lifted many of their themes and action pieces from John Carter, if the movie is in fact representative of the book. (Which I intend to read at some point on my Kindle.) Unlike George's underwhelming prequels, though, the film had very entertaining characters, an extremely strong and well-motivated female lead, and even children's elements (the dog-alien) that didn't insult the viewer with lowbrow humor.  In short, this is the movie that The Phantom Menace should have been.  In a fair world, JC would have made the $700M that TPM did, while TMP languished.  Sadly, that was not to be.In the end, I have the feeling I'll pick up the Blu-ray in the near future.  It's a film with great action, pretty doggone good CG effects (the Tharks and the dog-alien are very enjoyable, even if they're not 100% believable), and an excellent score.  I dropped the film by one star mainly because I felt that Taylor Kitsch lacks the charisma to be a leading actor and he pulls the movie down when it should have soared.  He has the physicality, but simply not the emotional or acting depth to make John Carter more than a 2D character in a 3D film.
summary: The Movie the Phantom Menace SHOULD Have Been

reviewText: Wow, I just finished watching this a few hours ago, and it was actually far better than I had anticipated.Especially after the bad rap the press and senile critics gave it.You know, when it comes to critics, especially people who have been in the business for a long time, there should be a limit as to how many films they are allowed to review, because I think as their mileage goes up, they forget how to enjoy a film.Then they need to be replaced, like a light bulb.Anyways, back to the movie.As you may or may not know, this is one of the stories, if not THE story that started the whole space opera genre, so if you see similarities with other well known films in this genre, it's because they were inspired by this.For a story that is one hundred years old it manages to hold up, thanks to a little modern intervention of course.It sticks close enough to the source material, and also expands on it.Although if you are a purist, you might be a little ticked off.Just keep in mind that adaption, from book to film, is never a smooth ride, since they are two very different ways of telling a story.Not a huge leap, but you know what I mean.Anywho, I really hope a sequel is made, because I found everything in the world of John Carter interesting enough that I do want to see what happens next.The visuals are great, and for a Disney film, sort of violent, to put it mildly, but don't let that turn you away.I have sat through a few boring movies over the years, and this is not one of them, not by a long shot.If you like adventure, fantasy, science fiction, etc...then you will enjoy this film.I think it has something for just about everybody.Also, if you can get ahold of the original stories, read those too!Now that I have helped advertise the film, and became a critic myself, go watch the movie and see what me, and many other people have been blabbing about.
summary: Hope we get to return to Mars.

reviewText: Not much one can add to over 1000 reviews. I am a huge fan of Burroughs in general and the Mars series in particular having first read "A Princess of Mars" over 40 years ago. Here are some impressions from that perspective that I came away with:1. Plot changes. They were certainly necessary as "Princess" ended on a cliffhanger. More importantly, "Princess" was a book with a lot of exposition which can work well enough in a book but is undesirable for a film. Films need a faster pace than a book.2. The Therns. The Therns are certainly much more powerful in the film as compared to the book(s). On the plus side they do provide a convenient explanation for how Carter gets to Mars. This was badly needed as Burroughs was very vague about this. On the debit side they are too powerful and make Carter too much of the pawn and not enough of the all conquering hero that Burroughs created.3. Dejah Thoris. Lynn Collins *is* Dejah Thoris, exactly as a dozen paperback cover artists have depicted her over the decades. Perfect casting. Her character has been updated in two ways to bring her more in line with 21st century sensibilities. First, she is as much a swordsman as Carter whereas in the books her weapon of choice was a dagger used to defend her honor against various miscreants. Second, she is depicted as a scientist here, a role her son played in the novels. Both changes were quite acceptable.4. Jumping ability. Hugely exaggerated over what Burroughs established in the novels. Not sure this was necessary but perhaps the producers were influenced by the success of the many superhero films of late.5. Barsoom. Perfectly depicted. Excellent use of CGI throughout. Quite impressed with the amount of Barsoomian visuals the producers were able to work in. It really had the correct "feel".6. The story. Very impressed with the amount of "Princess" that made it into the film. The entire framing sequence was retained. The 19th century setting was retained. The whole Thark/Tars Tarkas/Sola/Woola plot points survived.The "sword and planet" genre has been out of fashion for a long time now. It has always been something of a male juvenile genre which one had to be exposed to before age 15 to appreciate. The audience for this film probably died out long before the technology was available to bring to the screen. Those of us who survived to see it can be grateful that Disney brought it to the screen and it is to be regretted that they were not financially rewarded for their fine efforts. Highly recommended.

reviewText: Due to being called a box-office bomb and some bad word of mouth, I expected a bad movie, but John Carter is a fun space opera. The movie is daring and a little old fashion for a movie with such great CGI which is why some people just write it off as bad. The film also gets called a StarWars rip-off when the books were written by the writer of Tarzan and around much longer.Taylor Kirsch (Friday Night Lights) was even picked on by Richard Roeper but he had a lot more charm and charisma than he got credit for. While William Dafoe (Spider-Man) does brilliant voice work as Tars Tarkas, an alien that believes in John Carter from the start but he also wants Carter to fight for his race due to Carter's great jumping ability. You also have Mark Strong (Sherlock Holmes) good as always in a villain role of course as a shapeshifting alien and Lynn Collins as one of the sexiest Princesses on film in awhile and she of course is Carter's love interest. Oh and I want Carter's loyal alien dog that follows him everywhere.John Carter is one to be open minded about and to form your own opinion with. The film had bad marketing and wasn't even advertised as being based on a book which sometimes helps. It also was in the top 10 at the box office for a couple of weeks but was constantly picked on due to how much it cost. If it didn't cost so much to make, it would have been considered a hit.
summary: Better Than It Gets Credit For!

reviewText: John Carter (Taylor Kitsch) is an ex-military hero for the South during the civil war. The Indians don't like him, the union forces want him to fight the Indians or else and he is being forced into another conflict that he wants to avoid at all cost.  Forced to save a union colonel from the Indians and hide in a cave, he finds the gold mine that he has been looking for.  Suddenly he is attacked from behind by a strange looking man with an advanced weapon and he is forced to fight.  He kills the man and picks up a glowing medallion and is instantaneously transferred to Mars....This is a Disney Sci-Fi movie and I thought it was excellent.  The storyline is well done and the special effects are outstanding.  Aliens, monsters and a war on Mars bring John Carter into the battle of his life whether he wants to get involved or not.  The real reason he gets involved is the beautiful Princess of Mars (Lynn Collins) that he is attracted to.I did not know what to expect when this DVD came out because of all the bad reviews from the professional critics.  Don't believe them and get this movie and judge it for yourself.  My wife and I loved it and thought that it was a great movie.  Based on the Edgar Rice Burroughs books the script has been changed somewhat but it is still a masterpiece.  Disney does its usual fantastic job with the filming and special effects.  The movie is nonstop action and adventure and you will lose yourself in the story and characters.Watch this movie and you will enjoy it.  It is rated PG 13 but your kids will like it a lot.  It is top notch entertainment!
summary: Much better movie than the critics are saying it is!

reviewText: John CarterA couple of years ago, Asylum put together "A Princess of Mars" in just a couple of weeks. It was one of the most bastardized movies I have ever seen. The only good thing in it was Tracy Lord's body, which is still nice after all these years.Now, Disney has sunk a couple hundred million dollars in "John Carter" in another retelling of Edgar Rice Burroughs "Martian" books.I will have to say that I went to see this film with reservations. I have seen several scenes on YouTube, and they didn't look to be anything like the books that I have grown to love over 45 years. I started reading them when I was around 12 years old, so I am pretty well acquainted with the characters.That said, a friend and I went to the theater tonight and saw the film in a completely refurbished theater with new rocking chair seats. The cost of admission? $2.50.As I expected, many aspects of the film did not go along with the books. Some things were a bit outrageous when compared to print, but the movie as a whole was plain out good. I think that if I had never read the books, I might have liked it more. But on a scale of 1-100, I would still give it a 95. :DThe lead characters are Taylor Kitch as John Carter, and Lynn Collins as Dajah Thoris.A few inconsistencies (not all listed) between the movie and the books are:1 - Tars Tarkas was not the Jeddak when he found John Carter (The Jeddak was Tal Hajus).2 - Woola could not run as fast as the movie makes out. He could apparently put a Greyhound to shame, but he couldn't run like a shot out of a cannon as on the movie.3 - The Holy Therns could not just materialize anywhere on the planet. They also wore blonde wigs.4 - The weapon that the Holy Therns used in the move came on quite a bit later in the series and was developed not by the Therns, but by a crazy Jeddak who was out to conquer the world.5 - Matai Shang was a "Holy Thern" and dedicated his dirty deeds to "Lessor Therns". He would not have dirtied his hands with the things that the movie character did. He also had a beautiful daughter who was nowhere to be seen in the movie.6 - The movie intimated that the Therns were aliens to Mars. This was definately not the way it is told in the books. They fooled the planet into thinking they were "Holy" and doing the work if "Issus". They were definitely not Holy, and Issus turned out to be a several hundred year old crazy woman who dined on the "delicate" parts of the most beautiful women on the planet that happened to be taken hostage by the Black Pirates of Barsoom (who themselves made raids on the Therns).7 - Dajah Thoris was not a warrior, and neither was she a great scholar. She was a smart, pretty, and determined little princess who could wield a sword if she had too, and that was about it.8 - John Carter could jump at most around 150 feet. Most of the time it was more like 10-50 feet. The movie has him jumping a thousand feet or more.9 - Tardas Mors (her grand-father in the books)would never have made Dajah, marry "Sab Than", no matter what the cost to the city of Helium. There is no mention of Mors Kajak (her father in the books) at all.10 - Powell and Carter were mining partners in the books.11 - Sab Than was not a Jeddak and the city of Zodanga didn't move around on a giant machine. This was just stupid.Even with the inconsistencies, the movie was a good one to watch. I don't quite understand why it didn't do well in theaters. This is a shame too as there should be two more films to complete the original trilogy. But Stanton's incompetency has probably doomed any further movies in the series.All in all, I would say that this movie was really good. I will definitely see it again........and again. :DBut as stated: Andrew Stanton has screwed the characters up so much, and mixed up so many things from all the books, I don't see how it's possible to make another movie.Note: Even if you do NOT like science fiction, or other movies of this type, take notice: If you like seeing good looking women in skimpy costumes, you should see this film. Lynn Collins is absolutely beautiful as Dajah Thoris. I think I fell just a little bit in love tonight. ;DDisney should have had better advertising and not given up so easily on this film.
summary: Too many liberties taken with writing script, but good anyway.

reviewText: When I heard that John Carter of Mars was being made with Antonio Sabato, Jr, I had high hopes. They were dashed. The movie didn't make the best use of Edgar Rice Burroughs's stories or his imaginative writing. Most of the elements were in place, but the acting was marginal, even with Antonio's flexing muscles and sharply sculpted cheekbones, but the princess, played by one-time porn princess, Traci Lords, was lacking in everything, especially emotion and acting ability. There was plenty of skin, though. It was not up to my -- or anyone else's -- expectations.Along comes Taylor Kitsch in his turn as John Carter, a slow talking, brilliant man born out of his time and transported to Mars to a world he doesn't understand with abilities and strengths he didn't know were possible. John Carter definitely made the grade. There were some small bobbles, but this all star cast has done a creditable job with Burroughs's story and with the world of Barsoom he created.The special effects do not intrude but work seamlessly with the live actors and, despite everyone wearing at least some clothing, unlike Burroughs's story where the "red men" were naked most of the time, the story has been captured admirably. There will always be some difference between books and Hollywood's version, but this version of John Carter is as close as it gets to the book. Bravo!

reviewText: Disney's "John Carter" movie is based on Edgar Rice Burrough's classic story "A Princess of Mars" which introduced me to the science fiction genre and made me a fan for life.  This story is very character-driven, the main characters being John Carter, Tars Tarkas and Princess Dejah Thoris.This story deals with John Carter, a disillusioned Civil War veteran who is mysteriously transported to Barsoom (Mars), which is dying and slowly losing its atmosphere and water.  When John arrives on Mars he immediately notices that he has greater strength and can jump huge distances.  The world he has entered is in the middle of a civil war between Helium and Zodang, which is secretly aided by the Therns (White Martians).Every side in this conflict wants John to aid them but he refuses to become part of it until he sees what is happening here and turns the tables on the plotters.  The movie does true justice to Edgar Rice Burroughs' vision of the Red Planet`s creatures, cities, air ships and terrain, by delivering a stunning vision of Mars.The John Carter of Mars is truly a great movie with great heroes and a great villain Matai Shang, who is the leader of the evil Therns (White Martians) of Barsoom (Mars).  This movie is well worth the price of admission.
summary: Stunningly visual movie that's true to the original story by Edgar Rice Burroughs!

reviewText: "John Carter" should have been among this year's highest grossing films. It is a cinematic homage to Edgar Rice Burroughs' "John Carter of Mars" series of novels, based primarily on the first,  "A Princess of Mars", and one that remains true in spirit to Edgar Rice Burroughs, written by screenwriters, especially noted American fiction writer Michael Chabon, who are long-time admirers of Burroughs' classic space opera science fiction series. Much to its credit, the film is not only true to Burroughs's spirit, but it also remains quite faithful to the original source material itself. Director Andrew Stanton (who co-wrote the screenplay with Chabon and Mark Andrews) has wrought a most compelling film, filled with excellent special effects and great cinematography, but made especially noteworthy with the presence of an excellent cast. Canadian actor Taylor Kitsch is a credible, heroic John Carter, American actress Lynn Collins is a ravishingly beautiful and compelling Princess of Mars Dejah Thoris, and legendary American actor Willem Dafoe is an admirable Tars Tarkas (even if he is kept "under wraps" as Carter's faithful Barsoom (Mars) sidekick and friend).  Don't believe any of the negative reviews which "John Carter" earned from skeptical film critics. It definitely ranks alongside Peter Jackson's "The Lord of the Rings" trilogy as among the most successful cinematic translations of fantasy and science fiction ever created; a far more enjoyable and memorable film than either the "Star Wars" prequels or "Avatar". Eventually I predict that "John Carter" will be recognized as the most neglected science fiction cinematic classic of our time.
summary: An Ignored, Sadly Neglected, Instant Classic Of Science Fiction Cinema

reviewText: I first read "A Princess of Mars" in third grade, in 1951.  I loved this character, and the following books just as much.  This film is a weird combination of the first and second book.  For instance, the Therns were not introduced until the second book, "The Gods of Mars", but they are introduced here, not as the religious leaders but as the villains and very technologically advanced.  However, after seeming to pan the film, I do have to admit that it definitely had the "feel" of a Burroughs book.  I'm still not sure whether the changes made it better or worse.  The acting was really quite good, the special effects are uniformly excellent and the story, while not "true" to Burroughs, had enough of his ideas that it was very entertaining.  So, if you are a fan of Burroughs like me, it is somewhat disappointing, but the good points do outweigh the bad.  I would really give this 3 1/2 stars but Amazon won't let me do half stars, so I guess 4 will do.
summary: Major changes from the Burroughs book
Title: N/A

reviewText: Full disclosure: I did not purchase this through Amazon.  I won't go into the many reasons "John Carter" failed at the box office.  An entire book has already been written on that subject:John Carter and the Gods of Hollywood, by Michael D. Sellers.  I came to this film with low expectations, having seen and heard all the terrible media coverage.  I've not read any of Burroughs' work, and even if I had, I judge films on their own merits, not on how faithful they are to their source material."John Carter" is a good film.Okay, so it's not exactly Oscar-worthy.  But it's fun and entertaining to watch...and I don't say that lightly, because I'm extremely picky about the movies that I like.  This one may not be deserving of any Academy Awards, but it's better than most of what I see coming out of Hollywood lately.  I recommend buying it.Picture quality of this 16x9 widescreen transfer was excellent.  Audio left something to be desired; I found the dialogue a bit too soft.  I was impressed with the music, which was composed by Michael Giacchino; I hope to hear more of his work in the future.  I don't usually take note of title sequences or end credits, but did in this case; they're so well designed that I enjoyed watching them.  Of the lead cast, I thought Lynn Collins (as Dejah Thoris) gave the best performance.  I know that Taylor Kitsch has been criticized, by I didn't see anything wrong with his acting.  Honestly, it would have been difficult for any actor to deliver lines like: "Tharks did not cause this, but by Issus, Tharks will end it!", and keep a straight face.  And this is where the movie stumbles a little: story/plot.  Various words and concepts are unexplained, or explained poorly.  If you're not already well versed in ERB's Mars saga, expect to do some rewinding.  Although this is not, strictly speaking, a steampunk film, I think fans of the genre will get a kick out of it.Normally, I find extras boring, but in this case I thought some were good.  Special features are as follows:1. "Explore John Carter's Journal With Disney Second Screen."  I can't speak to this, because you have to download a special app.  I didn't want to bother.2. "100 Years In The Making."  Brief history of ERB and his work, and how he influenced just about all sci-fi that came after him.  Also, the tribulations of various attempts to bring his Mars saga to screen over the years.  Interesting.3. Deleted Scenes.  Most of these are unremarkable, with two exceptions.  The first is "Original Opening: Hall of Science." I think Stanton dropped the ball here.  This would have made a much better opening for the movie.  The second is "Ned at College."  This brief scene provides more of a connection between Ned and John, and was well done.  I think it should have been included.  All the scenes have commentary with Andrew Stanton, which I did not listen to.  Maybe he gives valid reasons why they weren't part of the final cut.4. "360 Degrees of John Carter" is a "making of" special.  To my surprise, I liked it.  They made an effort to include not only principals such as director/lead cast, but extras, make-up artists, costume designers, and even the cooks/craft service people.5. "Barsoom Bloopers" is, of course, a blooper reel.  It was funny to watch.6. Audio commentary w/Director Andrew Stanton, and producers Jim Morris and Lindsey Collins.  I don't usually listen to these, but I might listen to this one in the future.  It'll be interesting to hear what they may have said about the film's (mis)marketing and reception at the box office.Bottom line: in my opinion, "John Carter" has gotten a bum rap.  I think you should give it a chance; I'm glad that I did.
summary: Blu-ray, special features: in defense of John Carter

reviewText: Disney's John Carter is among the 5 worst movies I have ever seen.Terrible acting.Incomprehensible plot.Amateurish special effects.Clownish costumes.Just a total waste of time.Movies made by the SyFy channel are better.  Movies made by the Asylum are better.John Carter is rotten!EDIT to add more detail:I have no connection to the film company Asylum. I just did not care for John Carter at all.I rented John Carter, despite the many critics who gave it negative reviews. I have found critics to be wrong before, and I wanted to make my own assessment.Movies can be really subjective. John Carter just did not work for me. About the only part of John Carter I enjoyed was the interactive between Carter and the Union Colonel who comes to "draft" him. Those few scenes were okay.The fight scenes kept making me wonder why? Why if you have high tech weapons and machines do you need to fight with swords? And to me, the romance angle just did not work at all.The natives (tharks? spelling) portrayal seemed to me to be neither realistic, nor comical, and so they came off as too fakey. I kept thinking of JarJar Binks from Star Wars (I found that character annoying) and a cross with muppets.Most of the CGI effects I found seemed to be imitations of other, better done, movies.I think I may have enjoyed it more had there been better development of fewer characters.  It seems I was just getting to following who was what, and then it changed.  New people, or creatures, entered and it was all new again.At first I thought the lower gravity effects were going to be good, but then it seemed like it was inconsistent.  Sometimes he would "leap tall buildings with a single bound" and other moments he seemed to strain.  But maybe John Carter was mastering his environment better?Overall, I thought John Carter was a rotten movie.

reviewText: This is one of the most underrated and undeservedly slandered films I've seen.  This one boldy marches right up and sits right down beside Star Wars and other like time-tested, sci-fi 'space operas'.  Plus, this one has the added degree of being distilled from one of the earliest sci-fi classics by Burroughs.  As such, it can claim a somewhat unique plot line and scope, which I will not spoil for the potential newcomer.I gave it five stars, which is, in this case, 4.5 stars rounded up.  I would spare it half a star in agreement with some of the other comments about scripting.  It does get somewhat predictable.  Along with that, I found Taylor Kitsch's delivery a little juvenile and overdone.  His cockiness gets a little tiring.  Still, he is a good choice and a new face.Other than that, it really is a visual feast worthy of Lucas, Spielberg, Scott, et al.  The action sequences and CGI are spectacular and, happily, only improve in scale and depth as the film progresses.  Lynn Collins is an excellent choice for Dejah Thoris, and is stunning to behold in this exotic role; her appearances never go unnoticed....I can only echo the other pleas here for Disney to look past the box office performance and let the growing fan following of this film persuade them to continue the franchise.  It would be a great opportunity for Disney to add their own mark to the sci-fi genre, having such a strong and definitive opener with 'John Carter'.  Burroughs wrote plenty more material in this particular universe to be mined - it would be a shame to not see what happens next to John Carter and Dejah Thoris.  The fantasy is all the more fun contrasted with the new knowledge from the ongoing explorations of Mars.  Come on, Disney, let's go back to Barsoom.
summary: Another great visionary piece that refutes the critics

reviewText: Based on popular pulp fiction, "John Carter" (initially titled "John Carter of Mars") centers on a Civil War vet who finds himself transported to Mars. From here Carter rescues "A Princess of Mars" (a famous Pulp title) and finds himself in a war between alien races. Produced by DISNEY, this adaptation is unfortunately a piece DISNEY threw in the garbage before it was released in theaters focusing very, very little on marketing. It's not a bad film nor is it the greatest summer blockbuster. For me, the most memorable moments was the arena scene and the gorgeous Lynn Collins. It's a fun ride while it lasts but don't expect a sequel because in DISNEY's minds, it bombed before it hit the box office. Look for it on DVD and BD in June.

reviewText: I rented this movie based on all the good reviews here on Amazon.com. I am so sorry I wasted my money!Not only was the acting laughable, but the director and editor of this piece of junk should be banned from Hollywood for the rest of eternity. The script had lots of potential - handsome, rebel Earthling falls for the beautiful and smart Princess whose father wants her to marry the baddest, meanest warrior on Mars. Throw in some wise and friendly desert creatures who take in the Earthling and band with him to overthrow the warrior and you've got the makings of a decent film. Or so you should. Not so with John Carter. Somehow Disney managed to ruin what should have been a hit.How did it get to be a dull and amateurish (and did I say too long) movie? The director or editor had no idea how to smoothly transition from a comedic scene to a suspenseful one. And while the movie had good actors in it, the lines were horribly flat and there was no chemistry between Taylor Kitsch (John Carter) and Lynn Collins (Princess Thoris). And the native "monsters" in the film were hokey.I love sci-fi and fantasy movies but this was barely worth 2 stars. Don't waste your time or money.
summary: So horrible on so many levels

reviewText: There are some things that you wait for all your life, and then are disappointed when you finally get them. "John Carter" is most certainly NOT one of those things. I fell in love with John Carter, Tars Tarkas, and the Incomparable Dejah Thoris as a boy of 14. Half a century later, I am still in love with them, and I will always be grateful to Mr Stanton and all of the men and women who brought our mutual dream to the big screen in such a faithful manner. Was it perfect? Of course not. Did it leave out some of my favorite parts of the story? Certainly. But I'm don't really feel that those elements are lost, since they have been included in everything from the old "Flash Gordon" comic strips, to "Star Wars," "Highlander," "Avatar," and too many others to even mention here. Of course, only the real fans are aware of that fact, since Walt Disney Studios, for some inexplicable reason, chose to keep it a deep, dark secret."John Carter" has been the brunt of a lot of half assed comedians jokes and would be movie critic's reviews (which are themselves little more than jokes)but the actual truth is that this movie was murdered by the very people who should have been working the hardest to see that their investment proved successful. If Disney Studios had implemented an advertizement campaign only half as great as what was given "The Avengers," "John Carter" would have been seen and appreciated as the great movie that it truly is. It's not too late, even now. Disney COULD mount a proper advertizing campaign and re-release it in the fall or around Christmas, with considerable merchandise tie ins. With the recent management turn over there's a chance that maybe it will really happen. In the words of John Carter himself, "We still live."
summary: John Carter: The Movie That Wouldn't Die

reviewText: John Carter (originally titled John Carter of Mars) is based on the 1917 novel A Princess of Mars by Tarzan-scribe Edgar Rice Burroughs. An adaptation has been trying to get off the ground since 1931. When the film was finally released to theaters in March, financial prospects were already hopeless. John Carter is now infamous for what a huge flop it was for Disney. On a budget of $250 million (not counting marketing), it only grossed only $72 million in America. Despite what a gargantuan flop it was, it still managed to gross $280 million worldwide, while setting box office records in Russia. The novel it's based on was the first in a series of 11 novels, but this is hardly an established property. I think few would argue that the failure of John Carter was a failure of marketing. The "of Mars" was dropped from the title. A rumored reason being that Disney didn't want people to draw a correlation between this film and their recent Mars Needs Moms film, which was also a colossal flop. The trailers were too vague, giving no real indication of what the film was about. When will Disney (and other film studios) realize that it's not an established property or trying to get people to disassociate a film from an unrelated film that brings in box office? It's an intriguing trailer and word-of-mouth that will bring financial rewards. John Carter of Mars would not have reminded people of Mars Needs Moms, but the trailer did remind people of Prince of Persia.The financial hit that Disney took for this film has been widely reported, so much that it's overshadowed the film itself. So how is John Carter? Not bad. What immediately separates John Carter from most films like it is that it isn't a sci-fi, action blockbuster. It's an adventure movie a la Indiana Jones...And you don't see too many films like that anymore. It's a much better film than its reputation would lead you to believe.The film opens on Barsoom (the official name of Mars) and gives a bit of back-story, as well as making it clear that the film will be a visual treat. It then jumps back to New York City, 1881 where John Carter (Taylor Kitsch), a former American Civil War Confederate Army captain, dies suddenly. His nephew Edgar Rice Burroughs (Daryl Sabara) inherits his estate and his private journal. As he begins reading, the film once again jumps back to 1868. Here, John Carter escapes the grasp of a Union Colonel (Bryan Cranston) and ends up in a cave where a mysterious medallion transports him to Mars. Because of the physical characteristics of Mars and Carter's bone density, he is able to jump to great heights and utilize great strength. He is captured by some Martians called Tharks and soon finds himself caught in the middle of a war between two cities of Barsoom, with a Princess named Dejah (Lynn Collins) caught in the middle.Action, romance, aliens, war, a lot of eye-popping visual effects, and a charismatic lead actor; John Carter has every essential element necessary to appeal to the broadest audience possible. It's clear throughout the film where the $250 million budget went and the film benefits from this price tag in a way investors did not. The sets are grand and, like most of the film, terrific to look at.John Carter has about as much depth as the average film of this sort, but it's a largely superficial film. It doesn't purely rely on special effects and CGI to tell the story, but the story isn't particularly exciting or fresh. Granted, it's based on a story that was written almost 100 years ago but we've seen this template thousands of times in movies. Still, there is a certain amount of originality due to director Andrew Stanton's visual prowess. Stanton previously directed the Pixar films Finding Nemo and Wall*E, so he has an eye for telling a story visually. Even with his ability to stage a visual extravaganza, his visual sense recalls other films...I could never escape the idea that I was watching Indiana Jones thrown into Star Wars on the set of Lawrence of Arabia. Furthermore, despite a script by 3 different people; much of what's good relies on aspects that weren't on paper. The dialogue is heavy-handed and plodding, but it offers no surprises nor is it particularly important.Even with familiar themes, John Carter is entertaining and it's chock-full of fine actors (including Mark Strong, Ciaran Hinds, Willem Dafoe, and Thomas Haden Church to name a few) and the visual effects are particularly impressive. A familiar template for a story, with fine actors and astounding visual effects? That sounds like Avatar. Yeah...And John Carter, while far from perfect, still does nearly everything better than Avatar. The CGI-heavy action sequences are thrilling and consistently appealing on a visual level. A lot of effort was put into these visual effects and they're quite convincing. One battle sequence is intercut with a traumatic event in Carter's past and is both unexpected and effectively executed.Had this been a hit, it would've done been a major success for the charismatic Kitsch. He brings more depth to his performance as Carter than the film requires. He's got a great, commanding speaking voice and is a very talented physical performer as well. His performance, like the film, is pretty serious-minded. That's where comparisons to Indiana Jones end. There's a minimal amount of humor in John Carter, which is particularly surprising when most films of this sort rely on some type of comic relief.CGI aside, this film would feel right at home as a 70s movie. You don't see blockbuster fare like this too often anymore. I didn't love John Carter, but here's a rare example where a sequel may actually be warranted...And could no doubt be better than this first installment. There's a terrific and simple twist ending that actually concludes the film on a nice note and made me a bit disheartened that there would be no sequel. It's a crowd-pleasing film that will likely find an audience on home video. It falls short of being marvelous, but it certainly entertains and that's really all it needs to do.

reviewText: I had seen the reviews for John Carter when it premiered in theaters and so, this was immediately subjugated to the "wait for rental" status that happens with movies that have extremely tepid previews, weak marketing and mixed or poor critic reviews.However, after having seen the movie, I am rather surprised that it fared as badly with critics as it did.**SPOILER ALERT**My wife and I popped this in on a rainy saturday afternoon not really expecting much.  However, we really got caught up in the story and the great on-screen chemistry between Taylor Kitsch and Lynn Collins.The real weakness in this movie is the somewhat confusing plot... basically, the celestial "bad guys" are feeding off of the destruction of Mars, but Dejah Thoris, princess of Helium, is close to discovering a source of great power that can reverse Mars fortune.  The "bad guys" give a powerful weapon to the leader of the enemy of Helium in order to broker a forced marriage and ultimately destroy Dejah as well as Helium removing the threat for good.Sound confusing?  It is, a little bit... but it is very entertaining.  Other than the slightly confusing back-story my only real complaint is that the movie has a real anti-climactic ending.However, the movie is packed with action, great dialogue and the previously mentioned chemistry between the leading actor and actress that make the story that much more enjoyable.John Carter deserved much better than it got.  It's too bad that the terrible box office showing will remove any opportunity for a sequel.

reviewText: This movie deserves a sequel (or two)!Nicely paced for a somewhat epic story, this film introduces the human protagonist, puts him on Mars, then brings on the Martians, all in fairly short order... then a world is saved.Not a simple mess to organize into a 2 hour film, but the task is managed with humor, action, charm, and a fine Saturday matinee flair.John Carter pays homage to just about every preceding Sci-Fi flick, and as Disney spared no expense, the visual candy is just about the finest spectacle Hollywood can produce... truly state-of-the-art CGI and 3D.Don't chince on this one... pay the 15 bucks and see it in IMAX 3D! Until cinema begins to use 60 FPS or higher, this is as good as it gets!Any kid or kid at heart is going to LOVE this movie!

reviewText: After seemingly to bomb at the box office and receive negative reviews, I was a little nervous to watch. However, I got my popcorn ready and told myself it was going to just pass the time. I was surprised to find a story that was a real adventure - in the purest sense of the word - packed with humor and great effects. And yes - a nice romance. I was reminded of the pure fun of the movies like the first couple "Indiana Jones", "The Librarian", and even "Secondhand Lions".This film is a STORY, as in a story one person tells another. It seems outlandish because it is. But that doesn't mean it isn't fun and worth the watch! It isn't all airy lightness and there are some "internal demons" for our hero to work out and a war being raged on Mars, but they only add to the story. The story is about finding yourself again, despite what brought you to who you are.Highly recommend for family watching - my 15 year old boy watched with me and was very entertained. The cast is solid, and the effects are amazing. Go forth and adventure!

reviewText: I read this novel during my teens, but I'd known about it for years, because I'd inherited my Mom's hand-made paper dolls of John Carter and Deeja Thoris and she'd talked about them to me. In short, I'm an old time second generation fan. When I heard the movie had bombed, I was sorry but not surprised. There's a vast of story of a complex warring alien world packed into this one hundred year old fiction, and it's fairly complicated, which does not please the sound-bite ADD kids of today. When I finally saw the movie, I pleasantly surprised. I can't for the life of me, really understand what went wrong, except as one writer has said "bad marketing and insane critics." John Carter is an absolute breathtaking beauty. The CG and the costuming, make-up, world design, etc. was fabulous, and the writers broke their necks creating a credible, understandable screen play from a mass of backstory. The main characters perhaps were the problem. The body builder physiques of the leads were gorgeous, and right out of Frazeta's art, but they were overwhelmed by special effects and the thinness of the--let's face it--pulp fiction characters they played, who were, after all, written on spec one hundred years ago. I'd still give this movie two thumbs up for the love and care, for the thought and planning, and for the wonders of the incredibly inventive and imaginative Burroughsian world it brought to life.

reviewText: Think this movie is ripping off Avatar (Movie and Cartoon), Star Wars, Dune, Stargate, Stardust, and Indiana Jones? You are looking at it backwards. The John Carter of Mars novellas began in 1912, written by Edgar Rice Burrows. All of these movies and shows this movie seems to be copying are actually copying the original story of John Carter. That's why Disney wanted this so badly. This is the story everyone else is ripping off. Even the anime El Hazard is ripping off this series, but you have to understand that "Imitation is the Sincerest form of Flattery". So keep in mind that this story is over 100 years old, and enjoy the nostalgia your great-grandparents can enjoy knowing this was 1st.Also, for you science geeks: The movie stays true to the story, so even though we now know Mars is covered in ice, no one knew that in 1912. It's a period piece, and there's no evidence they're truly on mars. They just assume that because the star-charts match that it is. Also no one knew about gravity and spacial effects, so Burrows is actually thinking ahead of the curve at the time.
summary: Before you see The Movie, know the book came out before anthing you'll recognize in it.

reviewText: This isn't as close to the book as I would have liked, but was an acceptable deviation from it. It kind of combines Princess of Mars, with God's of Mars, though of course the Thern involvement is 90% different than the books. Kind of weird that Deja is a scientist! But I didn't read the books and didn't watch the movies because of her, but because of John Carter and Burrough's Mars.Strange that it didnt do better in the theaters, which means probably no future installments. It is a very enjoyable Sci-Fi/Fantasy action movie.UPDATE; I see that many more reviews have been added since I first wrote mine and the average score has increased. Its funny that this did so 'poorly' in the theaters. Hopefully the filmmakers will see that its really a popular movie after all and reconsider a sequel. Maybe if they didn't only define 'success' as what makes them a fortune. If a movie pays for itself after a year (I don't really know if this one has) and also provides a modest profit, why wouldn't that be good enough? Studios should be in the business because they want to serve the public in this way, not just for piles of profit.
summary: I like it a lot even though it departs from the book considerably

reviewText: First I rented this movie then I bought it to watch it a second time (and probably more). This movie is what adventure sci-fi should be but all too often fails to be. Too many sci-fi movies have cranked up the gore and correspondingly lowered the storyline and intellect to minuscule amounts. Adventure sci-fi is about science and thinking and wonder as much as it is about adventure. This movie should be thought of as an excellent blend of Dune and Star Wars. Mix some sci-fi adventure with romance, and then carefully blend in an intriguing measure of mysticism to create a drink well worth sipping more than once.  Enjoy! My only regret is that since this movie was not a box office smash the sequels based on the books written by Edgar Rice Burroughs may not get made.
summary: I'd give this movie ten stars if I could!

reviewText: I'm a Huge fan of Edgar Rice Burroughs Mars Books and the Mars art of Frank Frazetta too, so this sword & martian Princess-lousy project is dear too me. Without Carter there would never have been a Flash Gordon or Buck Rogers, but as result the promise seems cliched now, Hell!..even Superman's super leaping is direct from JC, Lucas' flying sand barges & Leia's Princess of Mars look... all ERB.... in addition to that concern the project has changed hands so many times since 2004, Robert Rodriguez who upon leaving the Directors Guild became ineligible, then kerry Conrad,  the director of the retro "Sky Capt. Film" ,the late Frazetta was on board  , the initial budget was 100 mil , currently Jon Favreau  was replaced by Andrew Stanton (who may never have directed a live action film before). So I'm concerned. Over all great stuff, sadly for DvD it needs to be seen on a big screen,  Mostly the story sticks to the Princess of Mar story that introduces John Carter, an ex-confederate soldier to Mars a.k.a. BARSOOM and to super powers maybe even a new  cause to fight for.
summary: 100 year milestone marked with a strong effort and a fun Sci-Fi tale

reviewText: It's a huge shame that the public have heeded a few nasty critics and not gone to see John Carter in theaters! I LOOOVE this movie! I've seen it five times and want to go again! It's been years since I enjoyed a film this much and missed it so much in between viewings that I couldn't wait to go again! The cast is fabulous, the story smart and not dumbed down, but so thrilling it totally pulls you in! If you're a fan of the original books written 100 years ago by Edgar Rice Burroughs, or if you've never even heard of the story John Carter is based on, you will enjoy this movie! It's epic and even if people don't go see it in theaters, they will discover its magic on DVD / Bluray after and regret having waited! It's definitely a film that is best viewed on the Big Screen! It is sad that it didn't reach blockbuster status, as it should have, but John Carter is headed for cult classic status! Go Barsoom!! :D

reviewText: So sad this movie didn't do better at the box office! It is really beautifully done. Excellent cast, acting, dialogue, story and great special effects. I'm old enough to remember when the paperbacks and artwork for John Carter, Dejah Thoris, Tars Tarkas, etc, looked very cool to me. All of the actors did great jobs with their parts. I was especially effected by the beautiful Lynn Collins as Dejah Thoris. I found myself thinking, "all the actors were great in this movie, but how did they get an ACTUAL princess of Mars down here to Earth to star in one of our films? Hah! Anyway, this movie deserved much better success in theaters and to call it a dud just seems like complete nonsense to me.I would say that choosing the name "John Carter" instead of "John Carter of Mars" was a mistake (though I can think of a couple reasons why they might have done that), and my recollection of the marketing for the film seemed sort of weak or unfocused. Beyond that, I'm sort of at a loss at the failure of the film to do well. Just bad luck for everyone involved in its making. I sure hope Disney continues with this series.

reviewText: 4.5 starsI'd never heard of this until I saw it always rented at the local dishbuster. So I grabbed the blu-ray when it was finally available and was surprised at how entertaining John Carter was. So I check good old Rotten Tomatoes, and what?! 52%?! I'd expected 80 at least. So I read the reviews and laughed at how few critics can just relax and enjoy well-made Flash Gordon-style escapism. Then I come here and voila, 4.5 stars. Why is it that the aggregate movie score here is SO often how I too feel about most movies? I guess my tastes are more typical than I'd like to think...John Carter is just fun, and great-looking fun. The leads are both very solid, with decent chemistry (somewhat Han/Leia-ish, but then Lucas took lots from ERB), and fine stage actors like Hinds and Purefoy (see them together in the great Mayor Of Casterbridge if you're a fan of great acting) add an unexpected amount of solidity to a very spacey story.I love Burroughs' style and read most of the Tarzans and his sci-fi as a kid, and I think this film really does him justice. I wasn't surprised to learn it was done by the guy who did Wall-E, the wisest animated film of the last decade. ERB's wild flights of fancy and crazy creatures come to life here, and who could resist a six-legged wildly loyal space-dog?Dafoe is perfect in his semi-animated role and the look of his species and this film in general is absolutely knockout on blu-ray. Incredible colors and detail. Along with the story, the eye candy and visual feel reminded me of so many of the best sci-fi/fantasy flicks, especially Star Wars and the first Indy, no small compliment.And I truly enjoyed Kitsch, who I'd never seen. His name must delight critics looking to be snide, but I found him fun and dead-on, like Buster Crabbe but better. And if you got that reference, dang you're old! If you didn't, go see what great kitsch you've missed. Director Stanton clearly did not, and made a film that's so epic and so fun that I think it will be a true cult classic as time goes by. "The one that the critics missed out on entirely!"PS The blu-ray is most fine indeed, with not only a perfect transfer but some good extras including a funny making-of that downplays the crazy 250 mil budget, but shows why the money turned into a truly mind-blowing visual experience.It ain't Shakespeare, but it's great Saturday-afternoon pulp sci-fi.

reviewText: Pundits are saying the movie launched and crashed.  It opened in North America at $30.6 million and another $70.6 million overseas -- which is 80% of the movie market.  It is ENTERTAINING.  Isn't that what movies are supposed to be.  Any moron who thinks this movie rips off George Lucas has a history lesson coming: the story was written by Edgar Rice Burroughs ONE HUNDRED YEARS AGO.  Gee, the same year the guy created a little known character named Tarzan.  If $250 million was spent by Disney it was all on the screen. It looks great, it moves along well.  Taylor Kitsch is fine as John Carter and Lynn Collins makes the most beautiful Dejah Thoris.  Willem Dafoe is wonderful as Tar Tarkus.  Dominic West is perfectly slimy as the villain.  The film does itself a favor by advancing elements from GODS OF MARS -- the evil Therns.  Look forward to seeing John Carter of Mars again!  A pulp fiction fan since I was 15, this movie sadly says what CONAN THE BARBARIAN could have been.  Look forward to the sequels and -- one day -- del Toro's vision of H.P. Lovecraft's AT THE MOUNTAINS OF MADNESS.
summary: Be seeing you for GODS OF MARS

reviewText: I'm not sure how this movie got by my radar.  I suppose the boring title might be to blame.  The original "A Princess of Mars" tag probably would have caught my attention better, but I suppose they were trying to avoid alienating the insecure male audience out there who avoids anything with a "feminine" title.What a pleasant surprise this movie is!  I enjoyed it far more than Avatar (which probably isn't a fair comparison, for I wasn't much impressed with that film).  "John Carter" definitely has a better story and is overall more engaging and exciting, with excellent production design, music, costumes, pacing, good casting, cool aliens, beautiful ships and sets, and doesn't take itself too seriously, giving the audience lots of humorous moments.  It's also, I think, good for a wide range of ages (should be OK for most kids, but it's NOT just a kid's movie).  It's exciting and engaging - imagination gone wild.I'm stingy with 5 stars, and this isn't perfect.  But as 4 stars means simply "Like It" and 5 means "Love It", I had to swing more towards the latter.  Why this didn't make it into the category of "blockbuster" is beyond me.  What's going on with critics and audiences these days?  It's just getting harder and harder to comprehend why really good movies seem to keep getting brushed aside in favor of shallow eye-candy films (or, contrarily, over-wrought dramas) that win awards.  :/  This should win some awards.

reviewText: I tried to approach John Carter as someone who had not read the books. But I HAD read the books so it was somewhat disorienting to see all the familiar characters and settings but an almost entirely different story. Unlike some, I didn't have a problem with this John Carter's attitude problems, but Dejah Thoris failed to charm me. Of course the "Incomparable" princess was never more than a raison d'etre in the books anyway so I didn't expect much. I have to say, the VFX were stunning and very true to the books (except Woola was too cute) I just didn't get some aspects of the story and few explanations were given. For instance, why was the city of Zodanga a big moving pile of metal? And, why bring Therns into the plot when they clearly weren't necessary? I have other questions that will never be answered but those are important, sort of. As an action/adventure film it was compelling if a little disjoint and It's too bad there won't be a sequel. I'd like to see more character development and perhaps the other two Barsoomian races (Yellow & Black), but I'll manage. I really think it's a film worth watching. Mostly because it's visually stunning.

reviewText: It is a shame this film did not do better in the theater. I saw it once and went back to see it 2 more times. I have only done that with 3 other film, Avengers, Serenity and Avatar. This film was great! It had so much more than the trailer showed. I was not familiar with the Barsoom books or that they had been written by the same author as Tarzan. This film has adventure, humor, romance and stunning visuals. It is just as entertaining and engrossing as Avatar. The film title, trailer, failed marketing and launch date in March was its downfall. This should have been titled John Carter and the Princess of Mars. It should have been a summer or Christmas holiday launch, not March. And the trailer should have been edited to encompass more of the humor and romance. I'm sorry but if you spend over 200 million making an epic blockbuster you should treat it as such. I hope Disney makes up in DVD sales. I know I'll buy myself a copy and 4-5 more for Christmas gifts to friends and family. I feel a bound duty to get the word out: Watch this film. Buy the DVD! You won't regret it.

reviewText: I just went and saw the best movie I have seen since Star Wars came out in the early 1977.  In fact this story by Edgar Rice Burroughs called a Princess of Mars was the main source of many ideas that Lucas used to make Star Wars.  The movie is called John Carter, whom is the main charter of a Princess of Mars and many other Mars stories by Burroughs.  The movie is simply great!  Very close to the book, there are a few changes from the book, but Disney Studios did a much better job of being like the book than most movies do.  You can see this movie in either 2D or 3D, and I assume that will be true of the DVD as well when it comes out.  We went to the 2D and are going back to see the 3D this weekend.  Just though I would pass this on.

reviewText: I read the Barsoon novels by Edgar Rice Burroughs when I was a kid, as classic science fiction adventure from the early 1900s. I liked them better than his better known Tarzan books.  Barsoom was a fantastic world with amazing creatures that would be hard to bring to a movie other than through animation, although many filmmakers had wanted to for decades.  Until Computer Graphics advanced to the level where such creatures could be created and look realistic, any such movie would look cheesy.Andrew Stanton, director of Finding Nemo and Wall-E, was able to construct a movie in this wonderful world, but he slightly modernized the story -- the original story would not have been appreciated by modern audiences -- but Stanton kept the spirit of Burrough's books.  He gave Carter a better back story, of a confederate Calvary captain whose family had been killed and whose home had been destroyed.  Stanton provided a better explanation for the fantastic elements of the story -- a reason why Carter was transported to Mars (known as Barsoom to the natives).Taylor Kitsch was good as John Carter, not amazing, but good.  Lynn Collins, however, was a great Dejah Thoris, the Princess of Mars, who is an accomplished warrior and scientist, and an amazingly beautiful lady.  Mark Strong is one of the best "villain" actors today, and does a nice job in this film.  Willem Dafoe is the voice and provided the motion capture for Tars Tarkis, the "Jedack" of the Tharks, a race of tall, green, 4 armed savage people.This film was the victim of one of the biggest marketing mistakes ever.  The generic title should have been "John Carter of Mars" or "John Carter of Barsoom" or even just "Barsoom."  The advertising never mentioned that the movie was based upon the classic books by the author of "Tarzan."  The advertising never mentioned that the director had also made "Finding Nemo" and "Wall-E" (although, this film is nothing like those -- it is a classic adventure).  And most of all, it never explained that "John Carter" was based upon 100-year old books which had been the inspiration for most of the great science fiction adventure stories we have been watching for years -- even George Lucas admitted that the Barsoom books were a significant inspiration for "Star Wars."  The advertisements had the absolutely wrong tone, featuring some old slow song and clips that made the film seem like a copy of lots of other films without explaining that the other films actually copied from the Barsoom books.One of the big tragedies that this film failed to do well at the box office is that the sequels will never happen.  There were lots more great stories to tell about the amazing creatures and places in Barsoom, but we'll never see those stories unless a LOT of people keep buying the film on DVD, Blue-Ray or Streaming.
summary: Lifelong fan of the books, was thrilled to see "John Carter" come to life on the big screen

reviewText: This movie is worth seeing. Many reviewers have done an in depth analysis of the film, so I'll keep mine brief.Why only 4 stars?Weakness: Scripting. Plain and simply, I believe that the scripting is the sole reason why the film got panned by critics. The characters are very easy to read and will say exactly what they should say when they should say it. This was a huge weakness and left me curious about why Disney didn't vet this a little better. IMO If the scripting was fixed up and the characters were a bit more.. unique.. it would have made this a 5 star blockbuster. As is, this is pretty much my only complaint about the film.Acting:The acting is well done. The characters interact well and they are very in the moment. However, the script that they seemed to follow to a T is once more the weakness.Filming: It's beautifully filmed. This is definitely some eye candy. I have not yet seen it in 3D, but the 2D version was good enough that I would bet that the 3D version is awesome.Plot: The plot was great. I have watched this film a number of times and enjoyed it during each sitting. I'm happy to say that this did not have the same issues as the scripting.Summary: It's definitely worth a watch. Hopefully Disney sees how well this film is doing on Amazon and decides to create the sequel that we all want to see; albeit with a new team working on the script.

reviewText: I bought a ticket to another movie, but had to wait an hour, so I thought I would pass time watching John Carter.As JC began I became swiftly swept up in it, forgetting the other movie entirely, as I was so transported.If you're like me and like movies such Star Wars,  I think you will love this movie. I'm not suggesting that it's better than Star Wars, but I certainly enjoyed it than some Star Wars movies.Like many movies our hero John Carter starts out in the ordinary world, in this case, earth slightly after the civil war.  Our hero, a former soldier now disillusioned, has lost his purpose. Now the army attempts to conscript him into service.  Being resourceful he escapes custody, stealing the captains horse, survives a showdown with Indians, seeks shelter in a secret cave with walls of gold.Something happens that transports him to a special world, Mars, with its own rules, where there is a power struggle, between two factions vying for control of the planet, which threatens the destruction of a group of giant indigenous green people, who ultimately become his allies.Quickly, he is taken captive, but in this special world with its different gravity he has special abilities, which impresses his captors.  Pretty soon he crosses paths with an extremely pretty princess, played by Lynn Collins, who has beauty, brains, and fighting skills.  She definitely is not your typical damsel in distress.  She also has an excellent suntan, sky blue eyes, and a most shapely figure.Though worlds separate him from the princess, as he crosses the distance quickly, we come to understand the loss that fuels his reluctance, and when you watch you will discover the cause that fuels his purpose.I have always loved the Tarzan stories by Edgar Rice Burroughs.  As a child I would sit in a tree and stop traffic with my blood curdling Tarzan impersonation.  I was unaware that he had also written the John Carter series.This story follows the same mythological pattern set out by Joseph Campbell in his book The Hero has a Thousand faces.  George Lucas followed this template in creating the Star Wars series, and other movies that follow this pattern include The Matrix,  Batman Begins, and Wanted.  John Carter follows yet precedes the pattern, as the book series was written before Campbells book.Stages of the story include a hero called to adventure, refuses the call, something happens to draw him into adventure, meeting the mentor,  meeting the goddess, crossing the threshold, allies, trials and tests, the inmost cave, mastery of both worlds etc.I loved the imagination and the creation of all these Martian characters.Disney was disappointed with its opening weekend gross of $30 million, which tracked several million below expectation.  Supposedly, the movie cost $250 million to make, but I always take these figures with a grain of salt.  The more expensive the movie is, the more impressed people will be, the more likely people are to watch, so figures can easily become inflated.  I think word of mouth will help this movie enormously.If one likes to be swayed by beauty, then one might enjoy the performance of Lynn Collins. I realised early in the movie, that she had not just beauty but a commanding presence, charisma, and acting talent.  In fact she has a strong grounding as a Shakespearean actor, having appeared in Merchant of Venice with Al Pacino.  I did not recognise her because she had different hair, played a man for at least a portion of that movie, and had a Venetian pallor instead of a Martian suntan, or perhaps a Los Angeles spray tan.So, it's nice to see the studio not cast a name but cast a great talent.I loved this movie.  I think most people will, and I hope this was helpful.
summary: A small step for Martians.  A giant leap for Mankind

reviewText: I grew up reading E. R. Burroughs novels.  Very original in locales and dependable story lines.  This movie is so close to recreating the world ERB created a century ago.  Fun action and eye-popping effects and scenery.  The biggest limitation with the novels was how the hero travelled back-and-forth between Earth and Mars.  The movie addresses this in a much better way but might put-off loyal ERB fans.  Let's face it, the reason we talk about green men from Mars is due to ERB.  Don't take it too seriously and enjoy the movie!
summary: Good attempt at a classic novel

reviewText: The only reason this bombed was because the producers did not know what to do with it. Movie-goers are mostly poorly read in classic science fiction, not knowing they were watching the inspiration for everything from Destination: Moon to Avatar. By the time this movie came out all those other hits had stolen from E. A. Burroughs' classic series. No one knows that when they watched this great production they were watching classic science fiction history. The director should be commended for his great work. The casting was superb, the production values were, at worse, phenomenal, while the only thing they were not faithful to was that the red Martians wore no clothes at all in the John Carter series. I can live with that! The failure of this movie indicts the illiteracy of the American movie public.
summary: John Carter: The Unsung Hero and Movie
Title: N/A

reviewText: I just saw the John Carter film, and I have to say, being a HUGE Edgar Rice Burroughs fan for well over 35 years, this film captured the essence of the Mars series.Although in true Hollywood fashion the film was much different than the original 1st novel - A Princess of Mars - it still managed to get a lot of things right. The filmmakers took several of the concepts and put them in the 1st film, and actually managed to do a credible job. Unfortunately, for people who go to see this film and don't know what the mars language terminology are or means, they may get a little lost. For ones such as I, then they are in for a treat!Director Andrew Stanton and his crew DO manage to create the look and feel of the long-awaited John Carter of Mars movie. The actors are excellent. Especially Lynn Collins as Dejah Thoris and Willem Dafoe as Tars Tarkas. Although Taylor Kitsch did a swell job, I'd much rather have seen Hugh Jackman tackle the role of John Carter. But Taylor did a solid performance.The director did an outstanding job of crating the old-fashioned pulp sci-fi/fantasy feel of the film, while injecting state-of-the-art special effects. The overall look of the film is tremendous.At heart I am a purist when it comes to my boyhood novels and comic books come to life on film. I usually hate it when filmmakers change the scripts they make into films are so vastly different. Rarely do they get it right. (The latest Conan the Barbarian is a perfect example!)And making a huge film like this from a literary giant such as Burroughs, (Yes, he was wayyyy before Tolkien, even!)was not an easy task. But, this time around, they get a hall pass from this gigantic fan. Stanton and his crew kept a lot of the heart of the Burroughs books, and much of the storyline in the 1st book.I hope this movie is a success. It deserves to be. Why? Because you can see that the director had his heart and soul in this, his very first live action movie. For a first-timer, he tackled a major sci-fi/fantasy movie. Not an easy task. He must have balls of steel. And, for the most part, he pulled it off.This begs for a sequel. Because for you people out there that don't know any better, the ending of this film, where John Carter goes back to mars, has him not going back to the arms of his beloved Dejah, but lost in the wilds of mars, where many years have passed, and his beloved wife and son are in extreme danger - as is the entire planet of mars.Now THAT would be a sequel that would not only withstand the age of time, but of movie audiences.
summary: Burroughs is Back on the Silver Screen!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I just saw "John Carter" and I liked this film very much! Long long time ago, when I was a teenager, I read some of the Edgar Rice Burroughs novels in the "Barsoom" series (Barsoom means Mars in Martian language) and I enjoyed them greatly. And thanks to this movie, I just relived again this experience and I could enjoy a little bit of the old magic. Burroughs books about Tarzan (he created this character) had quite a number of movie adaptations, but his Martian and Venusian series were considered for a long time too hard to film. Considering that the first book was written in 1912 and that the first plans to film it were made (without success) in 1931, it certainly took time to have a movie version of the first of "Barsoom" books - but considering the result, it was worthy waiting that long.Below I tried to describe the best things in this film, with as little SPOILERS as possible.1. John Carter from Virginia, a former captain of Confederate cavalry. For my personal taste Taylor Kitsch pictured him quite well, and the scenario describes him like in the book, as a man courageous, strong and aggressive but also noble, faithful and clever. Unlike in some other action movies I found this hero quite LIKEABLE - he is a little bit grim and sullen in the beginning, but we soon come to understand why and frankly he has reasons to be in such a state of mind. His progressive awakening to a second chance in life is credible and a pleasant thing to watch.2. Dejah Thoris from Helium, the Princess of Mars. Actually, the first book in "Barsoom" series, of which this film is the adaptation, had for title precisely "A Princess of Mars", as Dejah Thoris is a character as important as John Carter. In the film, in my opinion her character completely steals the show and it is in large part due to the excellent performance of Lynn Collins. Whoever cast her in that role was a genius! Her Dejah Thoris is an excellent mixture of an Amazon (courage and strength), a scientist (brains and learning) and an aristocratic young lady (pride and manners), like in the books.But it is not all. Lynn Collins added to all this a personal touch which made Dejah Thoris also a very feminine character, in the best sense of the term. Although she can swing the sword and pilot the warships as the best male warriors of her country, she also can display a moment of girlish cheerfulness and enthusiasm, smile in a way which melts the hardest hearts, give looks filled with an almost motherly warmth and tenderness (and also a purring promise) and walk in such a way that all males in the assistance are almost howling! I particularly appreciated the fact that when sharpening her sword she simply couldn't resist to look on the blade, check her make up and preen a little... And then, there are short moments when we perceive a brief glimpse of vulnerability - and at that moment she is even more impressive.The fact that Ms Collins is a very beautiful woman with an exceptional figure only adds to her performance - also her clothes, body paintings, haircut, makeup and jewelry were perfectly well chosen! And I really believe that her model of wedding dress should be MANDATORY on Earth - the number of men willing to marry would probably explode overnight as the result! Frankly, when she appeared in her wedding dress, the male part of the public gasped - and in the same time many girls in the cinema started to emit noises similar to those made by a very angry rattlesnake when choking on a half swallowed chinchilla...)))To resume, Lynn Collins pictured a Dejah Thoris so PERFECT and so faithful to the one imagined by Edgar Rice Burroughs, that I had a feeling of "Dejah Vu" (sorry, I couldn't resist...)3. The Tharks, desert warriors. Excellent. I found every scene with Thark tribe a delight. The characters of Tars Tarkas and Sola are very well done and played. The Woola "dog" is simply too cute and extremely funny - every scene when it appears was welcomed by a big laughter in the cinema.4. Other special effects. This film was very costly and you can really see the effects on the screen. The mobile city of Zodanga, walking through the desolate deserts of Mars is really impressive. The flying warships are excellent. The gigantic White Apes are really impressive and scary. The city of Helium is very beautiful. And finally, the panorama of Mars is really well done - one can immediately see that this world was once full of life, but it is now dying and in dire need of help...5. Dominic West. He plays a scoundrel - again. I must admit that I have a weakness for this actor, since watching him in "The Wire", but also the "300" and "Centurion". Here his role is not as important as it could be, considering that he is not exactly THE main villain (it is not exactly a spoiler - we learn it in the first scene of the film). But it is still a pleasure to watch him.6. Difference with the books. There are many small and one HUGE difference with the "Princess of Mars", concerning the race of Therns, who in the book do not play an important role - in the "Barsoom" series they really appear in later books. But I believe this HUGE change for once was a rather good thing, as it allows for a more logical explanation of John Carter's travels from Earth to Mars. The smaller differences didn't hurt the movie either.7. The ending is quite good, not stupid at all and rather moving. And that is something not so frequent in modern Hollywood movies. Good job for this one!Bottom line, I liked this film a lot and I am certainly going to buy it as soon as it is available - preferably in Blu-Ray, because here the quality of image has its importance. And I will certainly go to see the sequel if there is one, for many obvious reasons but especially because I am DYING to see how they would solve the little problem of Martian reproduction - because you see, in the books, when John Carter and Dejah Thoris are married, she lays him an egg...)))
summary: A good film, but the title should be  The Princess of Mars , because Dejah Thoris completely steals the show!

reviewText: It's been many years since I read the Edgar Rice Burroughs novels on which this movie is based, so I have no good comparisons between book and film to offer. The consensus among my sci-fi fan friends is that this movie was much better than the reviews or the marketing campaign Disney mounted to sell it. I've seen "John Carter" on at least one worst-of-all-time film lists; I don't think it belongs there. It's a pity that we're unlikely to see more installments from Burroughs' Mars novels.There's plenty of eye candy of both the human and CGI sort, and the plot is engaging enough for the genre. We've watched it several times, and bought the 3D version when we upgraded our TV early this year.
summary: A Poorly Marketed Popcorn Flick that's actually Fun to Watch

reviewText: Please note that I saw this on a movie channel so I can't comment on the quality of the DVD transfer or its features.First  of all  this movie is just spectacular visually. Even in this day of CGI miracles this is truly one of the most visually exciting movies of recent years. Even the most jaded fan of CGI will find something to like here. I thought the whole movie was just beautifully done. The exotic, desert-like environment (no doubt shot in the Southwest) of Mars was superbly realized.Other pluses:Strong supporting cast with actors like Mark Strong who excels at playing heavies and courageous bad guys.The ornithopter like flying machines, which ranged from little flitters to bigger battle cruisers, were terrific. A bit like the 'thopters in Dune but more like dragonflies with their glassy wings. Another beautiful special effects job on that.The costumes were another visual feast. I usually don't notice clothing that much but the outfits were just inspired, both men's and women's. It added to the exotic ambience of the Red Planet. It reminded me of the lavish costumes 30 years ago in the Sci Fi movie, Flash Gordon.The 100-mile an hour salamander-like creature who takes a liking to John Carter is a hoot. I want one.An exciting plot with many dramatic twists and turns. I saw some reviews that said the plot was boring. All I can say is stop taking those bong hits while watching a movie, it might improve your attention span.Lots of cool, miscellaneous special effects, such as the energy fields and matrices that appear here and there throughout the movie which were well done and put to good effect.Exciting battle and fight scenes. The humanoids like the 12-foot tall, four-armed Tharps were another plus.I only read one or two of Burroughs's books and that was 45 years ago but I still had a basic knowledge of the story line. I don't know how the Burroughs fans liked it but I thought the movie did justice to his concept of Barsoom (Mars). Overall, a visually stunning, beautiful, and dramatic realization of Burroughs's Mars and a great family movie for a slow Sat. night.

reviewText: For a science fiction movie from Disney, I loved this story!  It moved at a good clip, and Taylor Kitsch was totally believable as the scrappy fighter who learns and adapts fast to life on Mars, amid their warring civilizations.  The CGI was seamless and well integrated, and thankfully enhanced but didn't overtake the story and actors.  The female lead was excellent as well, and I didn't understand why Disney - with all their fantasy princesses - didn't market the movie or the Princess of Mars better.  A terrific action/adventure Sci Fi story, ending with the twists and turns of a man desperate to get back to his new life on Mars, and using a little Sherlockian intrigue to do it.Not many people know this, but this story was written by Edgar Rice Burroughs - who also wrote the iconic "Tarzan."  "John Carter" started out as a magazine serial in 1912.  But it goes far beyond Sci Fi Pulp expectations, with Egyptian Gods/Goddesses, hi-tech weaponry, teleportation, and sinister other-dimensional spies who roam both Mars and Earth in shape-shifted form as civilization "managers".  TERRIFIC movie!
