reviewText: This was a good, solid adaptation of the Edgar Rice Burroughs source material. The film manages to capture the essence of the character and create a decent traditional adventure story. Everything is simple and straightforward driving the plot along. It would not be exceptional but for the fact that so many other film makers would not be capable of doing it. The film is exceptionally well paced aside from the beginning which takes forever to get going.Some changes were made to the source material. Mostly useless and unnecessary changes in my opinion that are each somewhat associated with modern obsessions:(minor spoilers follow)- Carter is given baggage and angst based on his civil war service. This wasn't necessary and thankfully the film minimizes it.- Rather than the ambiguity about how he got to mars that features in the books, we are offered in the film a definitive pseudo-scientific "alien technology" reason. I liked the original non-explaination of the book better but obviously people today would think that getting to mars through a cave is "silly" while talking about alien technology is the ultimate in scientific seriousness.- The conflict with the apaches is unnecessarly politically correct. It would have been enough to simply have the US Cavalry at war with the apache and use their attempts to draft carter to make him "man in the middle" in the conflict. But instead we are given apache pacifists who only start fighting after the army shoots at them.- One of the more silly elements is making Dejah Thoris into a scientist who is going to save mars through technology. First, at the heart of the original concept is that mars can only make progress when its peoples start working together. Making science the savior is against the basic concept. Second, its unnecessary baggage for the character. Someone obviously read the books, thought she wasn't a serious enough character and launched into overcompensation to "fix" it. It extends to the point of calling her "professor". There were ways to freshen up the character short of the blunt and overly obvious ways they decided to go about doing it.- The worst change is to the Therns. The Therns are changed from the useless reminants of the proud technological past of Mars into all-purpose world destroying alien villians. This was no doubt added because people who see films today want easily identifiable archtype villians. Making the Therns responsible for everything on Mars undercuts one of the basic themes of the book which was the fall of a civilization through a natural disaster and that bringing the people of Mars together was the only way to make things better. The message of the book has a certain amount of relivance to modern politics today. But of course the idea that there is an easily identifiable villian responsible for all problems is even more relivant to the paranoid world of 2012.The Therns should have been presented, in my opinion, as a disinterested small elite on the planet with technology, obsessed with intellectual and religious debate among themselves and no longer interested in the fate of anyone else.The idea of the Therns as manipulators wasn't a bad one. But they could have gone in a better direction with it. Having the Therns, for example, manipulating and pushing an agenda that they considered as improving mars as a whole but without regard to the consequences to individuals such as Dejah Thoris.If they do more films, they should keep the action strictly on Mars. Nobody wants "tarzan in new york" with Dejah Thoris playing Tarzan.Despite the lengthy comments, I liked the film and I like the fact that they given a blueprint for how to do an adventure film that others will hopefully take up.
summary: good adaptation but lots of questionable changes to source material

reviewText: Despite horrible marketing and worse box office, John Carter is a wonderful version of the tale of a Civil War veteran who finds himself on a Mars as imagined in the age of Verne and Welles. It is part western, part swashbuckling adventure, and part science fiction adventure. If you missed this movie while it was in the theaters, you should get the DVD. Besides, the movie version of Dejah Thoris, the Princess of Mars, is Helen of Troy, Cleopatra, and Elizabeth the First all in one, with the added bonus that she can kick butt.
summary: John Carter a Worthy, Epic Version of Edgar Rice Burroughs Other Great Series

reviewText: "John Carter" is a 2012 film version of the first of the eleven books of Edgar Rice Burroughs' classic Martian series. This review is based on watching the film at home on Blu-Ray.When the people who produced this decided to bring out a film version of a book which had first been published almost exactly a hundred years before ("A Princess of Mars: John Carter of Mars, Book 1" by Edgar Rice Burroughs was first been published in serial form in 1912 as "Under the Moons of Mars") and which had enormously influenced a great many subsequent sci-fi adventures, they must have known that there was a risk of critics and audiences saying "We've seen it all before" - because they had seen films and read books which shamelessly copied from Rice Burroughs' ideas.For exmple, Luke Skywalker's battle with the Rancor in "Star Wars: Episode VI - Return of the Jedi (1 Disc) [DVD]," and the similar scene with his parents and Obi Wan Kenobi in "Star Wars: Episode II - Attack of the Clones [DVD] [2002]," and indeed, just about every scene in a Science Fiction or Fantasy adventure in which the hero and/or heroine have to fight for their lives in front of an audience against huge, strange and terrifying monsters, are pretty much plagiarised from a scene in "A Princess of Mars" which is reasonably faithfully reproduced in this film with the credit (or blame!) finally going where it properly belongs.Sure enough, when it came out this film had mixed reviews from critics and some of the flak did appear to be accusations of a lack or originality, with one critic calling the film "derivative" and another saying that "everything in the movie has been done so many times before, and so much better." A slightly more positive comment along the same lines was that "just about every sci-fi/fantasy/superhero adventure you ever loved is in here somewhere."Even allowing for the fact that this particular criticism was rather unfair, there were a lot of critical  raspberries, and this film didn't do too well in the US box office. So when I rented this and sat down to watch it with my family I wasn't expecting anything too special, but we were pleasantly surprised.Edgar Rice Burroughs' tale of a Confederate Civil War veteran miraculously transported though space (and possibly time) to the red planet which we call Mars and its' inhabitants call Barsoom was created on film with a fair degree of respect but without taking itself too seriously. The airships of Barsoom, the giant green Tharks, the great cities of Barsoom, the heroic John Carter (Taylor Kitch), the brave and beautiful princess Dejah Thoris (Lynn Colins) and even Woola, Carter's loyal calot, (a Barsoomian creature the size of a shetland pony who acts like a dog) - it's all here.The action in the film flowed reasonably fast, the characters were well presented and there was some quite good humour.It's not the most brilliant film I've ever seen and the mixed reviews demonstrated that not everyone liked it, but my family did find this entertaining. As mentioned "A Princess of Mars" was the first of eleven Barsoom novels by Edgar Rice Burroughs: if the creators of this film ever manage to get the finance to have a go at making film versions of any the remaining ten books I will certainly watch them.
summary: Filn version of "A Princess of Mars"

reviewText: Despite that it was poorly marketed (the main reason I didn't see it on the big screen and now wish I had!), John Carter (of Mars) is a charming movie with the same hopeful message that I experienced in the book by Edgar Rice Burroughs which I enjoyed as a boy.  The aliens were entirely believable--perhaps occasionally more-so than their live acting counterparts but visually it was appealing and the action was character driven AND there was plenty of it.  They changed the storyline to make Burroughs' original epic more modern in terms of real-world knowledge without destroying any of the innocence about alien worlds that existed when he wrote it in the early part of the twentieth century.  Sadly, the title should have remained true to the book for die-hard fans and the absence of "Mars" in the final title seems to reflect ignorance on the part of the marketing team/people in charge, but if you enjoyed the book series for what it was (idealistic hero type romp) then you should enjoy this movie.And I give two thumbs up to the creators/animators and voices of the four-armed green-skinned martians who made the movie amazingly fun! (They should have earned a five out of five rating alone, but there were a couple of live-actors who could have used with some animating themselves, though even they were passably good.)
summary: Matched the charm of the original book

reviewText: This is a good action flick , and most people who see it will like it. As it is a VERY HIGH BUDGET flick. NO expense was spared and this was done as a labor of love to the classic john carter of mars books by Edgar rice borroughs.  Those books changed popular science fiction and influenced all that came later. Of course edgar is better known for Tarzan. But this is a good version of his books.  It is very well done and In 3d it looks stunning. However , like most 3d you get depth here and little that pops out at you. Those who expect that don't know what 3d is really about , and may be unsatisfied on that account.  Not me though , as I enjoyed this film immensely. The effects are fantastic , the sets are great and stick to the books. IT's got a cool monster dog character , and has that romantic streak in it that we all love.  A man falls for a princess and fights for her!.  It's got good versus evil as well. It is amazing this got made at all. And I salute the people who did this , as they beat the odds to get this to the screen. The removing of mars from the title may have hurt this movie , I don't know. But this is a movie you can watch with your family and it's exciting , and afterward you can give your kid a john carter book to read! As they still thrill even today. Of course it doesn't help that we now know that mars is a wasteland. but back when this was written , people were sure that canals were on mars, and cities too. But it doesn't matter , as it's a cool movie.  A good action film that you can watch with your kids as even the violence is not too graphic. It's similar to the star wars type of violence. give this one a chance!.  The extras include deleted scenes, and other documentaries.  And even a blooper real. 3d is the way to go , but it looks fine in hd alone too.
summary: this is a good 3d action flick,~

reviewText: The fact that this movie's title changed from "John Carter of Mars" to simply "John Carter" is symptomatic of how hard it is to sell the planetary romance genre to modern audiences.  And that's a shame, because planetary romance has already achieved commercial success in two major franchises.Sci-fi fans will recognize all the elements: an adventurer travels to a foreign land, faces hostile tribes of primitive aliens who wield considerably more power than the "modern" despots, earns their respect, and ultimately leads a rebellion in upsetting the old world order while winning the hand and heart of a princess. Sound familiar? Before Star Wars and Dune, there was Edgar Rice Burrough's Barsoom series.Here's the thing: planetary romance by modern standards is cheesy, shallow, and likely a tad racist if not misogynistic.  The "savage" races are often analogues for other cultures, women are trophies to be won, and the hero is usually a white guy.  In short...all the criticisms leveled at Star Wars. Modern audiences won't tolerate anything so overt, so the princesses are always tough - but they still need rescuing.  The princess of John Carter is no different; Lynn Collins plays the princess of Helium, Dejah Thoris, and as soon as we see her it's hard to ignore the fact that the girl is buff.  There's a reason her arms are so wiry, and it's refreshing to see that Thoris looks and feels like she could kill a man with a single sword stroke.But back to the titular hero.  He's a Confederate soldier with an awkward past on the hunt for gold.  The Han Solo of the Barsoomian universe, he's largely out for himself. In a world where he can jump fantastic distances and punch twelve-foot tall four-armed Martians to death, Carter is free to do as he pleases.  The only shackles binding him are the affairs of the heart, thus the importance of the princess and Carter's involvement with Thark leader Tars Tarkas (Willem Dafoe).  Their relationship gets off to a rocky start when Tarkas gets Carter's name wrong and insists on treating him like a pet.It's not long before Carter stops worrying about getting home and starts thinking about getting it on with the inventor/warrior/princess Thoris.  She's fleeing a pending marriage to rival despot Sab Than (Dominic West) that threatens to doom her kingdom.  Imagine Princess Leia never taking off the slave outfit from Return of the Jedi with more muscles and you get the idea.And that's the thing.  On the surface, John Carter seems like a copy of the films that have since imitated its source material. There's a loyal dog-like alien named Woola, an alien sidekick, and swashbuckling battles on hovering ships.  John Carter is epic, but it's a little late to a party it kicked off decades ago.Taylor Kitsch is a blank slate, playing Carter as a brooding and monosyllabic thug.  Carter might have spawned rough heroes like Han Solo, but Kitsch lacks Ford's easy charisma. Unfortunately much of the film rests on Kitsch's chiseled abs. The film soldiers on heroically without him.The special effects are effortless, which is no mean feat in light of four-armed aliens, four-armed apes, and six-legged everything elses. Dafoe is brilliant as Tarkas, Collins is alternately desperate and heroic as Thoris, and even Woola manages to not be too annoying.  The script is top notch, filled with humorous asides and character-building moments that swell along with the music.  It's just Kitsch that's the problem.  If you can look past Kitsch, this is a rollicking good beginning to what we can only hope is a trilogy that will make its grandchildren, like Star Wars, proud.

reviewText: In any great Western there's almost always a call to "hang `em high." In the case of John Carter, Disney's 2012 spaghetti western science experiment that call came too soon for the legions of now unemployed production and marketing staff who brought this overwrought and under thought budget busting  sci-fi-western-fantasy-romance-unintentional comedy to our midst only to see it subjected to a fusillade of critical pounding and countless empty theaters.Originally envisioned as a franchise for the studio with two sequels already planned, those plans were immediately scuttled as Carter's Martian adventure brought with it an extraterrestrial write-down of $175 million for the Mouse House.To be fair, I have to admit a rather perverse fascination for films that by any objective measure - really suck. Not films that started with an interesting premise but wound up sabotaged by a bit of odd casting and leaden acting (Waterworld?) but productions that failed dismally through self-inflicted head shots at every stage of development from concept, production, continuity and marketing.Within a ridiculous, convoluted miasma of Peckinpaugh meets Leone meets Lucas meets Roddenberry meets Spielberg meets The Princess Bride, John Carter had no chance to ever present a cohesive storyline. Born on earth in the early 19th century, incomprehensively transported to Mars and thrust into their civil war all while beguiling a sullen princess who is promised in marriage to an enemy overlord.In this deep space muddle, the required suspension of disbelief is never the problem, it is the suspension of belief that always intrudes on the film through absurd dialogue, nonsensical plot twists and action sequences that would make a video game programmer wince. My only salvation being the $30 multiplex ransom saved by viewing this mess on cable rather than in a deserted theater. Tough stuff from beginning to end.

reviewText: As a fitting 100 year anniversary homage to Edgar Rice Burrough's first hero and heroine, before Tarzan, Disney delivers with the big bucks, special effects and adventure fantasy, although Hollywoodish, that can appeal to longsuffering fans, old and new.I grew up reading this fantastic series and eventually all of ERB's books.  I believe this screenplay works off the set of the first three books, originally written as serials: A Princess of Mars, The Gods of Mars and Warlord of Mars. Let me just say that although this movie is a different story than the books, it stays pretty faithful to the original elements and characters.The title John Carter of Mars was the 11th book of the series.  No biggie, one needs the name.  But here the hero, unlike the solid Virginia gentleman of the book, carrys a nightmarish back story, and overall, he's in it just for the gold.  Typical Hollywood.  Where the moviemakers redeem themselves are in the effects, the great visuals of Mars, and the fun characterizations.The actors are well chosen.  Willem Dafoe is the voice of the savage but noble Thark, Tars Tarkas.  They include a cute but ferocious and fast, Woola, Carter's Martian 'dog' or calot; they show Carter struggle, like Toby Maguire in Spiderman, with his new found leaping ablilites on Mars; the Princess is beautiful, exotic but willing and wanting to fight.  Like the novels, there's an uncertain romance in the air.My favorite scene, as in the books, is when John Carter is fighting the massive hordes coming down against him, jumping and leaping, sword flashing with faithful Woola at his side, slicing the enemy in such great numbers that the bodies pile up into ever growing mounds of dead flesh.  Sounds more gruesome than it is shown on screen.The movie's a visual feast, and for those of us who have waited for decades for the film to be made, and made extremely, high budget and all, well, I am overjoyed and totally willing to overlook the changes in story.  The heart of Edgar Rice Burrough's beloved Mars beats red as ever, and we can only hope for more.

reviewText: Considering how so many people, and critics, pulled the arms off of John Carter and stomped on him until he was dead, I think it still has some life on Blu-ray.  I don't recall if I read the novel when I was a youngster, but it has a feeling of being pretty true to its source.  I do seem to recall that the novel's character was a civil war soldier who awoke on Mars.  And adding Edgar Rice Burroughs, the original novelist, to the film was a cute touch.  Yes, the film does resemble many other epic FX movies out there, but I thought the special effects dept did an incredible job with the Tharks.  Movies have come a long way in just a dozen years with regards to special effects.  As far as adventures goes, it's a fairly enjoyable story.Part of the problem with the film, though, is the casting.  The leading man is bland, and he and the leading lady never established any kind of chemistry on camera.The 3D in the film looks terrific at times, but then in some him/her two-shots it looks flat.  In retrospect, I am thinking the parts that looked best were those shots processed through a computer (crowd shots, long shots, special effects).  I know there have been some who said the 3D was terrible, but through a pair of passive glasses, it looked pretty good on the whole.The 7.1 audio was excellent.The extras (which are on the regular Blu-ray disc) include a history of the novel to film, a few bloopers (too few), and a day on the set (this was well done and ran about 35 minutes).  Also there is an opportunity to hook up your iPad or computer to look at a second screen of background material while watching the film.  To me, this is something that they should have done on your TV while watching the film.  By moving it to an outlying device, you increase people's frustration and at the same time by putting it to an iPad or computer it cuts out the chance for more than one person to view it at a time.  There was also a commentary which I didn't listen to because the director did so much talking about the film in the disc extras that I was pretty tired of him.
summary: Better than I expected. 3D very good at times, but other times flat.

reviewText: As a kid I loved the Tarzan comics and I'm pretty sure I've seen every movie about Tarzan ever made.  But I never knew Edgar Rice Burroughts also wrote the John Carter series of books.  In this the first, in what I'm sure the Disney folks hope won't be the last of many films about the character, I'm a bit conflicted.  The film tries to pull together elements of "Avatar", "Star Wars" and "Cowboys and Aliens" and even the TV series "Hell on Wheels."  It partially succeeds.Carter (Taylor Kitsch, TV's "Friday Night Lights"), a Civil War veteran from Virginia, seeks his fortune in the West by searching for gold shortly after the war.  In an unnecessary sequence he is imprisoned by the controlling military Colonel (Bryan Cranston, "Drive") because he doesn't want to fight the local Apaches.  Escaping, Carter finds his way to a cave, filled with gold.  He also finds a medallion that when rubbed, sends him to the planet Barsoom.  We know it as Mars.  Forgetting what science now knows, Mars has breathable air and has a temperature appropriate for bare skin.  It also has a gravity pull much less than Earth, so Carter develops some unique abilities including heighten strength and jumping.Carter first meets local 4 armed, green inhabitants headed by Tars Tarkas (Willem Dafoe).  Eventually he makes nice with them and they become allies in a final battle against the evil-doers trying to take control of the planet.  Those bad guys are headed by Sab Than (Dominic West, "The Awakening") and his mystical shape-shifting mentor Matai Shang (Mark Strong, "Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy").  They are in a civil war against other humanoids headed by Tardos Mors (Ciaran Hinds, "The Debt") and his princess daughter Dejah (a delicious Lynn Collins, "X-Men: Wolverine").Directed by animated wizard Andrew Stanton ("Finding Nemo"), the story bogs down too often in order to provide info to the characters and the audience about who and what each tribe is about, how Carter got to Mars, how he's going to get back to Earth, what happened to Carter's family, etc.  For films of this genre, with many funny names and fantasy driven story lines, I found this pretty easy to follow.  When the battles begin, so does the fun.  The airships which look like huge dragonflies are very cool but not well built, so we see them crash often.The visuals and sound in the film are really exceptional and this is where the wow factor comes in.  The movie looks great.  The romantic relationship between Taylor and Dejah really never develops.  I'm sure it will if there are sequels, but here it remains a one night stand with no fleshy details.  "John Carter" doesn't achieve what it set out to do with its reported $250 million price tag, but has its moments and is certainly no worse than many other recent films of the genre.
summary: 3 1/2 stars for a visually stunning but underachieving fantasy

reviewText: John Carter is a very interesting and beautiful movie. The visual are outstanding, the actors are epic, the story is very well done, and the action is kick ass! I really enjoyed the love story that is intertwined, because this makes it not only a mans movie, but also a great date night movie. The 3D was very well done worth gear depth throughout, though if you are looking for pops this movie has very few, but the depth really does immerse you in the movie. This movie has a very big Star Wars influence, which is why I am rather surprised that Star Wars fans didn't cling onto this movie and skyrocket it to stardom, but as you can see by the rating it has on here it has gotten a pretty large fan bar and deservingly so. I enjoyed every second off this movie and am very pleased I picked it up. reviewText: Ignore the critics! Good advice at any time but particularly worthwhile in regards to this film! JOHN CARTER is the following:1. A strong character-based adventure story2. Exciting3. Romantic4. Humorous5. Wildly Imaginative6. Visually astonishing (sets, costumes, props, architecture, vfx, animation etc.)7. Epic in scopeIf you enjoy any of the above, See This Movie!To non-fans of the originals: you don't need to know *anything* about the books to enjoy this movie, it's great for anyone!To fans of the originals: this is actually more faithful than the Jackson "Rings" trilogy. It is absolutely steeped in Burroughs. Stanton has managed to make a film that is 90% straight from the original texts but in a way that anyone can enjoy.In summation: John Carter is an instant classic, go see it ASAP!

reviewText: Many of you might not realize the history of this story.  Did you know that it was written by Edgar Rice Burroughs in a 11-volume Barsoom series of novels from 1912-1943?  Did you know that this story was written WAY before Star Wars or anything George Lucas, J.R.R Tolkien or James Cameron came up with?  In fact, this story probably influenced them and other big sci-fi & fantasy writers & movie directors while growing up!Keeping that in mind, you then start to RESPECT it!Now I knew this before I went to see it and I was totally impressed.In fact, it's what the new Star Wars 1, 2, & 3 should have been (God, those films were so BAD and I loved 4, 5 & 6)!The biggest problem with this movie was all in the marketing by Disney.Disney should have mentioned the history of this story and having the balls to say something like, "Before Star Wars, before Avatar, before The Lord of the Rings came an incredible story of an earth-man stranded in the middle of a fantastic war, on Mars", or something like that.Instead they flashed a bunch of action scenes from the movie, which was a very BAD idea.Because when I first saw the trailer, I knew that most people would have thought it just looked like a rip-off of Star Wars or Avatar, when in fact those stories probably ripped their ideas from John Carter.It's a shame because I doubt Disney will continue filming it because it flopped in the theater (hope that marketing team gets fired at Disney).But if you watch it knowing it's history, then you might come to enjoy and respect it.I thought it was a lot of fun, but of course not perfect.  There were very few parts of the film that were a tad bit boring, but the 3D and scenery were fantastic so it made up for those moments.  Acting was great, costumes were very good, CGI scenery was excellent and characters were believable.  A solid good sci-fi movie!I bought the 3D blu-ray and am thankful it's in my collection.  Hope you do the same.Thanks for reading my review.Peace and take care!
summary: What Star Wars 1, 2, & 3 should have been!

reviewText: This is an excellent adventure film. Interesting story and beautiful to watch. John Carter is an unusual character, sort of a haunted western film hero.The script is often clumsy and the film staggers around before it gets the story started. If they'd cut the first scene with the Mars opening and start in Victorian times, trimmed the John Carter cavalry scenes and cut Deja's first scene with the 9th ray, the story would move better, unfold with more suspense. It's confusing, the way the film tries to start three times. I think that stagger-start threw a lot of audiences.Even with the editing problems there are great alien characters, especially the pseudo-dog. Costumes, hair and makeup are beautiful, props and sets are fantastic. Nice twist at the end. I read all of ERB's John Carter books as a youngster so I was thrilled when the movie came out.What Disney did or didn't do for marketing is a mystery to me. They should have called it "A Princess of Mars." I know they bailed on this film too soon. Even with its flaws, you will enjoy this film.

reviewText: 2012 was a year of blockbusters for franchises in Hollywood.  There were major successes like Avengers, Dark Knight Rises, and the first Hobbit film.  Then we had several movies that were intended to start franchises, but performed so poorly that the franchises-to-be were put on hold.  In no general order, they were John Carter, Prometheus, and Snow White and the Huntsman.  The first, John Carter, is based on the novels by Edgar Rice Burroughs, one of America's greatest writers of science fiction.  Featuring a big ensemble cast full of up-and-coming stars, great special effects, a good story-line, and what should have been a big fan base, this movie almost flopped at the box office, leading to some turnover at Disney's corporate headquarters.  The end result was a quick transition to the home video market, where it has found success.  This two-disc version is one of several versions available for purchase, and for those without a 3-D capable TV, this is probably the best choice.  The movie quality comes across quite nice from beginning to end.  The film itself is beautiful, and is probably the best role so far for Texas native Lynn Collins.  Watching this movie, one can see that many of the top sci-fi films of the past 40 years have been inspired by the Barsoom series of novels.  For example, Collin's character, Dejah Thoris, is clearly the inspiration for Princess Leia.  Likewise the titular character of John Carter seems a good template from which to start Han Solo and Luke Skywalker.  All in all, a great movie.

reviewText: I can't figure out why the Disney people did such a poor job of publicizing this film, starting with thehumdrum and misleading title. reviewText: "John Carter" is limited not by what's in the movie, but what isn't. There's a lot to like here, as so many reviews point out. I'm a lifelong reader of Burroughs, and somewhat to my surprise, I instantly liked many of the ways in which the film fills out what can be pretty thin writing in the original novel. But this is only two-thirds of a movie, and really falls short in some important respects. John Carter himself needed and deserved much more depth as a character in order to move from page to screen franchise. Robert Downey's Sherlock Holmes shows how a novelized character can be developed into a film presence; John Carter makes it partway there, but the main character just isn't compelling. Ditto Deja Thoris, who ends up being personable and appealing, and well acted, but never the ultra-female force that she could have been. Did Disney require that she be kept under wraps (literally: clad in metal) when the modern screen calls for her to be unleashed? And the director never solved the problem of alien Tars Tarkas, who needs to come across as a strong individual but who in the film ends up as one of a beautifully-executed but relatively characterless army of Tharks. The result of these unrealized needs is a movie that never comes entirely to life, and which rarely excites or thrills, even though so much of what has been accomplished is impressive and cool. Ultimately, it's a fantasy that captures our eyes but not our minds, hearts, or belief.

reviewText: I am not one of those people who read the books as a young teenager and fell in love with them.  I'm one of those people who read the books as a young adult because they are a part of science fiction history and I felt I should know about them, and after reading them, thought, "Eh, they're okay."  Heavy on the adventure, light on the science.  As adventure stories, they're quite entertaining.It's been many years since I've read the books, but from what I recall, the movie captures the feel of the books very well.  Carter has his "super-strength" and "super-jumping" powers from the books (John Carter was a pre-cursor to Superman).  Like most modern big-budget special-effect laden Sci-Fi movies, this is designed to be seen in a movie theater and not on your TV set.  The actress playing Dejah Thoris is very attractive (but wears more clothes than in the books.  Hey, it's a Disney movie, what do you expect?)The green-skinned, 4-armed Tharks were just a little too comical looking, but I suppose since most of the humor in the film comes during Carter's stay with them, this fits.  Another viewer left the movie saying "I'm so confused," but the movie made sense to me, by and large, with the exception that the Thern's motivations aren't explained very well.  And since this is the 21st Century, they had to throw in a couple of lines related to environmentalism.All-in-all, not a bad film to see in a movie theater.  Watching it on a small screen will diminish the impact, as it always does for this kind of movie.

reviewText: I read the Princess of Mars several decades ago and remember it fondly.While this story is an adaptation of an adaptation, it turned out to be decent, much to my surprise. There is a bit of wooden dialog, but the "flavor" of Barsoom is well captured in this production. Being Disney, the mild lack of clothing for the Princess is understandable (she is naked in the novel).The action is typical of many of today's action stories, and that doesn't help when it comes to making this thing stand out. Bookended by John Carter's "literary" association with the author (Edgar Rice Burroughs), it doesn't end with the cliff hanger of the book (many of Burroughs series, including Tarzan, followed the same pattern -- boy discovers girl, boy loses girl, boy has to overcome almost impossible odds to save girl, only to end the story with boy and girl being again separated, despite their obvious love for each other). That same formula is repeated in the movie and it works well.While the "real" Dejah Thoris is young (around twenty), the actress in the film (Lynn Collins) did an admirable job playing her opposite Taylor Kitsch's John Carter, despite being older (thirty-something). Kitsch, himself, isn't too bad, but the performance is uneven. As a former rebel, wanting nothing to do with the Union Army in the American Southwest, he was tough and no-nonsense. Once transported to Mars, he became somewhat less rebellious, giving me the impression that I was watching two different characters. I wasn't sure if that was intended, but Carter of Mars (and the end of the film back on earth) reminded me more of Hugh Jackman in Kate and Leopold, rather than his tough as, well, nails Wolverine.Still, effects were good, CGI pretty much seamless, and okay Burroughs-esque story. A very strong three stars, rounded up to four.
summary: Not bad, given the reviews and poor theatrical performance

reviewText: The first 'adult' books I read as a child were Edgar Rice Burrough's adventures of John Carter on Mars in hardcover editions that belonged to my father. My 11 year old self was fascinated by the adventures of the post Civil War Confederate soldier on the red planet that transcended space and time. So like many pre-adolescent fans of the books, I was pleased that John Carter was coming to the screen after many false starts over the hundred year history of the books original publication.  To prepare for the release of the fllm, I reread the first few of the books in the series. Time and my own maturity did not make the books age well to my eyes. The writing was awful. The dialogue was Victorian and stiff. The dated morality almost laughable. Racism and sexism, though taken for granted in the 1910's, was disturbing.  I  understood that the books reflected the early 20th century age it was written in. 'A Princess of Mars', the first John Carter book, was written  in 1911 and published in a pulp magazine in 1912 with the title 'Under the Moons of Mars'.The books were written by a man who failed at every endeaver he ever tried. Burroughs grew up in the latter part of the 19th Century. His social and cultural outlook was painfully Victorian and he knew nothing of Mars nor of science, but he knew how to spin a good yarn that captured the imagination of young boys.After reading the first 3 books again, I realized why the books had never made it to the screen. It was not only a matter of the need for the art of the motion picture to develop believable CGI  but also how to change the book to appeal to modern senses and culture. How to you film a book that was terribly written but which captures the appeal of it by generations of horny adolescents. So the director and writers altered the story of John Carter and hoped for the best. In my judgement, they succeeded.'John Carter the Movie'  loosely follows Burrough's 'A Princess of Mars'. We are introduced to John Carter via the same method that Burroughs introduced him to his readers - through a story framing device. Burroughs inserts himself into the story as the nephew of the mysterious John Carter who has amassed a small fortune and dies in the mid-1880's. His uncle leaves instructions to his young nephew to follow his burial wishes exactly - to entomb his body in a mausoleum  that can only be opened from the inside. John Carter also leaves a journal of his astounding adventures for the young Burroughs to read. This story framing device was also used successful by Burroughs in his other great adventure series, the Tarzan books.Th framing device of storytelling is as compelling as it was in the original book though the plot has been altered from the start to fit a more modern and more  believable  interpretation of  the Therns (the movie's villians). No longer are the Therns the bald priestly white race of Mars. They may not even be from Mars. More story alterations follow.No longer does John Carter simply raises his arms to Mars in the Arizona desert and get magically teleported. He discovered a teleportation device instead.  No longer is he a confederate soldier searching for gold with a partner being chased by Apaches. He is escaping from the custody of US soldiers who stupidly shoot at a band of indians causing them to attack. A back story involving Carter's family is added to provide clearer character motivation for his subsequent actions.The film was doomed to fail at the box office no matter what. Fans would see a different story then their memories.  Movie goers would watch it and wonder what the fuss was about. It was just another superhero movie with great CGI on a Mars that could not possibly exist. (NOTE: I may be incorrect here but I remember that Burroughs plotted John Carter's magical transport to Mars and back to earth and back to Mars again as a trip that transcended both space and time; that Barsoom was a Mars of many thousands of years ago. His Barsoom was not a desert world but a dying world with fields of red grasslands and purple vegetation )The director, Andrew Stanton, has made a credible effort to bring the essence of Barsoom and the John Carter stories to modern audiences by extensive rewrites to the original story. Just look at who was assigned script writting tasks. Amoung the screenwriters are Michael Chabon and Colin Wilson. Predictably, the film did better overseas then in the U.S. where it was not the money making blockbuster that Disney hoped for. It was a tremendously over budgeted film but in what universe other than the unrealistic expectations of bloated Hollywood studios would a take of $271 million be considered a flop?This is actually a good film, no better and no worse that then the parade of other summer extravaganzas that the movie going public is subjected to. It is worth your time to see it.
summary: Good Rewrite of the first Barsoom Book

reviewText: The writings of Edgar Rice Burroughs have greatly influenced sci-fi over the last 100 years. With John Carter the long road of taking the series of novels to the big screen has finally been realized. The result is a decidedly mixed bag and one that won't exactly hold direct appeal to any particular age or demographic.Based on the first novel "A Princess of Mars" the story centers on John Carter who finds himself transported to Barsoom (Mars) where he becomes involved in a war between factions on the planet. While he has little interest in taking sides he eventually forms allegiances while attempting to find his way back home.The film starts on Earth and really struggles there. The scenes are dull and the relevance of them are totally unclear. Once on Barsoom it begins to get more interesting though even then the sense of discovery isn't as compelling as would have been anticipated. Eventually the action picks up, the story gets its hooks in, and improvement comes through the second half of the movie which delivers a surprisingly strong conclusion considering the earlier struggles in getting the audience emotionally involved.While that sense of discovery is lacking there is feeling of wonder and imagination that shines through. Given that the source material is so old it doesn't always translate well but that forward-looking nature is easily identified. There are some decent laughs to be had but it's generally focused on providing adventure and it does a sufficient job of that.The special effects are suitable when keeping in mind that they're trying to convey scenes written 100 years ago and that means they won't always come across as realistic as one would imagine now. Outside of that though the alien creatures look great. The 3D is ultimately unnecessary - adding some depth to scenes but otherwise not enhancing the experience significantly.Despite some dreadful spots - which early in the film include jarring scene transitions - somehow I ended up enjoying the film as a whole. It's a tough one to recommend, and I suspect there will be opinions that stretch completely across the board, but there is a unique nature about it that struck me as being commendable. As an origin story John Carter struggles to gain traction but eventually shows some promise which would bode well for any possible sequels to come.
summary: High on adventure but ultimately low on appeal.

reviewText: Kaor!!! I won't go into what the movie was about. There are plenty of reviews here that do that very well. Another won't mean that much. I have been waiting 50 years for this movie to come out and I, personally, was not disappointed one bit, despite some of the changes the writers/director made to the original story. In some instances, such as the increased fleshing out (no pun intended about the luscious Lynn Collins) of the character of Dejah Thoris from helpless princess to a more well rounded female personality, was a well founded idea and is proabably (again with the help of Ms Collins exceptional acting ability) part of the reason why everyone who raves about this movie really does so. As so many have said, she stole the movie from Taylor Kitsch. In the scene where he finally realizes he is on Mars, her superior acting ability makes him look superfluous to the scene, unfortunately for him. Don't get me wrong, I think he did a good job for his first starring role, but when placed next to a more seasoned actor such Ms. Collins or even Willem Dafoe as Tars Tarkas, he sadly loses out. I STILL LOVED this movie though, beginning to end.Now, the marketing campaign. I have heard that marketing heads have rolled as a result of the botched effort on this movie. As they should have. From the minute they decided to change the name from John Carter of Mars to just John Carter, it has been a marketing disaster. Several fan made trailers have made their rounds on the internet that did a MUCH better job of describing the story and marketing this movie than the so called professionals ever thought of. I don't know if the people in marketing put the fear of "Prince of Persia" into Andrew Stanton's head,and this was part of his reasoning for some of the changes, but I feel he bears some of the blame himself. Not for the movie. His movie is magnificent and I really wish there would be the sequels of Gods of Mars and Warlord of Mars, but just how everyone handled the selling of the movie. It saddened me so much to see only 4-5 people in the movie theater with me when it should have been packed. The movie has it's weak points, to be sure, but it's over all strengths far outweigh any weaknesses.None the less, I have already put in my notice with Amazon.com I want to be notified the minute this movie becomes available to order because I will definitely buy it.
summary: Loved the Movie - loathed the marketing

reviewText: Based on the sci-fi book by Edward Rice Burroughs, John Carter is the movie rendition of the book. The book for what its worth was decently written for the era (1930's) and with sci-fi at the time it was short and not highly descriptive or engaging in character development...which may be why John Carter is the way he is - (he was written that way). The movie is a fun Disney adventure and kicks off the John Carter of Mars series (of which there are 12 books or so). Disney did a good job overall bringing a so-so book to a fun movie with some great special effects and an epic environment on Mars...The 3D however was not so great and it's a shame that they took the effort to make the movie in 3D because it was a disaster from that stand-point. Again a fun adventure that surpasses expectations (based on the story it was based on). Don't expect a lot from the 3D aspect.
summary: A Princess of Mars! Only better

reviewText: This was a lot of fun and there was much admirable about it in terms of creating a fantasy world that was realistic without being cookie stamped CG effects. The high tech was made to support the story wonderfully rather than to exhibit itself and flaunt "wow -- high tech." That is okay too. I just saw Prometheus and loved the CG and based on that enjoyed the film despite very weak acting and embarrassing script. John Carter had a decent script and decent acting and with the great settings and characters combined it worked.If I were rating the critical professional critics I would give them one star rather than zero. The one star would be for meaty nit picking. Sure they found things to complain about that "one could." Why they bothered to get into a snit fit  over the sorts of problems they dragged out is curious. One almost gets the feeling they were trying to second guess each other. Phew!! Glad I didn't let them scare me away from the film. It may not be the Hope Diamond but it is a small gem. So, okay, maybe not for everyone.Okay Carter was not on the edge of your seat Terminator etc. etc. It was cute and nostalgic for old fashioned science fantasy and quite well enough done. I want to read the novel. I wish the DVD had more features that SHOWED how they did the make up special effects etc. The director/producer commentary was above average but left me wanting to see how they did some of their tricks. I hope there is a sequel and maybe they will add this sort of special feature.
summary: one star for the critical pro critics

reviewText: Old John Carter fan here, ever since I was 12 or 13. I was thrilled to hear they made a movie, but disappointed by the result. The tricks are good, but then all CGI is good these days. they tried to mix various books together here and cramped too much into the movie so there's no plot development just a number of scenes strung together.Dejah Thoris is kinda OK but based ont he book she should be way more sexy, but of course this is America and Disney, so sexy is out of the question, but you know what? If you're not willing to commit to the spirit of the book, don't make the film. So the result is: One star for "It's John Carter after all" other than that: Thumbs Down

reviewText: I accidentally ordered John Carter of Mars...SENT IT BACK! It is NOT the movie JOHN CARTER. Disney version is a GREAT MOVIE.Disney can nearly be depended on to put out something that you don't have to hide from the kids and put under cover in case you have friends over.It is pure Disney in that it is just fun and lighthearted...you aren't going to be using this as a reference on one of you college papers.I really get tired of swearing and voyeurism and when you realize that it is one of the brain-children of E.R. Burroughs and if you liked Tarzan...I mean the "REAL" story, Lord Greystoke, another great movie that is full of thrilling adventure and imagination. It also doesn't insult the intelligence. It is a lot like H.G. Wells, The Time Machine or a Jules Verne tale.I, of course, have it now in my collection. It is another classic. It is to be read, but like I tell my students. Shakespeare was never meant to be read...they are Plays and should be introduced as plays or movies (no wonder so many people hate Shakespeare...they had to READ it in high school) The above mentioned stories and authors should be READ first and then seen as movies. Why? Because in reading you develop your own mental vision as the author wanted you to. In movies you are seeing some else's imagination. Both have their place. I really liked John Carter as much as I did Tarzan. It's a classic
summary: NOT the John Carter of MARS...Disney John Carter

reviewText: I was not surprised when this flopped at the box office.  And that wasn't just because of weak advertising.It's a mess.First, too much plot, too little coherence.The war on Mars generates no loyalty.  The Reds vs. the Blues, ho hum.  And then there are the Therns, who are never explained and who randomly choose sides.  (Who can blame them?  On the other hand, they are boringly robotic, so who cares about them?)The war on earth (the Civil War) ditto.  John Carter's anger and rootlessness is understandable, but uninteresting.  Yes, his wife and child (and side) have died, but this doesn't make him interesting.  His quest for gold is a yawn.Second, the characters are empty.  Not only is John Carter himself dull (all that jumping gets tiresome, but it's his best feature), so is everyone else.  Lynn Collins can act, but she isn't allowed to here.  Ditto the Tharks.  They have good voices but aren't interesting, except perhaps for Sola.Third, and most important, pacing.  This is an adventure movie, but the pacing is GLACIAL.  Bad directing all around.The special effects are interesting for a while, but no movie can survive on special effects, as George Lucas proved with The Phantom Menace (The Phantom Movie).All in all, long and uninvolving.

reviewText: This is a review of the 3D from the movie John Carter (of Mars) 3D.First, I enjoyed the 2 hour movie quite a bit and was warped into the world thanks to a like-able, well acted cast of characters and aliens, along with some great adventure as John Carter sets out to solve the mystery while choosing to sacrifice his freedom or not, regarding the princess, who needs his reluctant help.3D REVIEW of JOHN CARTER: Note: This is a 2D to 3D conversion with 3D CGI computer graphics. This suggests only the live action was converted.First, the parallax 3D (the layers of objects and the depth between them) is top notch here. The different characters really stand out strongly from foreground and background. If you value clearly separate layers of depth in your 3D movie, this one delivers throughout from beginning to end on an impressive level. The characters themselves also show good volume, so they are not flat cardboard cutouts. That's important.Next, the depth reaching into the screen, is also present. You can look far into the screen without any trouble.As far as pop out (objects moving outside the screen towards you), there are a few nice pop out moments here or there, but mostly, the film keeps things within the confines of the screen.3D Layers: 9/103D Depth: 8/103D Pop Out 5/103D OVERALL: 9/10 (not an average). This movie looks great in three dimensions.If you value 3D adventure movies, John Carter 3D is one to really consider adding to your collection. 2 hours of excellent 3D. Buy it.
summary: 3D Review of John Carter 3D: Excellent 3D throughout...

reviewText: One of our youth film critics reviewed this and here is what she had to say:From Disney's latest 250 million dollar film comes the exhilarating 3-D adventure of John Carter. This movie is based on the first out of eleventh novel of the series Princess of Mars, written about a century ago by Edgar Rice Burroughs. In this film, John Carter is a Civil War veteran who finds a medallion that teleports him to Mars. There, he makes allies and foes with the aliens he encounters and falls in love with the princess of Helium. At the same time, massive war is occurring between the aliens so Mars is in a chaotic state, and there is also an antagonist who tries to use schemes to put Carter back on Earth. Can John Carter manage to stay with his princess despite these obstacles?Writer and director Andrew Stanton wrote the magnificent screenplays for Toy Story 1, 2, and 3, Wall-E, and Finding Nemo, but John Carter is not one of his best works. Some parts are not well rendered and a bit corny, but I did enjoy the ending of the film because it's interesting and unpredictable, and I am sure this movie will become very popular. I also liked the main theme of the movie regarding to cultural differences. The movie shows how different the norms and appearances are for aliens on Mars compared to people on Earth, yet it is universal for both life forms to have good intentions.The CGI animation is also impressive, for it details even on the smallest of aspects. Its vividness combined with the 3-D makes the movie pop to life, particularly during the action scenes. The CGI animation is very compatible with movies such as Avatar and Planet of the Apes. The cinematography is also beautiful since the landscape of the film is set in the desert, which makes the movie more interesting to me since I rarely see action scenes occur in such an isolated, dry, and hot place.As for the actors, all of them performed their roles well, but I think Taylor Kitsch was especially well suited to his heroic character John Carter.I recommend this movie to teens 13 and older because there are a few violent scenes. The movie is a great family film, especially for tweens and some teens. Overall, the movie is an entertaining cinematic experience. There are a myriad of action scenes and the entire film is in 3-D, which adds a lot of depth making the movie seem realistic. You will definitely be thrilled if you're into science fiction movies and video games. Reviewed by Gabriella C, KIDS FIRST! Film Critic.
summary: Great Family Film, Especially for Tweens and Teens.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I should be giving this a one star for the box art, but I like the movie too much to do that and I don't want to affect the rating negatively. But let me first say the movie is fantastic. It really its a shame for it to be a flop at the box office because it makes people think it sucks when it doesn't. The story of John Carter being teleported to Mars is interesting enough to keep you hooked all the way through, with enough action to satisfy. But it's not perfect. I'll be the first to defend this movie but I will make fun of it right after. First of all, the Princess is a joke though at times I found her to be a definitive competent heroine. But she's bound by the Disney cliches such as "I can't marry the Evil Man, I don't love him!" Been there, done that, and even John Carter himself pokes fun at the cliche by saying "Is that all there is?" So points to the movie by addressing the cliches it creates and that's nice. I like how the movie becomes aware of the cliches and will even crack jokes about it. It's not a comedy by any means but the comic relief is nice. But the Princess really did annoy me at times.Overall this movie should have been a success but ultimately it was a gamble that didn't pay off. Evidently it cost $250 Million with another $100 Million for marketing to make this movie. And I'll be honest folks, I have no idea where that money went. I saw it and yes the special effects were nice but they weren't $250 MILLION nice. And how they did the marketing, I don't know. I only saw the trailer by chance and no one in my family even heard about it. Let alone anyone at work. So the movie was overblown and under-marketed. Add that to the obscure source material and no name actors (besides Mark Strong and Willem Defoue) and you've got a movie that is so desperate to make its money that we can now pre-order the Blu-ray not even a month from its original release.And it's a shame, because this movie WAS good! But, too much of "this" and "that" ultimately added to what financially is described as a "Flop".The Box Art doesn't help either. I mean what an unappealing picture is that. It's too much and at the same time too bland. Yellow bold text on an orange/blue background with white blind apes, and two pics of John Carter. This should have been way more subtle. They should have just taken the wallpaper of the bold orange background and near-silhouette John Carter and just slapped in on the box.So again, good movie with great action and decent plot, but unfortunately not only did it fail to make a profit, but now it's got a Box Art that is unlikely to make you interested.
summary: Love the Movie, Hate the Box Art

reviewText: I read all of Edgar Rice Burroughs' Martian series as a teenager and loved them.  (I also read all of the Tarzan series, all 26 or 27, whatever the total number was he wrote.)  So I was very pleased that the were making a movie of what turned out to be "The Princess of Mars," the first book of the Martian series.  For the most part they did a good job, but I was completely disappointed in two things.First and foremost was the character of John Carter.  A self-centered jerk who cares only for himself is about as far wrong as you can get from the John Carter of Edgar Rice Burroughs.  John Carter is a Southern Gentleman, complete with proper manners and would certainly come to the aid of an damsel in distress with having to be prodded and cajoled.  He was also a great swordsman, not a butcher swinging a cleaver.The other item was the whole "superior race" and completly invented explaination for how John Carter traveled back and forth between Earth and Mars.  How John Carter got there was a mystery he never understood, and ERB never bothered to explain.  They should have left well enough alone, as what they came up with certainly detracted from the story.
summary: John Carter was a Southern Gentleman, not a jerk with an attitude

reviewText: I can't believe this was not a HUGE box office hit!  A great movie from start to finish and a lot of fun.  Can't wait for the DVD to be released so I can watch it again....I just downgraded my review to 3 stars because of the way Disney is ripping off its customers on the digital copy.  I liked this movie so much, I payed extra to get the version with a digital copy.  Shortly after installing it, I upgraded to a new laptop and tried to re-install the movie.  There is no way to do it!  Each movie comes with a code that can only be used ONE time, so you can only install the movie on ONE device.  (I also discovered this is true of other "digital copy" movies I bought.)So if you are planning to pay extra to get a digital version thrown in, DON'T DO IT (unless you never plan to get a new computer!)  I'm sure the "movie pirates" will find easy ways around this scheme.  This only hurts your honest customers.  Shame on you, Disney!
summary: Great movie, but digital copy is a ripoff!

reviewText: After skimming some critical reviews when the movie was released, I had low expectations for John Carter, but it really is a very, very good movie! The acting was good -- in fact, there were some top-shelf actors here I had no idea were going to be in it, like James Purefoy and Ciaran Hinds, who was Caesar in the wonderful Showtime series, Rome, and the leads, Taylor Kitsch and Lynn Collins, were excellent as well. There were a few good laughs ("I'm getting away!"), some romance, lots of adventure. I think this could have been a big hit in the US for Disney if they advertised it differently. First of all, from the TV ads and movie previews I saw, I had no idea that John Carter started out as a Civil War soldier. That added an important dimension to his character. Why they would leave that out of the ads and promo, I have no idea. They could have riffed on the Cowboys and Aliens theme and done a much, much better job of promoting John Carter. It's truly a shame it didn't get the box office draw that was hoped for, because it's a fun, solid sci-fi adventure that appeals to the whole family. Oh well -- I hope people take a chance on it in instant video, because it's definitely worth it.
summary: So much better than I expected

reviewText: Anyone who knows me considers me a crank, a curmudgeon when it comes to SF and fantasy film fare. And If I know the material I'm even worse. The formula for what works for me is simple: don't treat me like an idiot and I might like your film. I'm not an art snob.That said I did NOT have any hope for this film. The fact is I've grown to loathe Hollywood's attempts at adapting good pulp writing to film. Few exceptions are made to this well established, personal outlook because I honestly think that Hollywood's efforts to own the material starts with denigrating it. Then they try to build it up by modernizing things or making them more and often even less logical than the stories they're adapting.This film is certainly guilty of that. However, this time the evident contempt was left out. Yes, it's a bit modernized but not in any bad way. The story is a bit more layered than the original and of course nothing in the character's motives remain intact from the original story but the character ARE sincere, at least as much as they are in the book without being embarrassing.This is not my John Carter, but he is a close cousin and that was enjoyable enough for me.Taylor Kitsch as John Carter and especially Lynn Collins as Dejah Thoris make these characters come alive in ways I did not expect. No, this john Carter makes no mention of his inability to remember his past or how old he is. This guy is a likable character driven at first by his being sick of war and the process of war. He wants wealth and place to get away from his past. Well, he gets his second wish.-As a side note I like this take on Carter even though I miss the ageless man, the warrior. However given our nation's constant state of war I'm not sure we would sympathize with Burrough's Carter who is described as grinning when he engages his enemies in bloodletting. Burroughs thought that war was noble, that it made a man of you. Later in his life as a war correspondent and seeing the travails of war he no longer clung to naive notions of war's nobler virtues. So, this is essential a Carter from that older writer's perspective-Collin's Dejah is a woman of conscience, a princess who now is also a scientist but also willing to endure a lot to save her people and her father's kingdom though that price is very steep. The original Dejah is also very loyal to her people, her city and her father. So, some change but not a facelift or even disdain, just a more humanized take on both characters.This is growing long but suffice it to say I liked it. I not only liked it I did something I almost never do for a SF/Fantasy film; I endorsed it and even argued with my illustrator/comic artists peers over how good it was. Normally we're very much in agreement but here we had to agree to disagree in a big way.One last thing, I also have come to be very disappointed with FX. This film has turned me around on the use of digital FX. The use of digital affects is used so seamlessly utilized in both settings (beautifully rugged Utah!) and in the characters like the Tharks (they look feel and act so much like they're real it's easy to believe it) are the best use of digital animation I've ever seen. The way they each have individual character, with little mannerisms, speech patterns and facial tics makes them as real as they can be. And the ruin of ancient, dying Barsoom can be felt and seen.Needless to say, all my reservations are on vacation from my usual cynicism. This film gives me hope and I know no one will agree but considering all the crap it takes to get a film like this made, well, I won't disparage the cost it took to make it. I won't say everyone will like this film. There is the hope that many more viewers will ignore the negative campaign to derail this effort and give it a chance.
summary: Almost 5 stars but still a far better film than expected

reviewText: A film destined to be a cult classic.Let's go back to 1877 when Giovanni Schiaparelli "discovered" canali on Mars.  Misinterpreting the word to mean canals, popular writers and even scientists around the world began to think in terms of life, intelligent life, on Mars.  Life that could build huge, planet spanning canals to bring water to the arid desert of the planet.  Another astronomer, Percival Lowell, took up the baton and began to observe Mars in earnest and for years before and after the turn of the 20th century, speculated on the probability of life, life that he thought could be intelligent.  In the meantime, H.G. Wells penned a novel about invasion from Mars.  "War of the Worlds" became a best seller and inspired a huge outpouring of fiction about Mars.  Edgar Rice Burroughs added to the fictional Mars accounts with "Princess of Mars," which was so popular it spawned eleven sequels with the same principal characters, John Carter and Princess Dejah Thoris.Mars had caught the public fancy and the love affair of the public with Mars has hardly abated even to the present day.  Burroughs's Mars is a wonderful place.  In 1917, when "Princess" was penned, flying machines were rare on Earth.  But they were already being prepped for war.  Burroughs caught on to this and made the Martian fliers fabulous weapons.  And "fabulous" is a key word here.  Burroughs wrote a fantasy, not a science fiction novel.  He was aware of the fact that gravity on Mars is only slightly more than a third of that on Earth and therefore gave John Carter leaping ability... but way more than the lesser gravity would actually allow.  He is almost a superman on Mars.Burroughs's novel was written near the end of the Edwardian era.  War clouds had precipitated actual conflict and the war was on everyone's mind.  There was war on Mars, of course. But the book is an Edwardian romance with beautiful women rewarding heroes with their favors.The plot of the movie, though it does not track exactly with the story of "Princess of Mars," actually captures the atmosphere and essence of Burroughs's so perfectly it is impossible to find fault.  The story is Burroughs.  The characters are exactly what Burroughs delineated in his novels and they are well played. His wonderful tharks look exactly as the reader envisions.  The flying machines are insect-like and adapted to the Martian gravity.  They ride on sunbeams (solar power?).  For anyone enthralled with Burroughs's stories, the movie is so evocative, it renews your sense of wonder.For anyone not familiar with Burroughs's novels, come with me back to 1917 and experience the world that Burroughs saw in his mind's eye.  Visit Mars of that era with its canals and old civilizations, a dying world of turmoil and danger, needing a hero from Earth to make things straight and to win the heart of the Martian princess.  A great and splendorous film and one to enjoy many times.

reviewText: I, like most of the movie-going world, skipped this flick. That's too bad. After watching it after the fact, I wish I would have seen it in 3D. It brings to life one of the classic SF pulp series, with an "everyman" protagonist (John Carter) and a believable supporting cast of aliens, humanoids, machines and landscapes. Watching the first five minutes of John Carter when he's on Mars, you'll find yourself thinking "So that's where the idea of Superman came from!"This movie was a treat to watch, and one I'll undoubtedly view many more times, James Cameron admits that the John Carter books were his inspiration for Avatar, and after watching this movie, you can see where the books have impacted SF for generations. Edgar Rice Burroughs started writing his Barsoom stories in 1912, at the height of the Mars hysteria. He envisioned ships that sail on light (solar powered aircraft), Astral Projection and more. His scientific ideas, like those of Jules Verne, were considered outlandish. Today, they are almost a reality.Do yourself (and the studio!) a favor and get this movie. It will make a great addition to any SF collection! No, it's not that true to the books - they were more of an inspiration. Carter's leaping ability and strength are over exaggerated, and the other races changed significantly. If Disney would have left some of these aspects, I'm sure the movie would have done much better. Unfortunately, Carter comes off as a clumsy superman.
summary: Too bad it flopped - fantastic Pulp ScFi

reviewText: One of my favorite movies in nearly 50 years of film-watching. Since first catching John Carter on Starz a few months ago, and then buying the Blu-ray, I have watched this movie at least a half dozen times, growing more captivated by it with each viewing. It is a great adventure, lovingly made, beautifully realized, and full of the action and romance of the pulp stories that inspired it. Based on the 1912 story by Tarzan creator Edgar Rice Burroughs, who is considered the grandfather of American science fiction, directors and studios have struggled throughout the last century to bring this epic tale to the big screen. Everything from Flash Gordon, to Star Wars to Avatar was directly inspired or influenced by John Carter's escapades on Mars (or Barsoom as it's called by the natives), but it wasn't until the once science fiction setting of 2011 that computer technology finally caught up to Burroughs'  prolific imagination, making it possible to bring his amazing otherworldly cities, creatures and flying ships to vivid life.As breathtaking and essential to the story as the special effects are, it was Academy Award-winner Andrew Stanton's direction, and the performances of the cast (including the CGI ones) that made me fall in love with this movie. For me, the heart of the film is the impossible yet destined romance between wayward Virginia cavalryman John Carter (Taylor Kitsch) and his literal star-crossed lover, the Martian princess, scientist and swordswoman, Dejah Thoris (Lynn Collins). The performances of and chemistry between Kitsch and Collins are so convincing I can't imagine anyone else playing these roles. And the thousands of green-skinned, nine-foot-tall, four-armed Martian Tharks who make up most of the supporting cast are just as convincing, even though they exist entirely as digital pixels. The only thing that kept me from believing that they were real is the knowledge that they can't be, and the motion-captured performances of the major Thark actors (Willem DaFoe, Thomas Haden Church, Samantha Morton and Polly Walker) convey as much emotion and character as any of their corporeal co-stars. This also goes for Woola, the Martian doglike callot, who quickly becomes Carter's faithful best friend and protector.My only criticism of the movie is the five minute prologue, which I feel takes away from the wonder of Carter's initial Martian journey as it was presented by Burroughs (to rectify this, I recommend starting the movie from scene two, which is when the opening title credit appears). It was mainly for this reason that I was going to give John Carter only four stars, until I realized that the last five minutes--which I consider one of the greatest movie endings in film history--totally offsets the deficit of the awkward beginning.Regrettably, I missed John Carter when it was in theaters, having been unduly influenced by undeservedly negative reviews from members of the film industry press who deemed the movie a critical and financial failure--almost entirely as a result of Disney's incomprehensible and incompetent marketing decisions (such as dropping "of Mars" from the title) and false reports of skyrocketing production costs (for more on Disney's marketing debacle, read Michael D. Sellers' excellent exposé,John Carter and the Gods of Hollywood).Fortunately, John Carter has found a second life and a growing fan following through people viewing it on television, computer and tablet, who are as mystified as I am at how so many critics could fail to appreciate this movie's many charms.  Hopefully, as more and more people give this film the chance it deserves, that fan following will eventually reach a critical mass, and those of us who didn't make it last time will get a second opportunity to see Barsoom on the big screen in a John Carter sequel.
summary: 100 years in the making worth the wait

reviewText: I used to read Edgar Rice Burroughs back in the '70's, when life was much less complicated than what we are experiencing these days. reviewText: It's a shame the fate this film suffered at the hands of the terrible marketing team Disney hired for this mo allowed to cut the trailers together, and the incredibly bland, generically boring title they decided to go with. Why they chose "John Carter" over the original novel's title "A Princess of Mars", or even the original film title they were planning to go with, "John Carter of Mars" is beyond me. This is the definition of one you have to see it for yourself, because audience interest never piqued for it, and critical reception was fairly split. It truly is a great movie, in my opinion. The pros far outweigh the cons. Biggest flaws were that some stuff, primarily dialogue, was a bit cliche and corny. The story itself has been done and done again. A soldier travels to a distant land, joins the natives, and helps them defeat an overwhelming enemy. That plot should not, and honestly cannot, be held against this film due to the simple fact that the novel is a hundred years old, and was probably one of the pioneers of that story template. Simplified is a perfect way to describe the script, but not too simple. It's depth is more than sufficient. The characters are unique and delightful. Woola is adorable, despite his ugly appearance.I have to say I was quite surprised and happy to see Bryan Cranston in his brief part. Some of the lead performances may be a little stiff, per se, mainly Taylor Kitsch and Lynn Collins. They have their high points, but overall, I felt they were a tad stiff. Taylor Kitsch, although I don't feel sorry for him if studios invested too much in him as a leading man, I have to say I am a little sorry that he had two major studio blockbuster flops within a span of three months. Lynn Collins is a beauty though, so in a way I can forgive her hiccups. Willem Dafoe and Thomas Hayden Church were great in their voiceover roles. Mark Strong played Mark Strong, or in other words, another intimidatingly intellectual villain. The Blu-ray is a nice, if slightly lacking, package. The extras are scarce, but the transfer is top notch. There is a director's commentary, which tends to be my favorite feature, and a short historical doc, on top of a few other minor things. Overall, it was satisfyingly action packed (in a story-driven way), funny at times, and it should make for one hell of a blockbuster if the marketing doesn't damn it. I recommend it.Note: I cannot currently watch the 3D disc, but I reviewed the 3D combo pack because that's the edition that I bought (for the digital copy).

reviewText: The only reason I never saw this movie in the theater is that the one nearest me that played it is a miserable theater.  I really, really wanted to like this movie, based on my enjoyment of the books.Let me start with the good things.  The scenery and CGI were great, as was the cinematography.  The retrofitted 3D wasn't terribly bad, though there were scenes where I could remove the 3D glasses and not notice much difference.  Still, the 3D did enhance the movie.Now for the bad.  The leading actor and actress were just bad.  He actually only did one scene in the movie where I actually gave a damn about the character ( where his finding his home burned and family dead, on Earth, interspersed with a somewhat overdone battle scene on Barsoom).  Her's was a plastic, single-dimension performance.  Two of the supporting actors were given so little to work with, it was a shame.  Ciaran Hinds is a good actor capable of a lot more than a simple, do-anything-to-survive "leader".  Willem Dafoe is capable of finely crafted facial expressions and speech patterns that he was wasted on Tars Tarkus.  Mark Strong played the same character he's played in every other role he's had...except most of his lines were dull and predictable.  That leaves me with the direction and screenplay.  Surprise!  The same person was involved in both.  Andrew Stanton might have had a role in the Toy Story series, Wall-E and Finding Nemo, but where he does good writing for animated fish, toys and robots.Sorry.  I wanted to enjoy this so much, that I am, perhaps taking out my frustration on the film and being more harsh than I should.  Hopefully, it will be one of those films, that if I watch it enough, will grow on me.
summary: The Saddest Words...It Might Have Been

reviewText: Like many older folk here, I was exposed to the original Burroughs series.  I did not expect this movie to be a carbon copy - what film is?  I expected to judge it on its own merits, and in this it succeeds well enough.  The period costuming is impeccable, the characterization adequately deep for a pulp fiction hero, the critters "authentic" enough.  There are necessary updates, of course: Burroughs could not have envisioned such electronic flying machines, and the chivalrous Southron of the original Carter would have come across as mere hokum to a modern audience, inviting more cynicism than honor. Lynn Collins is modernistically "correct" as an amazon princess; her scenes are worth watching for obvious reasons.  Altogether, good entertainment.  Why this should have "bombed" at the BO, as opposed to long-playing silliness not worth the ticket price, is one of those market mysteries whose secret may be revealed, some day, beyond the River Iss.
summary: Good entertainment in its own right
