reviewText: The best thing about the movie "John Carter" is...John Carter. How rare it is to have for the main character a man who is actually a hero; a man whom one can root for; a man who is unafraid to make a stand against those who wish him merely to "comply." Combined with the strong-willed Dejah Thoris, John Carter and his faithful Woola in the company of Tars Tarkas and his daughter Sola seek to change a world that is not-so-slowly dying from unwarranted tradition and gratuitous cruelty.Combining action, humor, amazing scenery, well-developed main characters, and a sense of wonder too lacking in modern cinema, "John Carter" transports us to a fantasy world that nevertheless is strikingly "real" to those who experience it with an open mind and an open heart.This is not a movie for cynics who diss any movie not led by an anti-hero. This is not a movie for the oh-too-sophisticated who disdain admirable characters and a rousing plot in favor of story-less meandering and disgusting souls bent on self-destruction. This is not a movie for those who have lost touch with hope and honor and honesty.The pundits have already written off this film as a "flop." Perhaps "John Carter" won't be a blockbuster financially. But those who crafted this movie have a winner of an experience for those who appreciate an engaging cinematic experience.I'm hoping that positive word-of-mouth will make liars of those who condemn this film and that more episodes in this saga will be made. The world that is Barsoom and the hero that is John Carter deserve to have their stories continued and explored.I certainly have quibbles with parts of this movie, but rather than focus unduly on the superficial, the incidental, the trivial as avenues to attack this film's value, I prefer here to emphasis what is great about this movie and what makes it worthy of its viewers' time.I hope John Carter's motto -- "I still live!" -- becomes the reality for this movie and that the series will not die with a single film.

reviewText: John Carter(released Mar/12)stars Taylor Kitsch as John Carter,Lynn Collins as Dejah Thoris,and many others.Think Dune meets Star Wars and you will see a film here that thinks epic but fails,because of its over attention to detail and the inordinate amount of time it takes to tell this enormous tale(I found myself clock watching numerous times-never a good sign).This story ideally would have been better off told in segments ala Star Wars.Edgar Rice Burroughs original stories really deserve a more detailed look filmicly speaking.The story starts out with Carter,a former Confederate soldier and now seeming archeologist,dodging someone on his tail to send a telegram.Next thing we know he is dead and his  nephew Edgar(as in E.R.Burroughs)is attending the reading of the will.His uncle is entombed in a crypt that can only be opened from the inside`,and much of the estate money will go to see that it is never disturbed.First off Edgar reads his uncles diary which begins back in the late 1800s in the Arizona territory(which in turn begins the main Carter storyline).He is there searching for a legendary cave of gold,which he eventually finds.However a strange being beams into the cave and the two struggle.With his dying breath the being utters some strange wording and a medallion that Carter picked out of his hand,suddenly sends him instantaneously to Mars.He has not a clue as to where he is(this takes quite a while to learn)and finds,due to the lack of an Earth-like gravity,that he can jump enormous distances.However he runs into a race of beings similar in stature to Jar-Jar Binks,but with a smaller head,two small tusks and four arms.They take him back to their encampment.One day a princess from the city of Helium comes into contact with Carter.She tells him that her city and the others on Mars(Barsoom to folks there) are at war and that it has not gone well for her people.She is being forced to marry the commander of the opposing forces in order to achieve peace.Carter of course falls hard for the princess and helps her.Carters main objective all along has been to get back to Earth,and to that end they journey to the scared place of his captors.There they come upon the answer,but which the princess denies,telling Carter she needs more info from her city.It is an obvious lie to keep Carter there.After their visit both are captured and the princess is returned to her husband to be to be married.The princess tells Carter about her lie and tells him he can go back anytime he wants,and says the appropriate words.When the wedding party interrupts their talk,she turns and Carter is gone.She assumes he has gone back,but he has just jumped up onto a ceiling alcove.Over and above all of the strife on Mars,there is a higher race of beings manipulating the outcome of every battle,and are so bold as to even introduce themselves to Carter.Carter in turn enlists the help of his original captors to go against Helium`s enemies.A gigantic battles ensues and in the end the citizens of Helium are free, and Carter and the princess wed.One night shortly after,one of the higher race of beings sends Carter back to Earth.Carter wakes up on the floor of the cave he was originally transported from.It seems a copy of your body is only sent from one place to the next.If something were to happen to the original,the copy would die.Carter returns home and for years searches for another cave with another medallion in order to return to Mars,but in vain.So he fakes his death(we saw at the beginning of the movie)which lures out one of the higher beings.As his nephew is about to open the vault,the being comes out of the bushes to kill him,but Carter jumps him from behind and dispatches him.Carter`s nephew and Carter re-unite,but just briefly.Carter tells his nephew to look after his body and returns to the vault and Mars,his adopted home.There is just so much information to digest throughout this movie as one race comes into the picture,another pops up,then later another which look exactly like the first ones,and on and on.What really threw me off was when Carter first came in contact with his original captors,neither could understand each other.In his captors camp later,everyone is speaking perfect English.There is no explanation as to why the sudden change,except to have Carter remark that he can suddenly understand them.The beginning where Carter is being followed then suddenly he is dead and a will is being read,I thought could have been done better.Sure it all ties back to the beginning at the end,but for a while there at the start,you don`t know whether you were looking at a flashback when Carter is running around and his death is the present,or is it the reverse...it is just unnecessarily confusing for the start of a film like this.The film is epic in style,to be sure,but with all this detail being thrown at you and the hopping back and forth from one sub plot to another,is does get a bit overwhelming,and annoying.Technically speaking the film is clear and crisp in its 2:40:1 w/s a/r.The only extras are commentary and a featurette on its making.All in all an overly detail-oriented showboat that tries to look Star Wars-ishly epic-like,but fails to deliver the goods,in this overly long juggernaut.

reviewText: Like so many others in posts about this movie, I was astonished at how good it was.  It's clear that the trailer and marketting of this movie did it a great disservice.  If--and this is a big IF--you can accept the fantasy genre rules for what they are, you'll love it.  Accept that the environment on Mars was at one time wet.  Accept that an earthman can be mystically transported to Mars.  Accept that inhabitants include four-armed humanoids.  Accept that warriors prefer swords even though the technology exists to creat guns. Accept that an earth man can jump and practicaly fly through the air, which is of course breathable, because of Mars lower gravity!  In other words, accept the vision of Edgar Rice Buroughs, the writer of the book created for Mars.  If you can, you will have a rip-roaring time.  The CGI is perfect.  Nothing on the screen looks phony. You'll love the wonderful tribal culture of the Tharks.  You'll love the male and female leads, who take their roles seriously, with no chesiness or tounge-in-cheek attitude.  The producers, director and actors all took the story seriously.  And given the nature of this sort of fantasy, doing it straight and doing it well require amazing talent. They succeed in maintaining the perfect adventure tone throughout, with no "modernizing" of the concept. There's not a doubt in my mind that Mr. Buroughts, if he could have seen it, would say, "Yes, that's precisely how I imangined it when I wrote the book."  You'll love the sheer adventure of it all.  Everyone in the theater--all five of us--were laughing, applauding, crying in a scene or two, and left the theater pleasantly astonished at how good this film was.  What a shame, since the poor financial performance of JOHN CARTER practicly assures that none of the planned sequels will ever be produced.

reviewText: An 1800's man finds himself on another planet, around alien beings. The planet is in the midst of a civil war, with one group of beings planning on taking over the territory of others. John Carter befriends them, and aids them in their fight, while also falling for a beautiful princess who is part of a local human-like species. All the while, one wonders if he will be able to return to earth. The visuals in this film are amazing, and the characters created are actually likeable. When John Carter first meets a local being it is actually quite funny, and the viewer can see the beginning of a camaraderie forming. At times the details of who are the aggressors and who is being threatened could have been more clearly delineated, as this genre does not lend itself will to a storyline that has a gray area in its portrayal of good and evil. Taken as a whole, the movie is a visually stunning film that does enough to keep the viewer entertained.

reviewText: Edgar Rice Burroughs wrote action packed stories with great characters. The Mars series is populated with many great characters and lots of action. reviewText: No spoilers, and not a review, but a passionate rant:This film was fumbled by bad marketing, raped by critics and forgotten by most everybody.It pisses me off in a over 40 fanboy way.  I feel towards "John Carter of Mars" like I feel towards "Firefly", or "Starship Troopers".. great entertainments that didn't catch on or were unfairly maligned, and I'm happy to see so many positive reviews here on Amazon.  I saw this film in the theater, and had a great time.  I laughed out loud alot at how audacious and fun the storytelling was.Simply put:  this is a classic swashbuckling adventure story. There's a tough hero, a beautiful princess, a host of adversaries, colorful side characters, steampunk technology, gorgeous Native American-meets-India-meets Final Fantasy art design, great soundtrack..there's also little to no swearing, no nudity, no bloody violence, no deep morality messages about racism or sustainability or how fathers don't love their sons enough, etc***and THANK YOU - no gritty realistic looking desaturated color palette.Yeah, this film is colorFULL- it looks fantastic in High Def!and it has plenty of romantic subtext, action and humor. And critics moaned about how the story didn't make enough sense. I could care less that they combined and altered some of the original books ideas and elements.. it was written 100 years ago.  It's no big loss, you can read it for free!Big plus:  a family-friendly entertainment that might get your kid interested in reading a hundred year old book  ;)If you're like me and like "serious" fantasy films like the Lord of the Rings, but ALSO have room on your shelf for lovingly made, FUN fantasy films that don't take themselves too seriously and are perfect for all ages, please give this film a chance.

reviewText: I read a few of the John Carter novels many years ago.  They were cheesy, but fun.  In fact, that's what workmates would say they saw what I was reading in the cafeteria; "Barsoom novels?  Those are a hoot."Superman was really based on John Carter.  Originally, he couldn't fly, and there was no kryptonite; he was just a dude from another planet who could jump really high, and had greater strength due to the Earths gravity relative to Krypton's. John Carter has super strength and high-jumping abilities when on Mars because of it's relative gravity compared to Earth's.  To the people of Mars, John Carter was an alien from another planet with strength beyond what was normal.  Both heroes fought for justice.  Put John Carter back on Earth and he's just a normal guy.  Put Superman back on Krypton, (if it hadn't blown up), and he'd be just another guy.  There really was no difference between John Carter and Superman.  I really think Superman would be a more relate-able character if he had stayed true to his comic book origins.  It was the Superman radio show that bestowed the gift of flight on him, as well as his pesky kryptonite allergy.  I have no doubt that Superman's creators must have been fans on the John Carter novels.  Think about it; the first Superman comic came out in 1938.  John Carter had already been out for more than a quarter of a century.  There is no way the exact similarities between these two characters was an accident.People often say that "Star Wars" was inspired by the "Flash Gordon" and "Buck Rogers" serials of the 30's and 40's.  This may be true, but Flash and Buck were inspired by John Carter.Disney has owned the rights to the Tarzan and John Cater books for a long time, and I remember listening to "our 25" on KPFK in Los Angeles in the 1980's when a guest was talking about how Disney planned on updating these stories for the big screen, for instance, there is really not much explanation in the books on how John Carter transports from the dessert cave to Mars, so some scientific explanation would be created for the movies.I waited and waited for the films to be made, but nothing in the 80's, nothing in the 90's, nothing in the 2000's.Then I heard that "A Princess of Mars" would come out in 2012 on the one-hundredth anniversary of the book's first publishing. The title would be changed to "John Carter of Mars".  I told my wife we would see that film for sure.Then I heard that Andrew Stanton was directing it and that it would be in 3D.  I again told my wife that we would see it for sure.Then we saw a trailer for it while watching another film.  At this point, I think they were still calling it, "John Carter of Mars".  I don't know what it was, I can't really explain why, but it just looked, stupid.  I turned to my wife and asked, "Does that look good to you?"  She just shrugged.  Something about it looked completely underwhelming.Then I saw television ads.  By this time, I think the title had been shortened to just "John Cater".  Again, nothing about the ad made me want to shell out hard-earned cash to see it.  I remember wondering to myself why would they change the title to just "John Carter".  That really says nothing about the film, and doesn't pull you in.  I'm not a marketing student, but I can tell you, this title sucks.So here I am, a guy who read and enjoyed the books, had been waiting for the movies for literally decades, and now, had no desire to see them.  Imagine how a non-fan felt about it.  I should have been the easiest person in the world to sell this movie to.  Instead. we spent our movie-going money on other films.One day, "John Carter" came on television.  I recorded it on my DVR but did not immediately watch it.  One day, my family was getting ready run some errands.  I turned this movie on to watch a few minutes.  I was transfixed.  I didn't want to turn it off.  My daughter, in the middle of getting ready, walks through the living room to go to her room.  She stops for a second to glance at the TV.  She too became transfixed."What is this?""John Carter of Mars.  It's by the same guy who wrote the Tarzan books.""It's really good."At this point, we had to leave, so I turned it off.  I turned the movie back on as soon as we got back home.  My daughter walks in and asks that I start it over so she could see what she missed.  Now we both sit there and kept saying, "wow, this is really good.  Why didn't we see this in the theater?"My wife walks in looks a little bit of it and asks, "What's that?""John Cater of Mars.", my daughter answers."It looks cool. Please don't delete it.  I want to watch it later."I get home from work one day, and my wife is watching it.  She's near the end.  She looks up at me and says, "This is really good.  Isn't this the film that Disney wrote off?"I'm sorry that I'm taking a long time to get to my point.  All it takes to really like this movie is just to see it.  All it takes to really hate it is to watch the advertising.Oh, and at the very end of the film, you see the letters "JCOM", and then the real title of the film, "John Carter of Mars".  I'll never understand why the title was changed at the last minute, but the fact that this older title is still in the credits does show that nobody on the creative side of this film got the memo that it was no longer called "John Carter of Mars".So, while I skipped it in the theaters, I will gladly shell out money to buy the BD of this film.J. J. Abrams has been hired by Disney to direct the next Star Wars film.  I think he did a pretty good job on the latest Star Trek film, but it wasn't the best film in that franchise.  Watching "John Carter" shows how well Andrew Stanton understands and really loves the source material from the Barsoom novels.  I have to think that he would be much better suited to direct the new "Star Wars" films than Abrams.
summary: One of the best space fantasy films ever made

reviewText: Bravo in this case to Amazon reviewers.  "John Carter" was low on my list of must-see movies after the critics panned it, but a quick look at Amazon's reviews changed my mind, and I wasn't disappointed.  It's hard to imagine what the critics' problem was with the movie.  The show had excellent special effects, more than a whiff of humor and laughs, a dash of mysticism, and entertainingly lifelike strange critters.  You can't help but think a good deal of Star Wars was cribbed from Edgar Rice Burroughs' Mars books, and why not?  Imitate the best, as they say.The plot in a nutshell is that of a former confederate soldier, sick of war, getting accidentally whisked to Mars and ending up in a three-way war that involves two sets of  humanoids and a rougher, cruder culture of tall, four-armed desert dwellers.  The humanoids (I suppose from the Martians' point of view the human Carter would be a Martianoid) are indistinguishable from each other save for the color of their clothing, and the fact that one side is an evil aggressor.  A mysterious group of powerful beings is intervening on the bad guys' behalf, and the battles are on.  Of course, the princess of Mars is on the good side.  She's not only gorgeous, naturally, but has the build of a football linebacker.  I wish I had her broad shoulders.  Carter is sort of like a low-grade Superman, made powerful by Mars's different environment and his earth physiology.That power leads to a couple of inconsistent scenes, in which he gets into trouble that his strength in other scenes easily gets him out of.  Well, all the suspense would be gone if he were unbeatable, I suppose.  Not quite clear too is his teleportation between worlds (potential spoiler here, though I don't think it is): The Carter on Mars is a copy of his body on earth, meaning that his earth body is lifeless but doesn't spoil while his Mars body holds his spirit, soul, whatever.  This datum leads to logical complications and a little confusion, at least for me.I still can't believe this movie wasn't a box office success.  It's not a ponderous, "serious" movie but a rollicking, fairly light science fiction fest that's a pleasure to watch.  Could Disney have possibly handled publicity for this movie any worse?  I'm not the most plugged-in grape on the grapevine, but it's unusual even for me to not hear of a huge potential blockbuster of a movie until the very day it hits the theaters.  A little "Battleship" hyping might have gone a long way for "John Carter."Still, it's not too late to enjoy this movie.  You might be surprised.A tangent that has nothing to do with the movie:  I rented "Carter" and again, as is so often the case, the DVD was scratched and dirty with one part of it unwatchable.  For pete's sake whoever's doing this, stop handling DVDs that are not your own with greasy, barbecue sauce-stained and peanut buttery fingers and picking them up with what appear to be claw hammers.  It's enough to make me pine for videotapes, which morons can't touch.

reviewText: Edgar Rice Burroughs wrote 11 Mars books and I have read them all.  I passed my love of these books on to my son.  We both have the complete collection.  We both went to see John Carter of Mars.  We both loved it.  I plan to buy two copies of the dvd (one for each of us).  To the reviewers who trashed the movie I say "Peeshaw!"  You can bet your bottom dollar that none of them had read the books.  Its getting to the point that if the reviewers trash the film I check it out.  They seem to be often out of touch with the people who go to films!  I have seen countless films they they trashed and I loved.  The film was true to the stories written by Burroughs.  The solar and hydrogen powered airships which are common in his stories were a wonder to behold.  The green men of Mars and the great white apes of Mars were just as described in his books.  Everyone I have talked to who has seen the film liked it!  I hope they do more John Carter films because I will go see them and I will buy the dvds.  Yeah for Disney and boo to the reviewers who panned it!

reviewText: As a long-time Edgar Rice Burroughs fan, I was filled with anxious anticipation for the viewing of "John Carter."  Alas, I was a bit disappointed.  I loved the special effects but thought that the depiction of the main characters was flawed.  I also sensed that the story had been modified.  So, I ordered and reread the Martian series on my iPad.  (FYI, I still have the paperback copies which I purchased in the early 1960s.)  I then watched the movie again.  I still enjoyed it but wished that the film had remained more true to the original story.  I regret that it appears there will not be a sequel.

reviewText: The first thing you notice when looking at the reviews is the wide disparity between stars awarded. Whole bunch of 5 stars and a boiling handful of 1 stars with not much in between.Almost as though the 99%ters are the happy many while the one star reviewers are the disgusted 1% occupying Carter Park and peeing on the lawn. In looking at those 1 star reviews, the common thread seems to be people who have read the ERB series of John Carter novels and hold them dear to their hearts. This movie is not for them. It borrows some from the series and takes off from there. Reconciling your inner visions with the Hollywood version of anything can be a jarring experience. "It doesn't fit my pictures" is a phrase that fits perfectly here. Hopefully, there's a mini-series out there somewhere more true to the source material although I have to imagine it would resemble old episodes of Flash Gordon.As for the movie itself, I liked it! It was epic at times, nicely photographed and the CGI was - well, I would consider it the real star of the movie. I found the plot somewhat predictable but not hackneyed, Taylor K. less annoying than I expected and the princess' eyes very blue. Overall, an enjoyable movie that reached for the sun and came up slightly short. At say, Mars.

reviewText: I wish there were some way to give this movie a 2.5 on this website, because I'm being VERY generous giving it 3 out of 5 stars. The only reason I'm doing so is because I felt the movie was not as bad as all the so-called "Top Critics" who really bashed it said it was.In 'John Carter of Mars' (which, if you're from an older generation, you'll know is an adaptation of writer Edgar Rice Burroughs' 'Barsoom' novels), Taylor Kitsch (who played Gambit in 'Wolverine: Origins', and also starred in the TV series 'Friday Night Lights') plays John Carter, a former American Civil War Confederate Army Captain now searching for wealth, to get away from the several different party's hunting him, and to escape from failures in his past. When Carter ends up in the cave of gold he was searching for, he ends up killing a being known as a Thern, and is accidentally transported to "Barsoom" (the real name for Mars in the novels). Carter is taken prisoner by the Green Martians, but discovers that he has the ability to leap great distances & perform feats of great strength due to his different bone density & adaptation to Earth's higher gravity. Carter soon finds himself caught in the middle of a Civil War between the two Red Martian (who are more human looking) cities, and finds a love interest in the form of a Princess named Dejah Thoris (played here by Lynn Collins, who also starred in 'Wolverine: Origins' as Silverfox).Despite my insistence that the film was not that bad, there is no denying that 'John Carter of Mars' WAS a bad movie. There are a lot of impressive effects, but nothing really special that we haven't seen from other space-themed movies such as 'Star Wars', 'Star Trek', 'Babylon 5', etc; the cast is horrible (only Taylor Kitsch who plays the main character seems like he was actually TRYING to act); the story is long, difficult to follow, & doesn't really hold your attention all the time; and really Disney? You let a PIXAR director who has never directed a live action movie direct this film??? You can tell the director did not know what he was doing, as the style & visualization for this film is really bland.Bottom line, I'd only recommend this movie if you were a fan of the 'Barsoom' novels, or if you're under the age of 12. Also, make sure you rent the movie first before you decide to spend the money to purchase it.

reviewText: Proof that great movies can be destroyed by bad marketing choices, John Carter is some of the most fun I have had at the movies all year. Based (moderately loosely) on E.R. Burroughs classic "A Princess of Mars" John Carter tells the tell of an earthman trapped on another planet, surviving and thriving among the often hostile alien locals, and saving the damsel in distress. The special effects are wonderful and the cast (despite being relatively unknown) deliver perfectly acceptable performances. Willam daFoe is especially awesome as Tars Tarkas, the Thark clan leader. This movie deviates greatly from the book (which I was inspired to read AFTER seeing the movie and am looking forward to completing the 11 book saga) but if Burroughs purist can look past the screenplay deviations they will see the bulk of Burrough's Barsoom brought to life quite faithfully. You won't find oscar winning performances or dialogue but you will find a fantastic fantasy adventure that can be enjoyed again and again. HIGHLY recommended!Oh, and who doesn't love Woola? =)
summary: Fantastic sci-fi fantasy that is pure entertainment!
Title: N/A

reviewText: John Carter is (loosely) based on the Edgar Rice Burroughs Mars (Barsoom) series. It is the story of a Civil War veteran who dies and magically appears on Mars (no explanation needed, although the film felt it wise to add a ridiculous supernatural element to explain the phenomenon). There he is captured by a green alien race called the Tharks. In the book, he wins their respect with his jumping abilities and his battle skills. In the movie, he simply escapes them (possibly because the filmmakers did not want to deal with the intricacies of the foreign culture and the relationship developments). The Tharks have also captured Dejah Thoris (who in the movie basically gives herself to them because she doesn't want to get married) and Carter falls in love with her. He aligns himself with her to save her native city called Helium.Aside from the adaptation problems, I was disappointed by how much the filmmakers relied on sci-fi cliches to keep the plot moving. Is making a strong woman reject her fiancee the only way to illustrate that she is strong? Is torturing a member of another race the only way to make an audience care for them? Are lame jokes about the aliens mistaking Carter's hometown of Virginia as his name really necessary? The cliches made the film watchable, but nowhere near remarkable. So much has been changed from the classic novel, that I just got more and more frustrated the more I watched.I much prefer the old fashioned straight-forwardness of the book. In it, Carter falls in love with Dejah Thoris at first sight, and although she is strong-willed, she is a captive and therefore helpless and able to be saved. The strong male-oriented sense of adventure is somewhat present in the movie, but it is overshadowed by convoluted additions to the plot. The platonic relationships between Carter and Sola and Tars Tarkas are completely glossed over, which is probably the most frustrating loss in the translation from page to screen. The overall theme of combativeness vs. peacefulness is completely lost.The marketing for this film was horrible. While the film cost millions of dollars to make, the studio did very little advertising, and the trailers I saw didn't give any hints at the story. It wasn't until later that I found out it was based on the Burroughs stories that I had recently discovered. I'll admit that my interest in the book is what brought me to the film, but had it not been for that I would have passed it by.

reviewText: John Carter is an excellent movie. I had wanted to see it for months, and I just expected it to be a huge hit. But I always had this little fear in the back of my mind that said it may not do as well as it should, considering Prince of Persia's huge failure, which is a movie I also loved. Then sure enough first weekend $30 million, which if you know the movie business, a movie with a 200 million budget making 30 million is bad, really bad. I kept thinking and hoping for the future of this franchise that it would by some miracle surpass it's budget and do ok. But I was wrong, the next weekend it made even less and less, until The Hunger Games came out to completely diminish any hopes of serious money or any at all for the tale of John Carter of Mars.But what America didn't spend the time or money to find out, was that John Carter happens to be one of the best scifi action adventure movies, one that Disney has ever put out, and two ever made. John Carter has an incredibly captivating story to tell, and has a side romance for any of you women out there. I know right now the chances of John Carter: God of Mars being made are about as good as me going streaking through Harlem. Right, probably not gonna happen, but I guess we can hope and pray, for a sequel not for me streaking. John Carter has an interesting prologue that leads into an excellent adventure on one of the many planets you've probably never been to: Mars.So pick up this movie immediately, because you will never be bored and you'll continuously be asking yourself what life would be like if John Carter hadn't bombed. Who knows you could be rich, or you could be dead. Well it was a thought anyway.
summary: Another Classic Example of a Great Movie That Should've Been a Hit, but wasn't

reviewText: First off, I have not read the Barsoom books, so I can't say whether or not this was a good adaptation. I can say that it was a fun adventure movie.The characters are likable, particularly the strong and beautiful princess, Dejah Thoris, who is definitely not a damsel in distress; she wields a sword and knows how to use it.  I also was very impressed with the Thark alien race, who have a unique appearance and distinct culture, but despite them looking and sounding similar, there's just enough nuance to see the personalities of the key characters, especially Tars Tarkas and Sola.  As for John Carter himself, he is likable and unlike a lot of reluctant heroes who quickly change their tune after meeting the pretty woman, it takes John a while to decide to fight alongside the Tharks to save Dejah and Helium.Having recently vacationed in Utah, it was great to see that scenes in this film were filmed there, because the state is very unique and has a natural beauty you won't find anywhere else.  The way Mars is portrayed is unique; the alien races, fauna, and flora are unlike what I have seen in other media.  I particularly liked the dog-like pet of Sola who takes a liking to John.One complaint I have is that we don't learn enough about the villains of the movie. I would have liked to know more about Sab Than, Matai Shang and the Therns and what was motivating them.  Still, the lack of development of the villains is nothing new to this genre.I don't understand why this film received a negative response; in my opinion, the story was fun, the film looked good, and it was family-friendly.  It must have been a failure on Disney's marketing, because I quite enjoyed it and am sad there won't be more films (I believe this was planned as the first movie in a trilogy).  I guess I will just have to read the books, which by the way, are in the public domain so they are available for free downloads.
summary: John Carter is a good sci-fi adventure

reviewText: This is a really great love story from the science fiction book but really well done. All ages can watch this (PG13) and the special effects and the story implementation are really well done. If you are looking for a great science fiction love story then you will probably like this movie. If however, you are looking for an exact adaptation of the book then you should skip this movie. If you cannot tolerate deviation from the book and literary license then skip the movie. I thought the movie was great but I also can watch a movie that is based on a book and not expect that it will be identical. It is difficult to condense a book into a movie, especially this book so I only had the expectation that it would be based on the book and probably only similar. That will be the fundamental difference as to whether you might like this movie.

reviewText: Former Confederate Civil War soldier, Captain John Carter has nothing left to fight for when he finds himself transported to a desert planet. Suddenly among a warrior tribe of four-armed aliens and a beautiful princess, Carter ends up in the middle of another war. But when faced with the chance of returning home to Earth, Carter may have found a cause worth fighting for in Princess Dejah and the people of Barsoom.Taylor Kitsch stars as John Carter, the bitter and destitute man who cares for nothing but his found cave of gold. Kitsch has a young face and stoic countenance, perfect for the role of the ageless John Carter. He's a believable fighter and a great straight man to plenty of humor. Princess Dejah is played by Lynn Collins, who has terrific chemistry with John Carter, and is just as strong and smart as her male counterparts (if not more). Mark Strong and Dominic West are fantastic villains, especially West as a surprisingly charming and attractive (though nave) despot. And my favorite characters in the novel (Princess of Mars) as well as the film were the Tharks, played by Willem Dafoe, Thomas Haden Church and Samantha Morton. Though CGI, the characters still brought depth, emotion, and humor and successfully brought Burroughs' characters to life.Based on Edgar Rice Burroughs' classic Princess of Mars (published in 1917), John Carter is a surprising and exceptional retelling. I recently read Princess of Mars in anticipation for the film. And though the film doesn't delve into the depth of the Tharks' stories as I would have liked, it still captures the spirit of the novel. And the natives of Barsoom get an impressive technology upgrade, and the science is updated for the awe-factor in the film.I had my reservations after seeing the official trailers. But I was happy to see that the screen writers and director Andrew Stanton knew what they were doing, even if the marketing was off. This fan was captivated from beginning to end and loved every minute of this epic adventure. Full of fascinating characters, life-like aliens, and advanced technology - science fiction fans will certainly enjoy John Carter.  But the action-packed thrills, suspense, drama, romance, and incredible story will appeal to a wide range of new fans - of all ages. It's heart-warming, inspirational, and highly entertaining. Don't miss this one.

reviewerName: Scotman's Film & Book Reviews "Film & Book Re...
reviewText: [This review is for the theatrical release.]I have read 12 of the John Carter novels by Edgar Rice Burroughs.  "A Princess of Mars" was the first and had Carter die in a mystic cave and spiritually elevate himself to the red planet Mars, aka Barsoom.  The old Marvel comics series and the newer John Carter series from Dynamite [Warlord of Mars: Dejah Thoris Volume 1 - The Colossus of Mars TP] were my only other resource and I'm really happy to report that the film follows along pretty much along the lines of the campy, pulp style of the early 20th century.2012 is the 100th anniversary of the publication of A Princess of Mars and so I was hoping this film would capture the spirit and it did!  Pro reviewers online were wondering about the film's derivation or why the Tharks had tusks, blah blah.  Clearly they had not read the book!Burroughs is actually related to John Carter and finds Carter has died and ERB has inherited the estate and is left with a diary that is full of the adventures of Carter's time on Mars.  This is a common device with Burroughs's stories.  I recall his Pellucidar tales had a type of radio that the author would get his stories from.  Or on Barsoom, some kind of radio or telepathy was used.In the film, the first meeting of the Tharks and Tars Tarkas was really realistic from the book's perspective.  The personality of Tars is just what I would have imagined:  a Jeddack (king) of his people, proud, challenged and sees an opportunity to help his planet.The princess is also of the same mind:  she sees in Carter not only the salvation of her civilization, but also the salvation of his heart.  Carter's family was brutally murdered during his time in the Civil War and in burying him he lost all hope and all purpose in life.  Can Deja Thoris rekindle that purpose?The bad guys in the piece are Tharns.  I can't remember them from the novel but I have seen this type of tale before - immortal beings who hold sway over lesser beings and guide a planetary civilization to death and despair, and them move onto another one and do the same thing.  Their agents on Earth are prepping us while they mop up Mars (Barsoom).And I loved the special effects.  Helium I imagined more a city in the sky, but they had it down pretty well.  The flyers were as I imagined - giant Dragonfly designs and the fights in the sky were great to see.  The crowd scenes were fun, as well as the gladiator battles with the Great White Apes!Bottom Line:  Don't listen to the naysayers and closed-minded critics.  If you like camp, and long for those thrilling days of yesteryear, check out this film.  No, it's not the best film they could have made of our gentleman of Virginia, but the sum of its parts - Western, Science Fiction and Fantasy Adventure - were really well done.  Recommended.And don't forget the great music.  Got to catch the soundtrack.Get the original books and the movie novelization too:John Carter of Mars: The Collection - A Princess of Mars; The Gods of Mars; The Warlord of Mars; Thuvia, Maid of Mars; The Chessmen of MarsJohn Carter: The Movie Novelization: Also includes: A Princess of Mars (John Carter of Mars)Other Books Mentioned in this Review:The Pellucidar SeriesTarzan: The Complete Adventures of Edgar Rice BurroughsVENUS SERIES COMPLETE COLLECTION (PIRATES OF VENUS-LOST ON VENUS-CARSON OF VENUS-ESCAPE ON VENUS-THE WIZARD OF VENUS)) BY EDGAR RICE BURROUGHS -THE AUTHOR OF JOHN CARTER OF MARS and TARZANAnd don't forget the comic books:John Carter, Warlord of Mars OmnibusJohn Carter of Mars: Weird Worlds
summary: Stunning Science Fantasy by the Master Burroughs!

reviewText: This movie surprised me.  After waiting until John Carter hit video, I sat down to watch, telling my wife we could turn it off if it was as bad as we had heard.  After sitting through the entirety of this wonderful film without leaving our seats, which we never do, we had to ask each how this was such a failure at the box office (this is not a film for critics, so who cares about them in this case).  From start to finish this was the second most fun I've had watching a movie all year (Avengers was my #1).  Now, I haven't read the books, so how well this translates the source I don't know (or care really).  A movie is NOT a book, so anyone looking for that, go read a book.  As a thrilling adventure that has it's feet firmly placed in the past while taking every advantage possible of modern special effects John Carter is a spectacularly fun film.  The entire cast was excellent, especially Taylor Kitsch who plays Carter as a man with nothing left in him but a hope that gold will fill the void within.  The worst part of the movie is the end title which implied more films would follow (which is now obviously out of the question).  If you didn't give this one a chance and like a little old school flavor in your action films, or just a fun filled romp, don't let it pass you by.

reviewText: I sure do hope that the DVD sales of John Carter make up for the bomb that the movie was in theaters. Because at this point I think any studio would be hard pressed to risk another big budget to bring a sequel to the big screen, and that's a shame really. John Carter was an excellent movie that for whatever reason didn't get a fair shake with critics.John Carter is based on Edgar Rice Burroughs' "Barsoom Series",  and the John Carter story was only the first in a series of 11 novels (circa 1917 - 1960something).  So there is/was plenty of sequel potential. But as I mentioned above, I won't be holding my breath for any sequels.Perhaps in addition to the odd slew of negative reception by critics, John Carter also suffered from bad marketing by Disney. I remember seeing the trailers for the movie and not being too impressed. It looked weird and unbelievable; some dude fighting monsters on Mars in prehistoric garb with spaceships flying around. And that's not too far off the mark, but the movie's a lot better than that description makes it sound.In a nutshell, in the late 1800s, John Carter is a Civil War vet that the army wants back in its ranks. While running from the army, he also runs into some hostile Indians and gets chased into a cave where coincidentally some portal or gate is being used by an "alien" life form. And Carter inadvertently gets sucked into the gate and lands on Mars where the new war that he'll be involved in is anything but civil. I'm gonna go out on a limb and suggest that the idea was not that Carter gets transferred to Mars as we know it, but Mars in an alternate universe, because John Carter's Mars is fully capable of sustaining human (and non-human) life.The movie has a great story, plenty of action, terrific CGI and it's decently acted. While it ran a little long at just over 2 hours, I was completely entertained from start to finish. And I was left hoping for more. And indeed John Carter was intended to be the first in a trilogy. But according to Entertainment Weekly, Disney expects to lose up to $200MM on John Carter and those kinds of negative numbers won't have Mickey Mouse green-lighting any sequels.But see John Carter. It stands alone as a great film, and while it may leave you wanting more, the open ending can be satisfied with the viewer's own imagination.

reviewText: I had to write a review of this one. I saw it in the theater, not sure if I would like it or not, b/c as many others have attested, the previews and advertising were hard to make sense of. Long story short, though, it was one of the most enjoyable cinematic experiences that I have had in a long time. I was thoroughly impressed with pretty much every aspect of this film, and I highly recommend it, especially if you have been holding off so far. One thought that kept coming to mind was, "this is what the first two Star Wars prequels (which I found quite disappointing) *wish* they could have been like (but were not)." Not that a direct comparison is warranted, but John Carter uses visual effects technology in the best possible way, to drive the story in a captivating manner that transports you to another place. Additionally, if like me you have not read the source material ("Princess of Mars" by ERB), the film will actually have some surprising plot twists and things that keep you wondering, which is always nice. It was/is a terrible shame that this performed so poorly at the box office, because it is such a well made film, and everyone who worked on it should be given great credit for not losing the quality at all when working on such a big project. Many films of far inferior quality have made way more money, and this one should have had so much going for it. Blame the poor advertising, I guess. Even the DVD cover art is horrible, in my opinion. I would not watch a movie if I had to decide based on cover art like that. But this one is so good. Just give it a shot.

reviewText: So I can't review the actual quality of the Blu-Ray since it has yet to be released, but this was a fantastic and under-appreciated movie.  I've seen it three times in the theater.  Simply put, people who see it, love it.  Unfortunately more people haven't seen it due to bad buzz prior to the film's release.  Its based on the science fiction book series John Carter of Mars by Edgar Rice Burroughs (better known as being the creator of Tarzan).  The first book, Princess of Mars which is what this story is based on, was initially published 100 years ago!  If you are a fan of modern science fiction you owe it to yourself to check this movie out because it inspired all of it.  Star Wars, comic book heroes, and Avatar in particular--all of them were inspired by John Carter's adventures.  The acting is great and there is some solid action sequences to be found here as well.  I also really enjoyed the music, which comes from the composer behind Lost and 2009's Star Trek.  The special effects have to be seen to be believed.  When John Carter is interacting with the green aliens of Mars its seamless, you can't tell whats real and whats computer animated. Give it a try!  You will enjoy it, I can promise that.

What got me is that it seems the directors expected you to have read about this before watching and made a lot of assumptions that viewers were familiar with the story. reviewText: Don't listen to the critics.  I've my own ideas as to why they trashed this movie but ignore their hating, or you'll miss a pretty great movie.  Yes, the movie is a little over-long but the plot is straight forward and the effects are excellent.  Disney is notorious for being cheap in the effects department but I was constantly surprised for two hours how high-end the production values were.  I don't think I've ever seen a Disney film that was this grand and on such large a scale.  It's definitely a sweeping epic.The best part about this film is it's deeper message.  It's not just about a guy who ends up on Mars and falls in love with a princess.  Not by a LONG shot.  In fact, the message is almost spoken word-for-word by the villian of the story.  This movie is really a wakeup call for everyone on earth today.  It's symbolic of what's happening on our own planet right NOW.  Clandestine persons or parties instigate wars to further their own agenda.  They don't actually fight the wars.  They just "manage" them, as was said in the film.  This cycle of war and causing divisions among groups within a civilization makes them easier to manipulate and facilitates the takeover of their lives and planet.  THAT's what this movie is really about and what we all need to pay attention to at this moment in time.  It's amazing that the book was written 100 years ago.  Burroghs must have been able to foresee the future.My only complaint would be Taylor Kitsch.  He's very pretty to look at, but I wish he had more range as an actor rather than "hot looking brute".  Highly recommended for all of the above but especially for the message.
summary: Big Movie with a Big Message

reviewText: Sci/fi films have been much too few and far between. Wait, make that good sci/fi films. With utter bombs like AVATAR (aka POCAHONTAS or FERN GULLY (take your pick) in outer space) and the purely dreadful THE DAY THE EARTH STOOD STILL, it has been a while since we've seen a rollicking good epic sci/fi-fantasy that comes across as fun and with a breath of originality. But it definitely delivered in Disney's JOHN CARTER.I will admit I had lower expectations going in on this one. I had such high hopes for Disney's PRINCE OF PERSIA a couple years ago, but the storyline and characters were just too simple and predictable. But here, with JOHN CARTER, there's a mild complexity to the story that delivers on the right levels.The story starts out with Captain John Carter, former Confederate soldier, being hounded by the Union soldiers to help fight in a war against the Native Americans in Arizona. But when Carter tries to escape from an attack, he winds up hiding out in a mysterious cave with strange markings and lots of gold. And that's when the strange man appears from nowhere, and John Carter suddenly finds himself transported across the galaxy to Mars. With a world on the edge of destruction, an evil warlord with a powerful weapon, and a mysterious race of beings representing a goddess, John Carter must decide which side of the war to fight on -- or whether to fight at all. But the fate of an entire race is in his hands. And it isn't only a warlord after him -- something much more powerful wants John Carter dead.CGI runs rampant throughout the film, but it's never overdone or obvious -- it's subtle in all the right ways, but delivering epic and astounding shots. There's a wonderful exotic look to the film that I don't think has been seen in years. The sets are amazing, and definitely took my imagination to task.My only beef with the film is the acting in the very first few scenes, where Taylor Kitsch (playing the titular hero) comes across a slight bit stiff. Once John Carter's on Mars working through his character development, he seems to come into his own. Lynn Collins is breath-taking as the Princess, and Mark Strong pulls off another great performance as well. The side characters complement the storyline and the main handful of leads.After I left the theater, it kept growing in my mind, just how much I enjoyed JOHN CARTER. The music (another wonderful score by Michael Giacchino) is haunting and truly worthy of this epic tale based on Edgar Rice Burroughs' source material. There are some very fun nods to the book series the movie originates from, and readers of those will be chuckling along the way. Don't miss out on this one.

reviewText: A Familiar Story100 years after it was first published Edgar Rice Burroughs' sci-fi epic FINALLY is done justice on the big screen. Under-hyped, over-budget, and helmed by a first-time live-action director most famous for directing CGI animated films for a general audience, John Carter is a sci-fi fantasy adventure triumph, and not only the best film of the summer so far, but the best movie I've seen all year.Anyone who has read the books knows the basic story, and many do even if they haven't. A cavalryman at the end of the American Civil War gets magically transported to Mars where his already formidable fighting skills become super-human thanks to the low gravity of Mars. He gets caught up in a war, rescues a Princess, and saves the day. Anyone who faults the movie for repeating tropes of the past should take a moment to consider something Isaac Asimov once said:"There is no such thing as an original idea." Does John Carter feature gladiator arena fights, a princess in distress, all the usual adventure movie themes? Yes it does. Do Star Wars and Avatar and dozens of other movies feature the same themes and tropes? Yes they do. The books written by Edgar Rice Burroughs did it a hundred years ago, but that's not the point. The point is that the movie does it again, but it does it WELL.That Old Saturday MatineePeople don't seem to care for movies that cater to the love of the old serials like they used to. When Star Wars came out it ushered in a whole era of fan-boy love for old-school adventure. When Indiana Jones came out it got the same level of excitement boiling in the blood of genre fans. Then Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow came out and everyone seemed to forget what movies were all about as it crashed and burned at the box office. The new Star Wars movies came out and people were so demanding in their expectations that they ceased to enjoy good old-fashioned sci-fi cheese for it's own sake (it's supposed to be fun!). And now here we are with John Carter and the same people are making the same mistakes all over again. John Carter is not a throw-away film. It's the best example of it's genre in a LONG time. It's better than the Star Wars Prequels. It's better than the fourth Indiana Jones (which is under-rated in my opinion). And it's a WHOLE lot better than Marvel's The Avengers.A Tour-De-Force of Wildly Entertaining CinemaThis film really does have everything you could possibly want in a summer blockbuster. After I saw it I just couldn't believe it didn't get a July 4th opening, because it deserved to be THE movie of the summer. The film is well-directed, with excellent pacing, timing, and framing. It keeps you watching closely every second, and wastes no time. The photography is beautiful, showing us alien vistas and armies reminiscent of monster films and sword and sandal classics. The fighting is never off-screen, cut-away, or out-of-frame (unlike the horribly directed close-up hand-to-hand fights in the Avengers).The jokes are genuinely and universally funny, viewing after viewing. The writing is sharp and neither overly sparse nor overly wordy. The editing of this film is excellent, yielding a compact, compelling picture that never drags. The CGI is excellent, and even characters that are completely CGI are believable and very human in their emotions and actions (take that JarJar!). There is a bit of a cartoonishness to the CGI, but it simply blends with the world of the movie so well (like Avatar) that I don't mind it at all. The sound effects could win an academy award, and the music DEFINITELY should. John Carter has the most recognizable theme I've heard in a very long time, and the score is dynamic, taking us through all the emotions of joy, sorrow, romantic longing, and heroic triumph.Most importantly, this film has HEART. There is character development, actual PLOT (scheming forces manipulating rulers and others to bring destruction, an internal struggle to let go of the past and fight to create a future). The action sequences are spectacular, but none is so memorable as when our hero has a series of flashbacks to painful past events while fighting endless hordes of green-skinned Martians all alone. I cried during that sequence. That's movie magic.What a Summer Movie Should BeSome people go to movies to see something shocking. Some go to see something dark and edgy. I go to get away from my problems and be reminded that anything is possible. I go to experience a sense of wonder, and most of all, to be entertained. John Carter is a masterpiece of these elements. If you have the right mindset it will make you feel like a kid again. It will let you forget about the world and be magically transported to a far away world. And you will be VERY entertained.John Carter is unapologetic escapist fantasy. Most good things in life are. The only flaw that I can think of is that the film SHOULD have been called John Carter of Mars (as it is on the End Title). Maybe then more people would have seen it. I saw it twice in the theater and only wish I could have seen it a few more times. Don't rent this movie. Buy it. On Blu-ray. Now!
summary: "A warrior may change his metal, but not his heart."

reviewText: As a fan on the book, I enjoyed this adaptation. I felt it was true enough to the source material than other adaptations, and was clearly made by someone who loved the book. If only Disney had properly advertised it as the story that inspired the genre that gave birth to Star Wars, Dune, etc... Edgar Rice Burroughs practically invented the planetary epic genre, yet Disney did nothing to exult this fact, leading many to wrongly conclude that the story was a rip-off of the films and stories that it, in fact, inspired. Sure, Taylor Kitsch was a little wooden in his performance, but overall he pretty much fit the character of John Carter from my own mind's image of him from reading the books.

reviewText: I really enjoyed John Carter 3D a lot. The story was fantastic as were the characters. The 3D was stunning especially when they floated into Lake Powell. A lot of great scenes for the surrounding landscape, CGI and earth. Some great filming locations. For a post conversation 3D movie it was done very well, with many of layers of depth. Only a few scenes where it looked silly and did not blend with the background. But 99.5% of the movie looked fantastic in 3D and the animated characters flowed very well with humans. The lead characters looked beautiful and the chemistry was great. It's hard to believe this movie did not do well at the box office, but hey 4.5 stars on Amazon. Perhaps Disney dropped the ball with advertising this movie correctly. I for one would love to see John Carter part 2.  I watched The Hobbit An Unexpected Journey 3D recently and I thought John Carter was a far superior movie yet The Hobbit was more successful. Go Figure.For 3D collectors, this one belongs in your collection, Enjoy!

reviewText: I read the Edgar Rice Burroughs series about 50 years ago. At the it was difficult too imagine how someone could do a decent job translating the concept to  film. This film does an excellent job of it. Unfortunately, Jeddak and other terms and concepts don't sound so original when bastardized forms of them were used in Star Wars and Avatar. Both films borrowed heavily from Burroughs 1911 book and it's 10 sequels. To anyone unfamiliar with the original works, the Carter movie probably looks like the "rip off".I'd recommend reading the 2 original books, then watch the movie, then read the "novelization, then watch Luke Skywalker and Avatar. If you take notes, it could be the basis for an interesting doctoral thesis.Buy John Carter and watch it on a regular basis.

reviewText: Overall, I really liked this movie. I just wish some things would have been done better.Good - followed ideas in book well while making a few adaptations. Female lead grew into role. Her dialogue was flat but she did well despite that. The  fight scenes were pretty good, but I wish they would have expanded those parts.Marginal - but was a little ambitious.... It took things from a few different books, which made explanations necessary, which increased the length of the movie. It got long at times. Also, tried to consider too many themes. This, in my untrained opinion, was the greatest weakness. Simplicity would have been better.Bad - Didn't like the costumes that much. The comic books when I was a kid were better interpretations, in my opinion. Also, the tattoos and John Carter constantly being dirty was distracting. Not really what I was looking for in a romance.
summary: followed ideas in the book well

reviewText: The first slow scene is when the father talks to his daughter...dads all wrapped up in shiny armor, which just like in opera, makes a performance seem like a tree standing. They simply didn't have a clue as to how the scene should be in terms of creating an entertaining moment. The daughter needed to have tons of attitude, and dad needed to be banging his head against the wall....instead it really slows up the film. I imagine once special effects added the proper visual layering to the scene, it was going to be too expensive to reshoot when they saw what they had. The rest of the film is a gorgeous blast. Incredible detail in the effects take it to another level, and you won't see this level  again unless you're watching something like Marvel's The Avengers, which also had absolutely top quality effects and design work. So make sure you see this film in Blu-Ray, as it's visual details are fabulous. At the moment, I can't remember the other slow scene. THe 3-D was excellent too.
summary: There's only two slow short scenes in this otherwise great film

reviewerName: The Movie Guy "Movies from A to Z"
reviewText: The blockbuster "Avatar" was loosely based on this book as was "The Princess of Mars." Edgar Rice Burroughs (Daryl Sabara), the author of the book, plays a part in the film in order to give credence to the tale. The tale is patterned on the common early 20th century belief that Mars was inhabited by a dying race with technology greater than our own.The character of John Carter (Taylor Kitsch) is nicely introduced through a series of events that take place in Arizona. Carter, a soldier of the lost cause is suddenly transported to Mars and finds himself part of a different war. Because of the low gravity of Mars, John Carter finds that he can run faster and jump higher than the natives. There are two warring factions of humans and giant green creatures just to add to the mix.Lynn Collins plays the warrior princess who wants John Carter to help her defend her city of Helium. Carter, wants only to return to Earth.This movie is finally a fitting tribute to the works of Burroughs. When you watch it, you think, "Oh, this has been done before," or "that was taken from Star Wars..." But really this wasn't taken from them, they borrowed from Burroughs. Modern movie goers might find this film a bit cliche and trite. As a sci-fi fan who loves 50's sci-fi stuff, this was 5 stars.No f-bombs, sex, or nudity. Tween safe.

reviewText: More and more I believe modern audiences are going to the movies expecting to be disappointed.  This is partly owing to pre-release media bombardments featuring a given film's highlights and then after we're lured into the theater we discover that those scenes were no more than window-dressing for sound and fury.  Yes, John Carter has those big, action scenes but they are absolutely essential for "bringing to life" what was originally an adventure, sci-fi/fantasy book series.There will, no doubt, be many reviewers that want to contrast this film with past monolithic sci-fi/fantasy adventures but let us not forget that long, long before Star Wars or Avatar there was John Carter of Mars; a fantasy series created by Edgar Rice Burroughs around the same time period as WWI and which remains to this day, one of the most imaginative mythologies in fantasy and sci-fi literature of all time.  When they were written, Burroughs' novels were considered more pulp fiction or fantasy entertainment for perhaps a less mature audience than serious fiction; however I believe that the film adaptation has definitely added levels of maturity and character complexity that were never fully developed in the books.  For example the principal character John Carter, although a natural fighter, is haunted by his tragic past as a Civil War veteran which causes him to resist an inherent, heroic inclination and compels him to simply drop out of society or at least obtain the option to distance himself from it (e.g. his gold prospecting).  Add to this the fact that he's suddenly hurled into an alien world complete with "civil wars" and racial tensions of its own where he is literally confronted with an option to embrace a separate "destiny" within the context of a new life.  The movie adaptation does not however force Carter to face these struggles alone because the role of Dejah Thoris has been transformed from a pretty piece of furniture, doomed to be continually taken captive as she was in the books, to an incredibly intelligent, as well as beautiful warrior princess  that proves herself to be every bit a heroine of Mars.  Ever since Dragonheart we have seen completely CGI animated characters in major roles, with Gollum in LOTR taking this potential to new levels and more recently the character of Caesar in Rise of the Planet of the Apes.  This is also the case with another leading character in this film, i.e. Sola a female member of the Thark race (the distinctive Green Martians), as a sympathetic and courageous supporting role.I always loved the creativity of Burroughs in his books but I equally admire what the writers and producers have done with the film John Carter.  Much of the cinematography looks reminiscent of the wonderful book covers that Michael Whelan did back in the 90's (lol, one of the reasons they originally appealed to me).  And of course, modern innovations in CGI have made it possible for such a fantastic universe as this to be transformed into a live-action feature film.  As with LOTR, the special effects supplement a great story rather than supplant a shallow story that only serves as a vehicle for cleverly-arranged, silver-screen pixels (e.g. transformers or the re-booted Star Trek).John Carter does not appear to be a "feel good" movie (although the kids in the theater seemed to like it) or sci-fi for the masses like Avatar; rather it seems to me that Disney might be targeting true sci-fi/fantasy lovers rather than producing typically forgettable crowd pleasers.  Is it possible that Disney is actually bucking the Hollywood trend?if I could give this one 10 stars I would because it's just so exceptional given the climate of modern movies.  It's truly a visually stunning movie with a multitude of memorable scenes, an excellent musical score and it honestly reminded me of the experience of seeing the original Star Wars in the theater as a kid.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Edgar Rice Burroughs (creator of Tarzan) wrote A Princess of Mars in 1912.  It, and all of his work, is pulp fiction at its best (or worst)!  What it lacks in realism, character development and import, it more than makes up for in action, adventure and good story-telling.  Scientific understanding, of course, goes out the window.  Even in Burroughs'  time, it was well known that Mars was a frigid, lifeless planet.  Yet Burroughs' planet Mars, if I recall, was a hot, dry planet, populated with all sorts of humanoids and beasts. Silly but imaginative, his books BEG to be made into fun summer movies.  Now, 100 years later, with CGI, we have the capability to do his imagination justice.John Carter is worth watching once, maybe twice, for the action and special effects.  It's superior to Episodes I, II, and III of Star Wars, for sure.  Particularly neat about the special effects is the steampunk appearance of the flying machines.So where did the Disney folk go wrong?  In the CASTING of the humans!  Taylor Kitsch does nothing but scowl the entire movie.  He's too damn scrawny and his hair's too long and scraggly. And finally, with dark circles around his eyes, he looked white and sickly against all the red-skinned Martians.  A better choice for Carter, in my opinion, would be Chris Hemsworth (or his brother), who played Thor. Lynn Collins as Dejah Thoris, the Martian princess, is OK she's but not much of an actress.  At one point she cries but sheds no tears.  With the millions spent on special effects, couldn't somebody have sprung for glycerin drops?In Burroughs' book, Carter is immediately smitten upon his first view of Dejah Thoris and battles all of Mars to win her love.  Disney's Carter and Thoris have no chemistry together and you get no sense they are in love.  The computer generated green Martians and even the Martian dog have far more emotion.So my recommendation is to do an Amazon rental of this movie. I don't feel it's worth owning.

reviewText: When John Carter came out, it was considered one of the biggest flops of 2012, and arguably of all time.  Evidently much was spent on casting and effects, with not much return.However, I recently watched this film and was pleasantly surprised as to how good the film is.  Based on the Mars novels of Edgar Rice Borroughs (the creator of Tarzan), John Carter is a stirring story with great visuals.The computer effects in this film are amazing.  I have read that the film was made and then adapted to 3D for the theater, which may have made the 3D version lackluster.  However the aliens are fantastic, and the sets, props and vehicles all add to the movie magic.The story is quite exciting, with John, a Civil War veteran in the US, whisked away to a similar civil war on Mars.  John develops super-like powers of quickness and strength with the change in gravity, etc., and assists the oppressed in making a difference in their world.Thus John Carter was an entertaining treat that a lot of people seem to have missed.

reviewText: I can see why the movie wasn't a big hit in the theaters.  It wasn't spectacular and it wasn't horrible.  It was okay.  But people expected fantastic and didn't get it.  They, in turn, felt it was junk and trashed it.  That was perhaps unfair but I don't think that JC deserves 5 stars on Amazon either.  Still, glad a lot of people really love it as I like to see Disney do well.What barely elevates this average actioner with cool special effects is the very end.  There are a couple of twists that occur that I won't spoil and that won't be expected and, importantly, the formerly unlikable John Carter finally becomes a likable character.  Seriously, the dude is unlikable pretty much throughout the entire movie.  He's a griseled, nail-spittin' Civil War cavalryman who is embittered and living for himself.  His transformation is slow and not well-drawn throughout the movie.  He's largely a resistance fighter, even by movie's end.  What saves him is his need for and ability to fall back into love.The bonus features have a nice historical retrospective of "The Princess of Mars" storyline and on Edgar Rice Burroughs himself, both of which are far more interesting than the movie (how'd they manage that?), and are worth watching even if you didn't really dig on the movie.
summary: JC "John Carter" is a savior to some martians but he's no JC "Jesus Christ".

reviewText: "This wild tale begins thirteen years ago, in the Arizona Territory, between the Pinaleño Mountains and the backside of hell." After Civil war vet John Carter (Kitsch) refuses to join the new army he is imprisoned. After an escape he finds refuge in a cave where he meets a stranger with a strange medallion. Curious, Carter touches it and is transported out of the cave. He soon learns he is on Mars and is in the middle of another war. Going in to this I heard all the bad reviews and that this is the biggest bomb in Disney's history. I really didn't think it could be as bad as that. While I won't say it was good it was a little better then I expected. The biggest downfall to me is that it was pretty boring and seemed to drag the entire time. I also have to admit that although this is my opinion this movie seems very much geared toward younger boys. My 13 year old son thought it was OK and really liked the little monster dog thing. I thought that was cool too. I have to say that if you liked "Prince Of Persia" you will probably like this too. I just had a hard time getting into it. Overall, A slow moving and pretty boring movie that was a mix of "Star Wars" and "Avatar". Again though if you have a young son he will probably like this one. I give it a C+, my son gave it an A-.
summary: A mix of "Star Wars", "Avatar", 'Prince Of Persia" and "Army Of Darkness". Very much geared toward younger boys. I say C+

reviewText: Let me start by saying that I have not read the book this movie is based on. I have to admit that I only recently was excited enough to go see this movie. I ended up watching it in 3-D. The first 15 minutes or so of the movie were nothing special in 3-D. Once the action moved to Mars, things definitely looked a lot more visually impressive. I thought that the action sequences were pretty good. I feel like the director balanced out the action sequences and the non-action sequences nicely--basically, there was plenty of action, but not so much that I felt overloaded by it. The plot was not too complicated. I felt pretty engaged in the movie for most of it--even the early part where not much was going on. The main actors in it did an excellent job. The dialogue was not dull like it could've been. Honestly, I think the main difference between the regular 2-D version of it and the 3-D version is the clarity at which you can see the creatures on Mars. There are probably one or two other differences, but that's the main one I can think of. I wanted to primarily talk about my visual experience at the theater in this review. I figure that most people going to see this movie already know what it's about. I hope this helps some of you that might be trying to decide whether to see it in 3-D or 2-D.

reviewText: When the majority of the buzz surrounding your film is the question of how much it cost, then there's a problem that usually ends with some studio exec's head rolling on the floor.  With Walt Disney and director Andrew Stanton noticeably shaken over the numbers being thrown out about the cost of John Carter($250M! $300M!), that type of scrutiny has been their reality for the last month. What was the response? A full force marketing blitz that wreaked of desperation, which ended with a 10 minute sizzle reel of clips that turned out to be the perfect cure for insomnia.Unfortunately, that footage was an indicator of what was to come, as all of the dollars spent on re-shoots couldn't make John Carter any less of a boring, incomprehensible drag. Edgar Rice Burroughs, the famous adventure author and creator of Tarzan, would himself be up a tree if he saw what has become of his nearly century old Barsoom novels. Based on the first in the series, A Princess of Mars, the film is led by charisma-free Taylor Kitsch, showing none of the snap glimpsed when he played Gambit in the otherwise terrible Wolverine film. His John Carter is an emotionless cypher, a former captain for the Confederate army who can't seem to stay out of trouble. We're introduced to him via his notes, left behind for a young Burroughs(Daryl Sabara) to read. The author began nearly all of his Barsoom novels this way in a clever little twist, as if Carter's space faring adventures were real and he were simply discovering them. After an interminably long setup, Carter is mysteriously whisked away to the planet Mars, where presumably the action begins.Instead what we actually get is a string of poorly realized characters with convoluted back stories, droning on about some sort of civil war. Known as Barsoom to the natives, the world looks like the bone dry Tatooine segments in The Phantom Menace, only with less pod racing. Or if you like, imagine Waterworld without any water, and that's a pretty good idea of how lame this place is. It's also an indication of the level of convoluted political maneuvering you're likely to face. For some inexplicable reason, Sab Than(Dominic West) of the Zodangans hates the people of Helium, including their badly dressed king(a depressed looking Ciaran Hinds). Yet he wants to marry their feisty and very busty princess, Dejah Thoris(Lynn Collins), in a scheme devised by a bunch of bald headed mystical shapeshifters. Throw in some alien Tharks, a few white apes, and some random mumbo jumbo, and what you have is an action movie so convoluted it makes Inception look like Yogi Bear.It's not as if the plot is all that deep, it's just impossible to tell who anybody is or what their angle is. Nor will you care. Carter arrives and everyone thinks he's some sort of messiah because he can jump really far.  Imagine what the Hulk could do in that gravity. Pointless questions like this will infect your brain because nothing happening on screen will hold your interest.  At such an exorbitant cost, you'd think that money would have bought something more lively than a bunch of unimpressive lizards and mountain landscapes. Stanton, a Pixar vet who directed no less than the amazing Wall-E, appears tripped up by the source material. He certainly didn't have the same live-action success as his colleague Brad Bird did with Mission Impossible-Ghost Protocol. John Carter too closely resembles many films we've seen already, sadly ironic considering Burroughs novels were the impetus for so many of them.
summary: Somebody at Disney is gonna pay for this junk

reviewText: Perhaps you have already read about the disappointing performance of Disney's sci-fi adventure "John Carter" at the box office. I don't know who is responsible for that, but I know for sure that the film itself is not to be blamed. It is overlong, I admit, but "John Carter" is actually a pretty enjoyable adventure movie with stunning visuals and effective performances from the leads Taylor Kitsch and Lynn Collins.A Civil War veteran John Carter's adventures and romance on Mars, or "Barsoom," is very famous. Transported to the red planet (the film describes the process in detail), Carter fights with his super-jumping ability and falls in love with a beautiful princess of Mars. No wonder it took so long (100 years to be exact) for the Edgar Rice Burroughs classic story to be made into a film - a film of this scale, which needs imagination, storytelling skills, visuals and someone who can play John Carter.Taylor Kitsch is perfect as the hero, and so is Lynn Collins as a Princess of Mars Dejah Thoris, but it is Carter's ever faithful pet Woola that steals the show. The combat scenes are to me a bit too fast and busy, but they are still exciting with first-rate special effects. Some characters' motives are not convincing, but the slick narrative almost makes us forget that."John Carter" (or "John Carter of Mars") is flawed. First of all, it needs a better title. This is the first live-action film by Andrew Stanton ("WALL-E"), acclaimed director whose excellent use of visuals is seen here, but not his tight narrative style.That said, "John Carter" is a very good sci-fi action film, much better than you are led to believe by negative reviews and disappointing box office results.
summary: John Carter and Princess of Mars; Thrilling Adventure Movie
