reviewText: I sort of like this movie, and yet I don't like it and I wish I did. I guess I just feel ambiguous about it. I can appreciate it intellectually, but I can't FEEL for it.It is a conundrum, wrapped in an enigma, with a mystery.The conundrum is why don't I feel more about this film... why didn't it move me as it should have?The enigma is why Disney produced it under their name (instead of Touchstone or another of their properties) -- implying this is a type of "kids" movie or family entertainment (which it isn't), and why did it fail in the Box Office and among critics and so many film goers?The mystery is how all the amazing talent that went into this fell so flat on screen.Pros:Very Lavish Production - sets and scenery are excellent, CGI work top notch and seamless.Good Actors - convincing us that they are the characters they portray.Fast Paced Action - plenty of action scenes - in fact these are what help hold the movie together.Relatively Faithful to the Source - based on the ERB "Princess of Mars" and other John Carter series of books. Follows the basic plot of POM with some elements from later books thrown in.Cons:Lavish Production is Eye Candy - While the sets are excellent, we get no reason WHY they are what they are. We see everything in very fast cut scenes (including the characters) as if the camera is afraid to linger on a scene long enough for our eyes to focus.Little or No Character (and possibly actor) Chemistry - It didn't seem like the characters really cared for or about each other. Carter and the Princess are at odds only because they have different goals. We don't know what they FEEL about each other or much of anything else. Tars Tarkas is interested in John Carter because he can jump? Huh? There's got to be more. Okay Tars is a CGI character but other films have paired CGI with live characters with a lot more chemistry.Fast Paced Action Too Fast - The camera never stops to linger on anything, it just keeps moving around so we don't see anything in detail or depth. We see lot's of battle scenes with hand to hand combat in what is supposed to be an advanced civilization. Huh? The Tharks have guns, but the people of Helium and Zodanga have swords? Why?Relatively Faithful to the Source - ERB wrote the John Carter series starting as a novel that was later turned into a magazine serial. It was designed to keep readers buying the magazine to read the next installment. In this genre, character is weak and adventure and suspense are high. That's what the audience expects for this type of literature.  The movie seems to follow that approach, which makes it a bit of an empty film. It didn't translate to screen well and lost what made the books appealing. How did they manage this?Pointless Back Story - Why did they put in the back story about ERB as a real person being the nephew of a real life John Carter? It wasn't necessary! The novel explains why JC goes to Mars and comes back several times, perfectly well. The movie could have eliminated the back story, been shorter and less confusing if it simply followed the book better. Having someone appear as ERB in the movie didn't add credibility for me, it seemed to be a cheap attempt at getting credibility -- as if the producers knew the movie wasn't going to fly on its own.------------------------Overall, the movie has all the parts of a good well crafted film, but they didn't hold together for me. I didn't feel any sympathy for John Carter until well into the film when we are FINALLY shown why he is so empty headed - that he lost his wife and child in some sort of attack by someone or other who burn down his house while he is away doing something or other. Action without reason leads to a cognitive disconnect. If this part of the movie (it wasn't in the books) was closer to the beginning (in fact, it could have replaced the back story) we'd have some sympathy for the character from the outset. Instead, Carter comes off as obnoxious for no apparent reason other than he is an idiot. People generally do have motivations for being who they are. The film should have gotten this underway a lot sooner.John and the Princess Dejah Thoris are at odds with each other throughout most of the film. They have different goals. Carter wants to get back to Earth, Thoris wants to save her city of Helium from being overtaken by Zodanga. This was never in the original book, but it could work today as a motivation. Thoris misses what should have been obvious, that she has to motivate Carter into coming to her aid (apparently because he can jump over tall buildings... not sure why this is a great advantage). If the film had developed her character into more of this type of leadership, she could have helped Carter go through a necessary catharsis (i.e. recover a motivation for living a full life) about his family loss and develop as a character. She could have been more passionate about her Helium and her hatred of Zodanga. We just don't get much of anything. It's not the actor at fault here, the script doesn't have the content for her to work with.We are looking at an alien world with fascinating looking beings and an alien culture. ERB did give them good descriptions and it appears that the movie follows that. But ERB also gave the Tharks and others a sense of motivation. They had a reason for their wanderings in the Martian desert (to gather their young hatchlings - which gets done in a few minutes towards the start of the film). Tars Tarkis is a leader among his people in the book, and there, we understand why. In the book, Carter learns about the Tharks, how they live, and why they do what they do. There is chemistry. Unfortunately in this movie, we just see THAT they exist without any reason other than to fight among themselves and get caught up in the war between Helium and Zodanga.Admittedly, the novel wasn't "deep", and was mostly about fighting among the peoples of the planet. That was in 1911. We have advanced somewhat since then, and the movie could have added some substance to the story. They tried with the introduction of the mysterious manipulators/villains the Thern, but I think it was the wrong way to go. They just are annoying meddlers. They could have been much more interesting, if they had a reason for being in the movie. But like all the characters, they are there, with no real reason.I found myself thinking of the very first Star Wars. It's not good when one movie makes you think of another! But all that made Star Wars good seems to have fallen flat in John Carter.In SW, we have the character of R2D2. He looks like a vacuum cleaner, has no comprehensible dialog, yet he becomes one of the most endearing characters in the series. In Carter we have the Woola, a dog-like thing which basically serves a similar cinematic purpose. Only it doesn't quite work. There is no interaction between the Woola and Cater to explain the animal's devotion to him.In SW we got Chewbacca the Wookie. He's large, furry, makes no linguistic sense (he can't speak words) but we love him because of himself. In Carter we have Tars Tarkas. He's large, green and he CAN make linguistic sense, but who cares? We never get any chemistry from him, any message, any motivation, and he was voiced by one of the best actors in Hollywood, Willem Dafoe. What the heck happened?In SW we have a Princess, Leia, who is trying to save her world. She's annoying perhaps, but spunky and feisty and we really like her. In Carter, we have Thoris, also a Princess, but she has no spunk, no energy and who really cares? She's beautiful (much more than Leia) and seems to be eye candy more than character.It is probably unfair to compare Carter with Star Wars - but it begs the question... what did Lukas do right, that the folks at Disney missed? And HOW did they miss it? Lukas had to invent the entire Star Wars Universe. Disney had it handed to them on a platter by ERB and somehow they still missed the boat!The John Cater books were highly successful and lasting. People still read and enjoy them today more than 100 years after they first appeared. The source material has a loyal audience. HOW did this movie lose out on all that?---------------------Conclusion:John Carter as a film is worth a look simply because it is the first attempt to capture the ERB JC Mars novels on screen.It has a good look, but not much else.So I'd suggest a cheap rental (like for $3.99 which Amazon isn't currently offering) because it helps you spend 2 hours wondering - what was Disney thinking?I can't say I liked the movie, I can't say I didn't like the movie.All I can do is ask, how did it fall so flat when they had ALL the pieces to make a really great film?Mildly entertaining, but nothing to get excited over.Sorry Disney. You've done such good films in the past.Pity this one came off as such a dud.
summary: John Carter Leaves More Questions Than Answers - on All Levels

reviewText: George Lucas in his creation of STAR WARS, James Cameron in his creation of AVATAR, the creators of Buck Rogers, the creators of Flash Gordon, and countless other writers and film directors for almost a century owe a tremendous amount of gratitude to Edgar Rice Burroughs and his Barsoom Chronicles (beginning with A PRINCESS OF MARS , first published under a different title in a short story in 1912). Burroughs is best known for creating Tarzan. However, Burroughs dabbled in several different genres, including science fiction. The most popular of these were the Barsoom Chronicles which feature John Carter and his descendants. After discovering John Carter a few years ago, I had looked forward to a major motion picture based upon Burrough's story. A PRINCESS OF MARS was a novel I toyed with transcribing into a screenplay of my own. Then, in the fall of 2011, I discover the story was being developed into a big-budget picture that was being directed by Andrew Stanton (director of FINDING NEMO and WALL-E) and co-written by literary darling Michael Chabon (author of THE AMAZING ADVENTURES OF KAVALIER AND CLAY). So, I put my own desires aside to see what kind of John Carter movie would be made. The final result is a great action movie and one of the best movies of 2012.The movie begins on Earth in 1881. John Carter (Taylor Kitsch) is being followed by an unknown tracker. He succeeds in getting to the telegraph office to send a telegraph to his nephew, Edgar Burroughs, who shows up only to discover that his uncle has passed away and has made him the sole heir of his estate. One of the items left behind is Carter's personal journal which Burroughs begins reading.The book flashbacks thirteen years to 1868. John Carter is a former decorated Confederate calvaryman who just wants to work in his mine in the dessert and dig for gold. However, the U.S. government wants Carter to work for them. Carter ends up getting chased and finds himself in a cave filled with gold before being immediately transported to some strange place. Carter is discovered by a race of giant, green, four-armed aliens who are outsiders in a civil war between two separate races of people. During a skirmish in the sky, Carter saves a woman who turns out to be Princess Dejah (Lynn Collins). The Princess will do anything to save her people, but her father wants her to marry the leader of the opposing army. She would, but she believes the marriage will ultimately lead to the destruction of the entire planet. Like the green aliens that discovered him, she believes he is the key to turning the tide and saving Barsoom (Mars).I was completely enthralled by JOHN CARTER. I loved the framing device at the beginning and ending of the movie. I loved the action sequences. I love the romance between Carter and Princess Dejah. I loved the bonding relationship that occurs between Tars Tarkas (Willem Dafoe) and Sola (Samantha Morton) after she learns she is his daughter. I love the playfulness of the giant dog-like creature Woola and his devotion to Carter. This is an action movie, but the acting is solid and the script is well-written.As far as flaws, the film doesn't have many. The movie does jump around here at the beginning and some filmgoers might have difficulty understanding exactly what is happening where. Also, I felt that the flashback sequences to Carter's wife and child were misplaced: they either should have been developed more or completely cut. Lastly, although most of the special effects in the movie are seamless, there is one scene that isn't. This scene occurs about two-thirds of the way through the movie where John Carter is driving beneath the moving city; some of the shots in this sequence look computer-generated and stand out.JOHN CARTER is a welcome surprise. Disney completely dropped the ball in the marketing department (thanks in part to the failure in 2011 of MARS NEEDS MOMS) with this movie because the ad campaign for the picture is one of the worst I've ever seen for a major motion picture. Hopefully, word of mouth will cause the movie to succeed where marketing and advertising executives failed because JOHN CARTER is the best movie of the first three months of 2012.
summary: A Sci-fi Movie 100 Years in the Making

reviewText: Despite the fact that everyone and their mother who bought this will no doubt write a review stating something very similar, I loved this movie so much I'm going to write one too; John Carter is a great, fun movie.Most people missed this one for 2 very big, very unfortunate reasons, the first being the marketing done for this movie was abysmal. I mean really, truly terrible. Second, for whatever reason, the media practically crucified this movie up to three months before it even premiered. I heard reports that this film was destined to flop before I even knew what it was called. For reasons I still can't fathom, no one in the media was on this films side. They didn't give this film a snow balls chance, much less the benefit of the doubt. Completely ignoring whether or not the film was good, they continually harped on how much it cost to make. As detrimental as that was to the movies eventual release, it is the first reason that really sealed "John Carter"'s fate.I can honestly say that I have never seen marketing this bad. The first trailer I saw for John Carter was a silent clip that showed no film footage and told me nothing about the film. As the weeks rolled by, things did not improve. The few commercials I saw made it look like a conan the barbarian rip off. Even the name "John Carter" hurt this great films chances of success. None of that matters though, because it is finally on DVD/Blu Ray and you can buy it for yourself, without having to wade though terrible ads and misleading media coverage.John Carter is about John Carters adventures on mars. I won't reveal more than that. The characters in this film aren't too deep, but they are enjoyable. The main antagonists are never fully explained, but they are no less effective because of it. The effects in this film are some of the best I have ever seen, and if you have a hd capable television, you are in for a treat.John Carter deserved to be a hit in the theaters. While that is no longer an option, at least now we can make sure it recieves the love it deserves on DVD/Blu Ray. Who knows; if enough of us buy it, maybe they'll make the much deserved sequel.
summary: Pure fun no matter what anyone says

reviewText: John Carter. Did it deserve the fate it received at the box office?  I'm not entirely sure what the answer to that is, but I do know, for what it's worth, the movie is an enjoyable adventure flick deeply rooted in its pulp fiction source.A story of an ex-Confederate soldier who finds himself in the middle of a planet wide conflict on the surface of Mars is pure pulp fiction and in that respect I ate up every minute of John Carter.  I've always enjoyed these kind of stories and John Carter is elbows deep in its background as a pulp serial.  This is swashbuckling action with a sci-fi background, and if that's what you came to see you will not be disappointed.The special effects of John Carter are solid, although they do leave something to be desired knowing the film's immense $250 million production budget.  Don't get me wrong, many of the visuals are stunning, but there is nothing that immediately comes to mind when I think about John Carter.  Sure, watching the film scene by scene I can say "That looks good" but never was there anything that just made me say "Wow!"  If I remember anything it's the design of the four-armed Tharks.Special effects don't make a movie, but the characters of John Carter leave a lot to be desired.  Taylor Kitsch lacks the necessary charisma to pull off his role and his chemistry with Dejah Thoris is non-existent.  Carter's alien allies Tars Tarkas (Willem Dafoe) and his daughter Sola (Samantha Morton) are probably my favorite characters in the film and it likely has more to do with their design than their writing.For the record: I have never read any of Edgar Wright Burroughs Barsoom novels.  I cannot say how this movie compares to A Princess of Mars or any other entry in the series.  As such I am not reviewing this movie as a fan.  It is my understanding that the movie has been divisive amongst the book series' fans mostly due to the fact that it compresses too much of A Princess of Mars's  plot into a relatively short running time.  That's just what I've heard.That being said, I wouldn't be surprised if this claim was accurate.  John Carter feels like a film that been cut down from a far longer running time and I am curious to know if a longer cut exists.  If Disney is ever willing to release an extended cut I am certainly willing to give it a watch.At the end of the day I'll say that Disney was in over their heads investing so heavily in this film.  I see no problem in adapting a source as old as John Carter, but it needed more memorable visuals, a charismatic lead, and some truly spectacular action sequences...but even then I don't think Disney should have sunk themselves so deep with this film's budget.John Carter is by no means a spectacular adventure movie, and Disney was in over their heads with the budget, but it is enjoyable for what it is.  There are some fun visuals, and some impressive effect sequences here and there.  As unlikely as it is I would enjoy seeing a sequel to John Carter.  So if you're looking for a fun movie to rent.  On Blu-Ray John Carter looks and sounds great.  If you want to test out your hi-def television or are interested in enjoying a pulp adventure I'd say John Carter is a winner.

reviewText: In my opinion, this is Disney's answer to 3D Avatar. The movie is very well done, use of 3D is about average, with nothing popping out of the screen that I can recall. Pop out is what I like most in 3D, but that's just me. The Director of the movie said he sought to be true to the book(s), and he was just that to the BOOKS. By that I mean that IF YOU HAVEN'T READ THE BOOKS, you'll be lost and not able to follow the story. However if you HAVE read the books (there's 13 in total, by Edgar Rice Burroughs) then you'll understand the movie. By the way, you can get the books on your NOOK for free by searching for $0.00 in the Nook book store. It's bound to be a classic, if for no other reason that the CEO of Disney resigned over this movie, because it wasn't the box office hit they were banking on. However, this will make a good addition to your 3D Blu-Ray collection.
summary: John Carter of Mars: Read the Books first!

reviewText: I get the feeling that this fantastic and amazing movie was purposely "assassinated" by warring interfactional "tribes" or individuals within Disney itself. Also complicit in this murder were the pretentious critics who probably never read books as children and cannot comprehend a movie that reflects as best it can the incredible imagination of Edgar Rice Burroughs. Imagine that this series of books was written in 1912, before any form of air travel existed on earth except for balloons. Yet Burroughs creates a world of sophisticated technology being used for baser instincts (war) and for sustaining all life on the planet. He created a planet with 2 equally intelligent species and illustrated how culture can determine the growth of each individual within that culture. And he created a smashing good story that has survived for 100 years. This movie was lovingly made with fine attention to incredible CGI effects that really places the viewer within the fantasy world of Mars that Burroughs created so long ago. The movie has adventure and great zest and charm. Some critics said there wasn't enough character development. Perhaps someone should tell them that Burroughs wrote adventure stories, not psychological thrillers. I truly loved this movie, and it pinged with a very small boy within myself who sat in the backyard in the summer immersed in the Burroughs series of John Carter related books. I feel great sadness for the vicious critics who somehow missed that phase of a child's life. If you like adventure set in a world of fantasy, you will love this movie. This movie deserves to be enjoyed and loved. I feel it will long outlive its negative critics that helped ensure it bombed in its movie distribution. I actually can see this becoming a great cult favorite over the years and perhaps help Disney recoop the massive sums used to make Barsoom (Mars) real.
summary: Great Movie - assassinated by pretentious critics and Disney

reviewText: Edgar Rice Burroughs' fav uncle John Carter "dies"; uncle leaves estate to Edgar along with a "diary" of his adventures on Mars & the fun ensues.  I really enjoyed it and had a good time watching it  after a string of dull, lifeless flicks lately.  John Carter is a memorable good time.  Fortunately, I didn't have any preconceived notions about it one way or the other; I knew nothing whatsoever about it.  Apparently it was some kind of critical flop & cost something like 250 million to make.  I could care less about all of that.  I think John Carter will hold up over the years quite well.  Yes, it's a Disney flick, but it's not really for young kids.  There's a whole lot of kick-ass and killing going on, with several dashes of lighter gore thrown in.  I liked it because it had a reasonably good plot with some reasonably good acting and some good laughs thrown in as well.  Throw in Lynn Collins in some very nice skimpy outfits & you've got my vote. I really had no complaints with this movie.
summary: John Carter is a memorable good time

reviewText: I love a good science fiction movie and as long as Hollywood doesn't screw it up by cutting it up to badly or skimp on the production the movie is usually satisfying. To cut it to the quick this movie was destine to be a classic and if you listen to the critics all you will get is a boxed up commercialized substitute for real scfi. I do have to say that Disney has been making the best movies when they choose to make them. My worry with Disney is that it looks like they have fallen into the trap of having to make a lot of money in order to keep the cogs of corporate profits rolling in. I think when a company gets as large as Disney it is very hard to know topical art/culture from cash cows....Back to John Carter, remember this was about that movie ;)I have to say I never read the books (sorry) but I am a avid Scifi/Fantasy enthusiast and this movie shines with new ideas. Ideas like presenting alien forms an cultures that are truly alien from the way we view how things should be done (ie Birthing and raising youth). Basically if you are a true scifi fan you will enjoy this movie and the critics, well they have to think they know what they are talking about even when the true fans know they haven't a clue. Enjoy.....

reviewText: The movie was given to me as a gift for Father's Day and I was a little nervous wondering if I would really like it. I thought I would like it after seeing all of the trailers for the movies and many people online who said they liked it have enjoyed the movie for the same reasons I thought I would. They said it was a fun adventure that had some great special effects. However, it received mixed reviews upon release and it did not do well at the box office. After viewing it I have to say I really liked it!I am not going to go into great detail about the movie but I will say what I did and didn't like about the movie. In the beginning there is a short prolog that tells the story of the conflicts between the civilizations on Mars, known as Barsoom to the natives. I wish that part was just a little clearer because for a while it was confusing for me to understand who was who and what was going on. I also think the early part of the movie before John Carter arrives on Mars could have fleshed out his character a little better. However, once you are on Mars and the confusion clears up the movie is very enjoyable with good character development with both John Carter and Dejah Thoris, a Princess of Mars who must enter into an arranged marriage in order to resolve the global conflicts. When John Carter arrives on Mars he is captured by a very tall green skinned multi-limb race of humanoids called Tharks. This warrior tribe eventually assists John Carter in his aid to save Dejah Thoris. John Carter's character development is an essential part of the story as his motivation goes from wanting to leave Mars and return to Earth to falling in love with Dejah Thoris and wanting to rescue her and resolve the planet's civil discord.I found as the movie goes along it gets better and better and really becomes an exciting action and adventure movie. I don't want to put too many spoilers in my review but the movie did hit a slight snag for me toward the end. Spoiler alert for the next part if you haven't seen the film: When John Carter gets transported back to earth against his will, his journey to return to Mars seems rushed. It also resolves some of the confusion form the opening of the movie, which is in reality setting up the ending. Its not that this part of the movie was bad, it wasn't, its just that coming so late in the movie the pace of it seems hurried.I wanted to make a comment about leading actor Taylor Kitsch as John Carter. There have been some complaints that he has been miscast because he doesn't portray a larger than life persona one would want in a warrior hero. To some extent that is true. His screen presence is not the best. Yet in the framework of the film it works. He is supposed to be just an average guy that is placed in extraordinary circumstances. When John Carter defeats the Giant white gorillas and Tal Hajus you finally see the larger than life warrior emerge. As I stated that is later in the film. All in all Taylor Kitsch is fine for the role of John Carter.Although I really enjoyed the movie it does have some flaws, which all movies do, and I do not think that it is bad at all. The saddest part for me is that the ending sets us up for a sequel and the movie really cries for one but with the poor performance at the box office we will probably never see one.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I read all of the Burroughs books as a kid.  They took me away from the miserable day to day world of elementary school of the 50s to better and more interesting worlds.  They inspired me to read about science on my own since what school provided was so light weight.  As an adult the books are dated.  However, I am now an avid sci fi  reader and still a science nerd.  I think this film will do for younger viewers what the books did for me; provide an entertaining and inspiring interlude.  Loved the settings, the costumes, and the story line.  I do not understand why this movie was poorly reviewed by the critics.  For me it was much better than the under scripted Conan and the dull Thor.  Give the film a change.  At least on streaming it is a bargain.

reviewText: Ive read the carter and carson books since I went to the boys club libery at a much younger age. The show would be exciteing to kids, but it did not have the character building ingredients of the original books. admittedly these ideas of fair play, good will win in the end over evil,chivelry. many ideas which in todays society are becomeing irrelevent were not present in the film. The movie was full of special effects which were great but the story lacked something.

reviewText: Better than I would have expected, given the critical and box office drubbing the film took. There's at least a good story here, with a sense of wonder about it, and an epic scale. Though the film does tend to get overwhelmed with the special effects at times, and it does get convoluted almost as much as David Lynch's Dune. Some good actors are mixed into the cast, particularly Mark Strong, who always does such a fine job playing the villain or the heavy. The leads have a fairly good chemistry going on, and the aliens are- unlike a certain George Lucas prequel creation that annoys everyone- rather nicely rendered and not at all frustrating. I think the film requires close attention, and multiple viewing to really appreciate it.
summary: Not Quite The Disaster I Was Expecting

reviewText: "John Carter" was so brutally savaged by most critics that I felt I was taking a chance buying the four-disk set (which I got at a very good price). Well, it's a delightful, highly entertaining film.Unlike the dreadful "Flash Gordon", "John Carter" respects its source. The tone is serious, without arch or campy humor. The story is treated as romantic fantasy, which is what it is. (Michael Giacchino's excellent score sets the right mood.) Though there's a fair amount of action, it's not excessive or gratuitous. The focus is principally on the characters. The ending is highly satisfying, and //almost// draws a tear. Almost.Taylor Kitsch (an unfortunate name for the star of a fantasy film!) isn't a great actor, but he's more than competent. His height (IMDB says he's 6', but he looks a lot shorter) and wiry build make him a believable 19th-century soldier.One assumes Roger Ebert's readers are more-perceptive than the average movie-goer, so it's notable that the viewer rating on Ebert's site is 3 out of 4 stars.Once people who didn't see "John Carter" in the theater see it on home video, they'll talk it up. "John Carter" is a good film that needs no apology, and will eventually be considered a classic fantasy.-------------------------------------------ADDENDUM ("PS" seemed weak)... It's rare to see a film receive such wildly varying audience reviews: "A masterpiece!" is followed by "It's garbage!". We all think we have better taste/judgment than those who disagree with us. Being no different, I feel obliged to stick in another two cents.No doubt fanboys (of which I an /not/ one) like films such as "John Carter" simply because they're acceptable adaptations of a favorite story. Then there are those who detest such films because they don't like the genre, or they find fault with (what they perceive as) "bad" acting/writing/direction.My all-time favorite film is the magnificently acted and directed "Amadeus". (Peter Shaffer's screenplay is merely "excellent". The acting and direction raise it to a perceived level of superbativeness.) I just got the DVD of "The Apostle", Robert Duvall's tour-de-force of writing, acting, and directing, to replace my LV copy. I'll be taking a course in screenwriting at TheFilmSchool in July (yes, really), and wanted to watch it at least once again. (If you haven't seen this film, /do so/.) I think I know the difference between "good" and "bad", writing-, acting-, and directing-wise.What, exactly, were the "John Carter" haters expecting? It's taken from pulp novels written by a man who felt he could churn out fiction at least as rotten (his word) as the cheap stuff he was reading. The film spends 1/7 its running time giving John Carter a backstory, so we know why he acts as he does. The story plays out as drama (though a weak one); the characters' personalities and interactions are generally plausible. (I don't know how much Michael Chabon contributed, but it's hard to believe he wouldn't have tried to push what is basically an action/adventure tale in the direction of a character-driven story.)"John Carter" avoids some of the clichés of romantic fiction. Carter might be a great sword-swinger, but he won't fight other people's battles. (This is why some viewers incorrectly perceive him as a "pacifist".) And as Carter still pines for his wife, do you expect him to immediately start drooling over Ms Thoris's thorax? (Though the humanoid Martians are mammalian, the script wisely avoids revealing that they lay eggs. Deejah Thoris is kin to the duck-billed platypus.)I'll agree with the naysayers in one respect... Over the past 30 years, American films have become increasingly cool and  affectless, losing the intense emotions of Hollywood's Golden Age. (Had Michael Curtiz directed "John Carter", there would have been fewer objections.) It's also true that effects-heavy films can make it hard for directors to keep the focus on the characters, rather than which shots have to be completed that day. I don't like this, but what's a viewer supposed to do? Reject such films altogether?Is "John Carter" a great (in the absolute sense) film? Of course not. Is it a bad film? Emphatically no. Could it have been better? Definitely. It is what it is -- a well-made adaptation of cheap fiction. If you don't like the latter, fine -- but don't blame the film for being an honest representation of its source.

reviewText: I really enjoyed this movie.  It's based on the 1912 book, Princess of Mars.  My partner thought it was terribly cliche - but that's because other movies, from Star Wars, Avatar to Prince of Persia, borrowed freely from it.  This is the original sci-fi swashbuckling fantasy adventure.  I liked it even more the second time I watched it, with the subtitles on, so that I could catch all the dialogue and names.  The green Tharks are smoothly done.  The overall feel of the sets is authentic - not too glossy, and very similar to the original Star Wars trilogy, actually.  I liked the desert cultures, the multi-legged animals, the red Martian's clothing, and the dog-like creature.  I liked the Princess of Mars the most - she's a strong fighter AND a scientist! Taylor Kitsch was the weak point (very bad facial hair and hairstyle) but once I ignored that the movie improved greatly.  I'm going to start reading the books now.

reviewText: The hatred to this movie by the critics seemed like some kind of self-congratulating schadenfreude bandwagon.  Due to all the FUD put out by the critics and others (the hype about how expensive it was and how it was a flop)  I didn't see this in theaters.  I finally rented it on Amazon download (HD).  I was pleasantly surprised.  I found it to be an entertaining and worthwhile fun movie.ADDENDUM:  While I definitely liked the movie, I notice there is someone (or two) rabid fanboy posters who are copying and pasting the exact * same * comment throughout large parts of the discussion thread.  They may even be one and the same person (sock puppets?)  This kind of crap devalues and degrades the whole Amazon review discussion thread.  Please STOP.  If you liked the movie (and I did) then ...groovy.  Just trust this movie enough to let it stand on it's own and get a life... without pasting robotic comments throughout the entire discussion of this movie!  Don't badger me lobbying to write in for for a sequel.  It's really rude.  If I ever wanted a sequel the desire for it will come within me and not from some outside manipulation.  Unlike fanboys, my identity doesn't come from this movie, it's just something I enjoyed.
summary: Don't understand the smug contempt for this movie - I liked it
